PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I preface my question to the Treasurer by welcoming you back and remarking how nice it is to see you looking so well. I ask the Treasurer: Were the Forward Estimates for 1985-86 predicated on a non-farm gross domestic product growth of approximately 2.5 per cent compared with about 4 1/2 per cent this year? If not, on what assumptions were those Forward Estimates based?
—On a consumer price index rate of 4 1/2 per cent and an implicit non-farm price deflator of 5 per cent.
—Has the Prime Minister seen comments over the weekend by Kim Hughes on the proposed rebel tour of South Africa? Do these comments change the Government's attitude to the tour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I also, on behalf of the Government, welcome you and say how pleased we are to see you looking so well again.
—Thank you.

—I have seen the remarks made by Kim Hughes. I must say that I think too much of the debate has come to be centred now on individuals. I would like to get it back to principles, where I believe it belongs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government remains firm in its opposition to the tour. I would draw the attention of the House to certain facts. The fact that the South African authorities had to offer enormous sums of money for Australian players to tour, the fact that the tour has been arranged in such a clandestine and conspiratorial manner behind the backs of the Australian cricket authorities and the fact that the emphasis has been so strongly put on the bringing together of an Australian team to play tests against South Africa rather than just getting a few Australian individuals demonstrate that South Africa is desperate for the political legitimacy which is associated with a sporting tour by an apparently representative Australian team. The South African authorities are prepared, apparently, to go to almost any lengths to achieve that end. Clear evidence of South African political involvement in the tour is provided by comments in today's Press in which it is reported that people at the level of the South African Government have expressed joy about the apparent problems that have been created for the Australian Government on this issue.

It is interesting to note that the organisers of the tour attempt to argue that sport, including cricket, in South Africa is racially integrated. The fact that this is not so is dramatically demonstrated by what I am about to say. I ask those on the other side of the House who have been raucous just to listen quietly to these facts. Several months ago, well before we had heard of this rebel tour, the Government invited Mr Krifh Mackerdhuj, President of the South African Cricket Board, a non-racial body which opposes the South African Cricket Union and a member of the non-racial South African Council on Sport, to visit Australia. That was the invitation. His organisation and similar organisations oppose international sporting contacts with South Africa while the apartheid system continues to prevail. Mr Mackerdhuj was due to arrive in Australia shortly. Our Embassy in South Africa has reported over the weekend that he will not be able to accept our invitation. Why will he not be able to accept our invitation? It is because the South African Government will not give him a passport. This represents the third occasion on which Mr Mackerdhuj has been refused a passport. I suggest that any reasonable person would have to agree that nothing more clearly demonstrates the falseness of the glib assertion that South African sport is not political.

There is no intention on this Government's part to take similar action towards the rebel cricketers. This is a free country and, as they have correctly said, they are free and have every right to make up their own minds, but the Government is concerned that Australia should not give comfort to the apartheid regime. We also have to think of the possible consequences for Australia's international competition not only in cricket but also in other events such as the World Cup Athletics to be held in Canberra in October, the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh and Brisbane's bid for the 1992 Olympic Games.

It is said that Australia trades with South Africa and that therefore it is illogical and hypo- critical that we should take an attitude against sporting contact. I believe that the Leader of the Opposition at least, if not those raucous members in cockies' corner, understands the distinction. Let me make it clear that I am not going to say of Kim Hughes and other people that they may not, with full integrity, believe that they are able and entitled to make the decision they have made. I would simply say quietly on behalf of the Government and, I hope, on behalf of at least a considerable number of people on the Opposition side of this House, that they should consider the position in these terms: It is quite clear that there is nothing that the Australian Government can do unilaterally to stop trade with South Africa. No actions we can take in that area would affect the legitimacy or otherwise of or give aid or comfort to the South African regime. We have made it quite clear that to have an effect, there would need to be universal or near universal action in the area of trade sanctions.

The critical difference is that Australia and a few other sporting nations have the unique capacity to have an effect on South Africa. South Africa craves, through international sporting competition, the legitimacy which that international competition gives it. Because we have that unique capacity and because the South African Government so obviously craves that recognition, as is obvious from all that is going on at the moment, we have that opportunity. I suggest, quietly and responsibly, to Kim Hughes and these other fine Australian cricketers, who have given so much for their country and for whom their country has done so much, that they think about and understand that distinction.

Having said those things, it is legitimate, in conclusion, to ask: Where does the Opposition stand on this matter? As usual, chaos reigns. In the House on 15 May I commended the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Goldstein, for his support of the Government's position which he made clear was consistent with the Gleneagles Agreement. On 17 May, however, on the ABC National program the Opposition spokesman on sport, the honourable member for Richmond from the National Party, not from the Liberal Party, supported the rebel tour.

I ask, as I believe the House is entitled to ask: What does the Leader of the Opposition propose to do about this? Is he prepared to follow the leadership and the principal position of his predecessor Malcolm Fraser, or is he once again prepared to act in a short term, spineless and opportunistic manner? I conclude by quoting the honourable member for Goldstein in the Australian Financial Review of 16 May. It is important that Opposition members remember this. This is what the shadow spokesman for foreign affairs said on that date:
Malcolm Fraser once said to me 'In politics there is very little room for conscious but, I Malcolm Fraser, would die in the ditch on the question of race'.
The member for Goldstein went on to say:
'And he knew that was my disposition and I made that public last year . . . and many times in my actions'.
The member for Goldstein concluded:
As far as I am concerned there is no doubt the Opposition policy is what it was in government. It is what it was and will remain that.

That was a clear statement of principle and it is a pity that there is not a repudiation of the alleged shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism who purports to speak for the Opposition on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Government's disharmony and factional fighting over tax policy abated sufficiently to allow the Treasurer to advise the House whether the White Paper on taxation will contain a preferred position-and I do not refer to the Prime Minister's one of last week?

—The Leader of the Opposition has been a Minister in this place for years and he knows that this Government, like all governments, will present its documentation when it is good and ready. That is when the Leader of the Opposition will receive his answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Nuclear magnetic resonance imaging is a genuine advance in medical diagnosis. There is great concern among radiologists in this country about the need for its controlled introduction. Can the Minister advise the House of the Government's plans to ensure that this important new medical technology is introduced in a rational and planned way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government recognises that nuclear magnetic resonance imaging is an important new radiology technology, particularly accurate and sensitive in diagnosis of brain and spinal disease. However, there are major costs associated with this technology. The individual scanner costs between $1.2m and $2.6m and there are high operating costs, but it has the potential to generate significant costs for the health system and there are dangers of inappropriate and excessive use. For these reasons the National Health Technology Assessment Advisory Panel proposed that NMRIs should be introduced in three public hospitals, and there should be no medical benefits for a period of three years while they are evaluated. However, that proposal has been overtaken by events and by the development of NMRI technology. I have therefore written to all State Ministers proposing an alternative method of funding the controlled introduction of this new technology. Under this proposal there will be a Medicare benefit for NMRI services, but it would be restricted to services performed in one nominated installation, preferably a teaching hospital in each mainland State.

ANSWER.PARA: For people in Tasmania and the Northern Territory access to those scanners would be through the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme. Thus there would be a two-year trial for these machines, with one unit in each mainland State, although I have indicated to the governments of New South Wales and Victoria that we would be prepared to consider a request for a second unit after one year. Of course, the States will meet the costs of purchasing or leasing the installations, although they will be able to levy a facility change for fee for service use. This will provide a proper way of evaluating this new technology and assure a cost-efficient introduction. I am looking forward to receiving answers soon from all Ministers.

I point out to the honourable member for Perth that the Western Australian Health Department supports the proposal and plans a single nuclear magnetic resonance imaging machine in the Sir Charles Gardiner Hospital. It supports the general approach as a proper method of evaluating such a procedure before any general benefit is provided. I also point out that both the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists accept this approach to the new technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Did the suppressed Economic Planning Advisory Council report suggest that unemployment rates might fall to between 6 and 7 per cent if there were a reduction in potential wages drift? Has this report been suppressed because the implications which flow from this conclusion are incompatible with the Government's and the Australian Council of Trade Union's opposition to a deregulation of the centralised rigid labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no suppression of any report. The office of EPAC makes its own decision on what it presents to EPAC. In fact, Mr Miller issued a statement this morning in which he said that he believed it would take some considerable time before the office 'could be satisfied that the technical base of this work was sound and sufficiently well understood'. In other words, he is making the point that he has a draft statement on his hands. It was his view that it should not be put to EPAC, although I might add that he said this morning that, contrary to the report which was published today, the draft report indicated that an unemployment rate as low as 5 per cent by 1989 appeared feasible.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, that is at odds with the report in the Australian Financial Review, to which the honourable gentleman referred. So the parameters of this question about unemployment rising, on the basis of this draft report, are wrong. I make the more important point that Mr Miller himself has said that it will take some considerable time before he is satisfied with the technical base of the work. What he wishes to give EPAC is entirely a matter for his office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am pleased to see you back. I address my question to the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that during the last decade Australian consumers have, as a direct result of non-uniformity of food laws, faced higher costs in excess of half a billion dollars? The honourable member for Capricornia has had a long struggle in this area. Did the Minister preside over a Health Ministers conference last week? Did those Ministers agree on the need for uniform legislation? Do we need seven sets of bureaucrats to police a tin of baked beans? If not, will the Government exercise its undoubted constitutional power and enact legislation to remedy this mess? If the Minister is not prepared to do so, he has my personal assurance that I will seek Caucus support to bring in a private member's Bill to clean up the mess.

—On the evidence that I have, the assertion by the honourable member for Hawker that the lack of uniform food standards in this country has cost the consumer something like $500m over the past decade is correct. Certainly the present estimate is that it is costing something like $50m a year. As to the second part of this question, no, I did not preside over the Health Ministers Conference last week. That role was performed by my colleague the Minister for Health in Queensland. The conference considered the issue of uniform standards. The Commonwealth put forward a proposal that every State should automatically, by reference, include the food standards issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council and that a food council consisting of the Health Ministers should be created to deal with any disputes and to ensure continuing uniformity in the implementation of those standards. I must say that the Health Ministers received those proposals sympathetically. There are a number of details to be worked out, but I believe that this proposal offers a co-operative way of ensuring national food standards in this country. I also made it quite clear that, if we could not do it through this co-operative method, because of the cost to the community the Commonwealth would have seriously to consider national legislation.

Furthermore, will he release the letter immediately to other summit participants or, at the very least, release it publicly so that we can all see what was in that information and that it is not just part of a deal with the ACTU?

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of reported remarks by the Chairman of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, Mr Jim Bye, that the new Federal dairy arrangements are a sell-out to New Zealand, that New Zealand vetoed some sections of the Kerin plan before the States had even seen it and that New Zealand was given more favourable consideration than Australian dairy interests? Are Mr Bye's remarks a correct interpretation of the Government's decisions regarding new Federal dairy arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members are aware, I have been attending quite a few meetings and there is a lot of interest in the Government's plans for the dairy industry. As a result of those meetings, I have been receiving quite a few letters from dairy farmers who have been saying that at least they understand what is in the plan, because industry leadership is spreading a lot of propaganda, if not absolute lies. I have met with Mr Bye singly and collectively on at least three or four occasions and have gone through these issues with him. Of course, what is being played is straight politics and straight propaganda.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me set the facts straight. There have been no deals, secret or otherwise, between the Australian Government and the New Zealand Government on dairy policy. There has been one unsolicited letter from the New Zealand High Commissioner to me which was an instruction from his Government detailing New Zealand's attitude to entitlements under the Australian Dairy Industry Conference plan. I also wrote to the New Zealand High Commissioner giving details of the Government's decisions on dairy arrangements. That letter was sent some time after I informed the States and had made a public announcement on the new arrangements. Whenever dairying was discussed at the Australian Agricultural Council, New Zealand, which has observer status to that Council, was excluded. The New Zealand Government never sought to, had a chance to, nor was it afforded an opportunity to, veto the Government's proposals.

What the Government says is that the retention of an efficient and competitive Australian industry is the best defence against fair competition from any country, New Zealand included, in third markets or here at home. The new dairy arrangements will make the industry more efficient and competitive, unlike the current arrangements that have caused the problems we have-the socialistic Sinclair scheme-which are sending farmers and factories broke and leading Australian consumers to subsidise foreign consumers with little benefit to Australian farmers. Under the closer economic relations, negotiated with manic determination by Mr Fraser and Mr Anthony, dairy products from New Zealand are allowed into Australia in unrestricted quantities duty free. The same things prevailed under the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. We cannot wish New Zealand away. It is another country, you fools.

A memorandum of understanding between the Australian and New Zealand industries limited New Zealand exports to Australia, and then only for cheese, which are limited to the rate of growth in the Australian market. What the Government has said is that unfair competition from New Zealand or anywhere else will not be tolerated. If New Zealand should be found to be subsidising exports in Australia in order to meet the Australian price-that is, 130 per cent of the average export returns for three years for Australian products, above the undumped, unsubsidised export prices-then the Government will take action under the provisions of CER. What Mr Bye is spreading is lies, and he knows it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the last six months of brawling between Cabinet and Caucus and between Cabinet Ministers which has contributed, undoubtedly, to the reduction of confidence in the Australian Government, both at home and abroad. Is it not the case that the latest public row between the Prime Minister and his Minister for Education over the reintroduction of tertiary fees can only further undermine the confidence in government? Does he intend to advise the House that he now accepts that the concepts of government in this nation have changed, that collective responsibility is no longer an aim or an element of government but rather that fractured factionalised fighting is to be the order of the day under the guise of some open discussion of policy? On that note, will he advise the Australian people just when he proposes to institute the discussion on the reintroduction of tertiary fees?

—This is probably the most hypocritical question that has ever been asked by the Leader of the Opposition. It is an Opposition which is wracked by division between the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia and within the Liberal Party. Members of the Liberal and National parties hate and detest one another personally and their policies. Having exposed the hypocrisy of this gentleman opposite, the answers to his three questions are: No, no, no.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I refer the Minister to the Government's decision to terminate the diesel fuel subsidy for the Great Barrier Reef island resorts. I ask: What is the likely impact of this decision on this vitally important tourist area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In short, the impact will be very small. I was rather bemused by what happened the other night when the Treasurer was making a speech and he mentioned the removal of this subsidy, which is worth something like $300,000 to the tourist islands. The almost manic glee with which that was greeted by the honourable member for Moncrieff, amongst others, simply staggered me. Perhaps I should put the history of this matter in context. In, I think, the 1980 Budget the then Government made a couple of incredible decisions regarding the tourist industry. One was to take from the tourist industry the exemption it had from paying diesel excise. The other was to put a 20 per cent sales tax on the building of boats.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government decided in a time of great recession in the tourist industry in Queensland to allow the tourist islands to retain that exemption-it has meant something like $500,000 in a full year-to recompense those islands for the cost of electricity generation from diesel fuel. It must be remembered that that concession was given back to them at a time of recession in their industry. Of course, in the last two years the tourist industry has recreated enormous prosperity, especially in the tourist islands. I am sure that every Queensland member of the Opposition would be among the first, if he had one iota of honesty, to admit that. Their rate of occupancy and prosperity has gone through the roof in the last two years.

The Government has made two decisions which have been principally responsible for that. One was the removal of the 20 per cent sales tax on the building of tourists boats. The return to those islands of the removal of that sales tax has been many hundreds of thousands of dollars. That is a great exemption which we have given back to them. They are now building their pleasure boats in Australia instead, as they were doing during the Opposition's period in government, of running off to Taiwan to build them and destroying an industry in Australia. The savings to those islands from being able to build those boats in Australia without sales tax has been hundreds of thousands of dollars. Having taken away $500,000 in the diesel excise exemption, one would have sworn blind from the reaction of honourable members opposite that the Government had wrought despair and disaster upon them. That is far from the truth.

Also, with the support of the Treasurer, we increased the depreciation rate on the construction of buildings in tourist resorts from 2 1/2 to 4 per cent. The effect in Queensland has been quite profound. In fact, in the last two years there has been a 71 per cent improvement in the building of tourist resorts in Queensland simply because of that concession we gave them. The great guffaws of the Opposition that greeted that decision of $500,000 merely showed up how stupid members of the Opposition are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Speaker, and offer you a warm welcome home. Will the Minister for Defence inform the House what criteria were used in granting Australian Shipbuilding Industries (Western Australia) Pty Ltd the contract to build Australia's new patrol boats and why the submission by North Queensland Engineering and Agents Pty Ltd, whose patrol boat construction and design have received international acclaim, was rejected, to the disadvantage of numerous workers in the far north of Queensland who are already adding to the great pool of unemployment created by the abandonment of the sugar industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could start by going through for the honourable member the stated requirements which were developed in consultation with the Pacific nations interested in the boat and then answering his question as far as possible within the constraints of the necessary commercial in confidence requirements imposed on us. The areas looked for were the compliance of the proposed boat design with stated requirements, the cost, the level of Australian and New Zealand manufactured content, the ship builder's production capability, facilities and quality control arrangements, the ship builder's proposals for the training of the crews and maintainers of the boats, and the degree to which the boats could be supported and maintained locally by the participating nations. On top of that, the requirements for the boats were developed after, as I said, extensive consultation. They included survivability in extreme sea states occurring in the region, ability to operate continuously in rough seas, an overall length of 25 to 35 metres, a maximum sustained speed of 20 knots, a range of at least 2,500 nautical miles at 12 knots and provision for a crews of 14 as required for the envisaged role of the vessels.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite a substantial number of the tenderers met all those requirements and were therefore capable for being considered in contrast with each other. The tenderer that was eventually successful on just about all of the criteria came out ahead of the other competitors-it would not have been selected otherwise-in cost and in the other areas that I indicated. The only proper basis on which one can appropriately take decisions in relation to a process in which one has sought bids from companies is to take advice on who most accurately meets those requirements. Where there is a clear meeting of those requirements and an obvious capability to perform to the standards set down, one must go to the tenderer that meets those requirements. That has been done in this instance and on those grounds ASI was awarded the contract.

I appreciate the comments made about impacts in the area of NQEA. I did not need to be advised on that matter by the honourable member for Kennedy. The honourable member for Leichhardt keeps me constantly informed on that subject and he mounted-

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?

—Presumably he was not given notice of this matter by the honourable member for Kennedy. The honourable member for Leichhardt has strongly advocated the interests of the yard in his electorate as he would be expected to do given the significance of that company as an employer in his area. He comes to me with constant suggestions on ways in which we might overcome some of the problems that would be associated with that and I am giving consideration to those matters. One way in which we cannot overcome those problems is to enter into a process which effectively, for political reasons, perverts the tender process. We will not engage in that and we did not in this instance.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Trade. Is it a fact that Japan has brought down a package of trade liberalisation measures which have been widely reported in the Australian Press? Can the Minister inform the House if the recent package contains anything of significant benefit to Australia and what measures he proposes to take to ensure that Australia will benefit from Japan's measures to open its market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question because it is a very important one indeed. The April package presents a positive step on the part of Japanese because, for the first time, it includes long term policies which are transparent and multilaterally focused. A three-year action program has been adopted based on recommendations of an advisory committee of private sector experts-Australia presented its views to this committee-in such areas as tariff, standards, certification systems and promotion of imports. Japan accepts the basic approach of 'freedom in principle, restrictions as exceptions' and Prime Minister Nakasone made an unprecedented direct appeal to the Japanese people to buy more foreign goods.

ANSWER.PARA: The framework is now set for Japan to introduce new trade liberalisation measures that will have a real impact. We have impressed upon Japan, from the Prime Ministerial level down, the need to ensure that its market opening measures are for all comers, not just for American products and services. Solutions to trade friction issues with Japan's partners must not lead to a bad result for Australia or other Pacific countries.

I turn to the second part of the honourable member's question. There are a number of positive elements in the April package and in Japan's trade liberalisation program generally. An element of the package is an expansion of the specific products trade expansion program-STEP. The Japanese Government has responded positively to Australia's request for assistance under STEP. For example, Australian wine and furniture are included in STEP and we will be seeking to include other products in the future. Additionally, Australia will benefit from improved plant quarantine facilities at Narita Airport and improved treatment in standards and certification systems for certain manufactured products. Much more remains to be done to translate trade liberalisation rhetoric into practical actions that will significantly open up the Japanese market to foreign suppliers. At the Australia-Japan Ministerial committee meeting to be held in Tokyo in June, the Australian Government will impress upon the Japanese Government the need for its trade liberalisation measures to have a broad multilateral appeal rather than a selective focus aimed only at its principal trading partners. We will also continue to press that the action program addresses the issues of access and import procedures for agricultural and horticultural products-

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want an extension of time?
—He has got only a couple more paragraphs to read.
—If the National Party of Australia does not want to hear about access for horticultural products, if it does not want to hear it-
—Order! The Minister should return to his answer.

—Including the administration of Japan's plant quarantine regulations. We will also encourage Japan to assume a forthright position of leadership in moving trading nations towards a genuine round of multilateral trade negotiations, focusing on liberalisation of tariff and non-tariff impediments to world trade.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In view of the media attention focused on the planned army expansion in the Bathurst-Orange area, is the Minister aware of the threatened total removal of the communities of Point Parham and Webb Beach in South Australia to provide for an expansion to the Port Wakefield proof range? Is the Minister aware that such an expansion will mean the acquisition by the Department of Defence of some of South Australia's finest recreation beaches? Will the Minister undertake to visit the residents of Point Parham and Webb Beach prior to any decision being taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the various points that have been made by the honourable member for Wakefield because I am nagged constantly on it by the Special Minister of State, who makes his case in a somewhat more extreme manner than the honourable member made his. In that regard, I thank the honourable member. The circumstances to which the honourable member for Wakefield referred are well known to me. On the last point as to whether or not I would visit that area before any final decisions were taken, the answer is yes, I will. I have already undertaken to the honourable member for Port Adelaide, the Special Minister of State, that I will do that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether or not I am aware of the degrees of difficulty and dislocation that will be created, the answer is yes. There is a substantially important task performed by that range as far as the Army is concerned. It is the one place we have for reliably testing shells and it will be very difficult to find an alternative location if we are not going to proceed with the utilisation of the range. There are some other options. I am not sure how acceptable those options are but I will be going through them before I take any final decision on the matter. Any final decision that is taken will balance the Army's requirements in this area with an understanding of the difficulties such a decision would create for local citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In consequence of escalation of civil unrest in both Lebanon and Sri Lanka, will the Minister give consideration to allowing again migrants from each of those nations to enter Australia under the special humanitarian program?

—I thank the honourable member for Lowe for keeping up his reputation of asking questions without notice. The answer is that the Government does now look at applications for entry into this country under the special humanitarian program, both from the Lebanon and from Sri Lanka. There are many trouble spots in this world. We have the Indo-Chinese problem, and we had something to say about that last week, but there is also the northern Irish problem and the Sikh problem in India. One could go around the world and notice that there are many applications to come to this country under the conditions that people would be so much better off here than elsewhere. In fact, we get two million inquiries for a program that is running at the rate of about 80,000. Among that 80,000, of course, we give a lot of preference to those under family reunion. The Government looks sympathetically at every one of the applications that come to it. There is already a very special program for the Lebanon. Indeed, we are considering every day applications from Sri Lanka and the other trouble spots I have mentioned.

—Will the Minister for Social Security inform the House of current estimates of fraud involving social security payments, conceded by his predecessor to be in the region of $300m? Has the Minister initiated any new measures to combat fraud which would result in the saving of $25m claimed by the Treasurer in his economic statement of 14 May? Finally, if there are no new measures, why has such a sizable sum only now been considered recoverable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I think it is extremely important in this area to define one's terms. While it is true that there is and has been through the years a substantial problem in the Department of Social Security in terms of overpayments, that is not to say that there is such a substantial problem in terms of fraud. I think the fundamental problem that we deal with in the Department of Social Security is more to do with people being paid money to which they are certainly not entitled; it is not necessarily their fault and there is not in any sense any intention on their part to receive payment in an immoral way. So I think it is important to recognise that for the most part these substantial overpayments have resulted from regrettable errors that we need to overcome. It is also true that a small percentage of the total overpayments-perhaps less than 10 per cent-relates to some kind of fraud. So the Department in terms of its strategy seeks certainly to reduce the level of overpayment and to eliminate fraud.

ANSWER.PARA: I think if we are to administer social security payments more effectively and to reduce fraud substantially, which is certainly what we are seeking to do this year as we did last year, a systems approach needs to be applied. I draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that last year we shifted towards a system of direct deposits. This system of paying people by way of direct deposits as opposed to paying by cheque, is a much more efficient and effective system which will not only reduce costs but also will reduce overpayments and the level of fraud.

PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generation of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The highest real interest rates in Australia for fifty years.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is always talking about the record things it has done. There is one record we never heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talk about, and that is the record real interest rates the Hawke Government has given us over the last two and a bit years. So that we get it straight, the real interest rate is the difference between the rate of inflation and the nominal rate of interest. Last Friday one of the largest private trading banks in Australia, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, lifted its prime interest rate for loans over $100,000 to no less than 17 1/2 per cent. If one accepts that we now have an inflation rate which is running at about 5 1/2 per cent, that means that at the moment, according to that measure, this country has a real interest rate of no less than 12 per cent. Without any doubt Australian house owners, Australian business people, Australian farmers, Australian consumers, Australian investors and Australian borrowers are now operating with the highest real interest rates this country has seen since the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: It is little wonder that we hear so little from honourable members opposite about that record achievement of the Hawke Government. We hear a great deal about other things-we hear a great deal about this Government's economic luck; we hear a great number of quotations from people after the mini-Budget; and we hear a great deal of self-adulation-but we hear very little indeed now from either the Prime Minister or the Treasurer on the matter of interest rates. Both of them have become decidedly coy on the subject of interest rates over the last several months. That is little wonder because before the election one could not keep them quiet on the subject of interest rates. They competed with each other to make wild, outlandish predictions about what would happen to interest rates in Australia. On the Sunday program on 4 November last year the Treasurer said:
. . . the fact is there is scope, I believe, for further falls in interest rates.
On the same program a little later he really got warmed up and into his stride. He said:

. . . I'm sure that if, as we get through the tax rundown period of this year, where the market's always a little apprehensive now after the float, of about the capacity of funding the tax rundown period, you'll see declines in interest rates.

That was what the Treasurer said on 4 November. I will quote what he said in the House of Representatives when it met on 25 February. Despite the market having pushed up interest rates, he was questioned about his prediction before the election on what would happen to interest rates. What did the Treasurer say on that occasion? He said:

I am quite prepared to stand precisely by what I said in the election campaign. I said on that occasion that I accepted the view of most market commentators that there was a further interest rate step fall ahead of us--
I repeat that he said 'a further interest rate step fall ahead of us'-
particularly after we get through the tax rundown period. I stand by that.
That is what he said on 25 February 1985. On the PM program on 14 March he went on to say:
I still stand by the remark I made in the election campaign that I think there is an interest rate step fall ahead for Australia and its interest rate structure generally through 1985.

He repeated that affirmation on 20 March in the House of Representatives and as late as 17 April this year when he was asked again about the statement he had made before the election campaign on what would happen to interest rates. What did he say again? He said:
I stick to that commitment.

They were the words of the Treasurer. As late as 17 April this year he was sticking by the commitment. Yet this is the man who now has added the record of the highest real interest rates in Australia for the last 50 years to his achievement of being the biggest spending, highest taxing Treasurer this country has seen since Federation. It is little wonder that the Treasurer has declined to take part in this debate. Finally, having been overseas, the Treasurer made another remark. It is very interesting that the remark to which I am about to refer was made after the Treasurer had visited New York, after he had participated in a conference on the financial outlook in Australia and after he had talked to people about the attitude of overseas investors to Australia. When the Treasurer came back his tone was markedly different. He had undoubtedly learned a few of the facts of life about the attitude to Australia of international investors. At a Press conference on 29 April 1985 the Treasurer said:

. . . there has been, owing to the shift in the exchange rate an unavoidable tightening in conditions in the market and I am not making a prediction about interest rates in the second half of the year.

In other words, he had cut and run. The facts of life had been brought home to him in New York. He had been told by the international investors that interest rates in Australia were going to go up in the latter part of 1985 and that, if he valued his credibility and his reputation-to borrow one of his own expressions-he would get out of the cart of predicting future falls in interest rates. We now have a very silent and contrite Treasurer on the subject of interest rates. But I do not mind. There are on the record plenty of quotations he has made over the past few months and of which we will be reminding him during the rest of 1985 and 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Prime Minister also?

—Let me come to the Prime Minister. My friend from Berowra reminds me of the Prime Minister. If honourable members thought the Treasurer was expansive on the subject of interest rates, they have not heard anything. I remind them of the words of the Prime Minister. He got positively lyrical when he started talking about interest rates. He started off in a fairly sober tone by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at present, the outlook for interest rates is as bright as it has been for more than a decade.
Can we not see it-the arms uplifted and the ear being twitched-as he said that. Then he went on to say:
we will continue our work of putting the public finances of this nation back in order and creating the conditions where further interest rate reductions can occur.
That was said to a business luncheon in Adelaide on 20 November 1984. Of course, the best quotation of all came a little later in that speech. This is what he had to say:
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the past 20 months.
He got even better:
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds.
In the very near future, we will harvest the crop.

It was absolutely marvellous! That is what the Prime Minister said on 20 November. Some harvest! Some crop! A bare six or seven months after that outlandish, deceitful, disgraceful and careless prediction was made by the Prime Minister to try to influence the election result he has landed us with the highest interest level of real interest rates this country has seen since the 1930s. That is certainly some harvest and some crop! I remind the House that, according to a table I have obtained from the Parliamentary Library-monthly economic and social indicators for April 1985-yields on long term government bonds of five years or more in real terms are 8.2 per cent in Australia, 7.6 per cent in the United States, 4.8 per cent in the United Kingdom, 3.8 per cent in Japan and 5 per cent in West Germany. That compares with figures of 7.2 per cent, 8.5 per cent, 5.3 per cent, 5.1 per cent and 5.2 per cent in June 1984.

Let me take the House back to February 1983. The real interest then in Australia was 2.8 per cent. In the United States it was 6.9 per cent, in the United Kingdom 5.3 per cent, in Japan 5.5 per cent, and in West Germany 3.5 per cent. It is all very well to say, as undoubtedly the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) will say, that since February 1983 the inflation rate has gone down and that that is why the real interest rate has gone up. In anticipation of that response from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, I would say that in other countries where the inflation rate has come down real interest rates have come down in sympathy. That has not happened in Australia. Indeed, the reverse has happened. I can remember the Treasurer saying that we were the high interest rate specialists. I would have to cede that title totally to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. He is the high interest rate specialist of the last 50 years. The Treasurer has given us real interest rates that would have been undreamt of.

High real interest rates have very adverse effects on the outlook of investors in Australia. There may be many domestic savers who think that high real interest rates are a good idea-I suppose that high real interest rates for domestic savers are a good idea-but they are not such a good idea if one is thinking of investing in a business because what they represent is an additional cost and they are a factor which inhibits one from making a business investment. They represent an assessment by many people on international financial markets. I can do no better than borrow the rhetoric of the Treasurer who has said repeatedly over the last few months that now we have a floating exchange rate people overseas will make sharp and instantaneous judgments on us and those judgments will be translated directly into domestic financial and economic conditions in Australia. That is happening in relation to high real interest rates in Australia.

The level of interest rates in Australia will stay up for some time. Interest rates will stay up to support the fall that has occurred over the last few months in the value of the Australian dollar. The continued drift in economic policy management, particularly in the wages policy area, the rowing that is going on inside the Government over taxation, the running fight over the reintroduction of university fees and all the other disputes inside the Government are doing absolutely nothing to improve international financial perceptions so far as Australia is concerned. There is certainly a very widespread belief that economic policy in Australia over the last few months has become very rudderless and the previous perception that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had a firm grip on things and were giving a sense of direction and purpose has changed. The fact that real interest rates have gone up so much over the last few months and have so totally discredited, undermined and dishonoured the Prime Minister and the Treasurer's promises is a very sure and certain sign of that. The higher the real interest rate the more risk the financial community sees for Australia's future.

The level of real interest rates is very much a barometer of what the world financial community thinks about Australia. It needs higher interest rates in this country in order to invest in Australian dollars and thus insulate itself against potential exchange losses through a downward movement in our currency. The interesting thing to note is that despite the fact that our real interest rates are about one per cent higher than those of the United States, and are significantly higher than those of our major trading partners other than the United States, there is less private capital inflow coming into Australia than there was coming in last year. This may well mean that the rest of the world is not convinced at present that Australia is a good investment, despite the fact that our interest rates have moved higher than they were last year. That could well mean that even further upward movements in the level of our interest rates will be needed to sustain the sorts of levels of private capital inflow that are needed in the face of the very large current account deficit that Australia is running and also, of course, the very significant weakening of the Australian dollar that has occurred over the last few months that has given us the largest depreciation that this country has seen in her currency in the last 30 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is going to get worse.

—It is not a very optimistic picture. As my colleague the honourable member for Menzies says, the situation will get worse. There is no likelihood that the level of real interest rates will be abated in the near future. Even the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have stopped making those foolish predictions that they made before the last election campaign. I remind the House again that the Treasurer stopped predicting falls in interest rates after he had been in New York a couple of weeks ago. No doubt he had his ears pinned back while he was there. He was told by the investors in New York: 'Look, chum, there's no prospect that interest rates in your country will fall. If you want us to put large heaps of money into Australia you will have to make sure that your interest rates stay very high'. So the Treasurer, on his return to Australia, stopped making those foolish predictions. He told the Prime Minister to do likewise. Since then we have seen a very humiliating and significant change of tune.

SPEECH.PARA: This Treasurer has the distinction of having given Australia the highest level of real interest rates that we have seen since the 1930s. It is not a bad record. It is a record and an achievement which we do not hear a great deal about, but it is a record and an achievement nonetheless. I can assure the House, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that they will be reminded of that contribution to our economic management over the months ahead. They will be reminded of the promises they made so wilfully and deceitfully before the last election. They will be reminded that everything that has happened in the interest rate area since has totally dishonoured and repudiated those reckless, shameful promises that they made before the last election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has given this House more heat than light. Of course, he has done so in his quest to talk down the Australian economy against our national interests. He has done so in the absence of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who is unable to be here today because he is getting on with the excellent work he has done over the last two years to lift the Australian economy from the abysmal depths to which it had sunk, thanks to the work of the coalition Government and, in particular, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who rants and rails today.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point to be made about this spurious matter of public importance is that it is false to claim that real interest rates are at their highest point for 50 years. I will come back to this and outline just what the interest rate history has been. I admit straight away that real rates of interest are certainly far higher than the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or I would want to see at present. Why is this so? The main reason why real rates of interest are high is that the rate of inflation is low because, indeed, the Government has had success in its campaign against inflation. We have now to be grateful to the Opposition for bringing forward the matter of public importance because it draws to the attention of the Australian Parliament and the Australian people the wonderful success achieved by the Hawke Labor Government in its fight against inflation.

Whereas we inherited an inflation rate of 11.5 per cent, we are now, according to the figures for the most recent quarter, that is, to the end of March 1985, enjoying a rate of inflation of 5.3 per cent for the year ended March 1985-a reduction of more than one-half of the inflation rate we inherited from the Liberal-National Party coalition. Yet those Parties have had the gall to propose this matter of public importance to the Parliament today. We now have the opportunity, as a result of that gall, to point out just how successful we have been. I remind the House that the real rate of interest is the difference between the nominal rate and the rate of inflation. If there is a lowering of the rate of inflation, there would be, of course, an increase in the real rate of interest. The challenge is to sustain the low rate of inflation because the nominal rates of interest will come down in the wake of that. What is keeping the nominal rates high at this time? As I have already said, the Government does not think that we should have such high nominal rates of interest. Firstly, there has been a lack of adequate competition in the Australian financial system.

Frankly, the profits of Australian banks are very high at present. My personal view is that they are too high. I shall point out the latest profit rates for various banks. The Commonwealth Bank's profit for the last year reported compared with that for the year before was up 57.7 per cent. The profit of Westpac Banking Corporation is up 37.7 per cent, the profit of the Australia and, New Zealand Banking Group Ltd is up 35.9 per cent and the profit of the National Australia Bank is up 41.7 per cent. Of course in those figures there is some element of the improved economic conditions. Also we have the fact that the rate of return on shareholders funds for banks is somewhat higher than that recorded by other groups in the economy. This is because there has not been adequate competition in the financial system. Nothing was done by the Liberal and National parties during their 30 years in office to make sure that there is adequate competition in the financial system. We have done something about it; we have arranged for 16 new licences. A far greater efficiency is now likely to result than applied under the Liberal and National Party governments.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reason why nominal rates are high is the need for relativities in this country with rates in markets overseas. Deregulation has facilitated the flow of funds across borders but our market has to look at rates, say, in the New York capital market. We are doing something about that too. I had the job of representing this country at meetings of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank in both Washington and Bangkok during April. I quote what I said for instance, to the interim committee of the International Monetary Fund:

Despite a welcome convergence of inflation rates, there has been a pronounced divergence between fiscal policy in the United States and that of several other major countries. The Government dissaving which has taken place in the United States since 1981 has resulted in continued upward pressure on interest rates and the United States dollar, a negative trend in the current account deficit and unprecedented net capital inflows into the United States. The exchange rates of non-dollar currencies have weakened, creating a potential for a revival of inflationary pressures.

I went on to point out that this did not help the rest of the world's interest rates because of the need for relativities with the all too-high interest rates in the United States. We are doing something about them; we are having our say in international fora. I was very pleased, when meeting Mr James Baker, the new finance Minister of the Reagan Administration, to learn from him-both in his public utterances and privately-that the United States is addressing that problem. So we are having success there too.

The third reason why nominal interest rates are higher than they should be is, of course, inflationary expectation. I know that we have to continue being successful in our fight against inflation in order to bring down inflationary expectations. How more successful can one be than to bring inflation down from the 11.5 per cent that we inherited to the 5.3 per cent that it is now? I will give honourable members one reason why inflationary expectations are not what they ought to be: There are some misinformed people who believe that in three years' time we might have the Liberals back with their discredited wages policy and we should get back to the 11.5 per cent inflation rate. One cannot stop people from being misinformed politically. Of course any informed observer would know that with the wages policy that the Liberal and National parties now have there is not a hope of their returning to government and not a hope of us returning to the sorts of inflation rates that we suffered under their Government. However, there are some misinformed people and that is one of the reasons why inflationary expectations are higher than they ought to be. The Liberal and National parties wages policy would be one for the survival of the fittest. They go into the charade of the market determining wage rates. Certainly we would have the strong unions playing havoc in this country; they would not be party to any wages accord, such as the accord which as been such a marked success in bringing down the rate of inflation in this country.

I said earlier that I would return to the level of interest rates and the false claims that have been made about that level by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Let me just point out how phoney were his words. He was the high interest rate specialist during 1982. The large overdraft rate then was 17.5 per cent; bank bills were 21 per cent and more, and home loans were 13.5 per cent. In all cases those rates were higher than now. In fact, his matter of public importance is wrong in its title. It is very easy to demonstrate examples where real rates were higher under the Liberals too. In April 1982 bank bills were 21.65 per cent when the consumer price index was 10.6 per cent. Work out the difference there between 21.65 per cent and 10.6 per cent for the real rate of interest. The real rate was more than 11 per cent, which is higher-

TALK.START.PARA: —That was lower than it is now.

—It is 12 per cent now.

—It was much higher than today. Bill rates are 15.5 per cent and the CPI is 5.3 per cent; therefore, the real rate is below 11 per cent. It is worth looking at the Government's success in the fight against inflation. I mention the March quarter, in which the CPI rose 1.4 per cent, or an annual rate of 5.3 per cent. Compare this with the previous Government's record. It is worth saying again that in the March quarter 1983 the CPI rose by 2.2 per cent, or an annual rate of 11.5 per cent. Over the 12 months period the average inflation rate in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area as 4.7 per cent. The rate of inflation recorded by Australia's major trading partners was 4.1 per cent. Australia's inflation rate is now running at a rate of about one-half of a percentage point above the OECD average and a little more than one per cent higher than the inflation rate recorded for Australia's major trading partners. We have further to go but, my goodness, it is a much better record than the one we inherited.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth looking at what the coalition would do other than run that ruinous wages policy to which I have already referred. The implication of the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is that he would work on monetary policy. He is always calling for this tightening of monetary policy and demanding a credit squeeze and a return to even higher interest rates. Let us contrast that with what the Government is doing. The Government's monetary policy remains one that is firm and non-inflationary. The M3 target was suspended because aggregates were not providing a reliable guide to money conditions. That is the result of deregulation, which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition did not have the guts to put into effect. The Treasurer acknowledged last Tuesday that financial conditions had firmed recently and that policy had played a part in that firming. The firmer stance for monetary policy will be maintained just as long as it is required.

The Deputy Leader made a lot of the claim that the Treasurer had promised lower interest rates. I will read exactly what the Treasurer has said on this subject. He was asked a question during a television program and he responded by saying that, in the conditions that prevail of a seasonal tightening in the second half of the financial year, he agreed with the position of most market commentators that there was a prospect of an interest rate step fall ahead of us. He went on to say, and I quote exactly his words:
Now there has been, owing to the shift in the exchange rate an unavoidable tightening in conditions in the market and I am not making a prediction about interest rates in the second half of the year.

They are his words, they are credible words, and therefore the House can disregard the claims made about the Treasurer by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Of course he said that there is scope for reduction. Surely this House-both sides of it-would agree that there is a scope for reduction. I have mentioned the need for more competition in the financial sector, which of course should bring down nominal rates in the wake of the wonderful success we have had in the reduction in the rate of inflation.

For the past 20 months we have had a period of dramatic change in the Australian financial system. In our first term of office the Labor Government took a number of far-reaching steps to dismantle unnecessary regulation of the financial system. These actions have received widespread acclaim, both in Australia and overseas. They will lead to great success in nominal interest rates coming down in the wake of the wonderful success we have had in bringing down the rate of inflation. Of course, bringing down the rate of inflation is not the only economic indicator. Wherever we look, there is a real rate of growth in the economy. If we look at new motor vehicle registrations, at the level of employment or at the level of unemployment, there is a story of success. Even in real private business fixed investment, where we are hoping for even better things shortly, this firm economic management provides the only real route to falls in interest rates in the medium term. Sound economic management is the reason why the Government has been so successful in managing the economy over the last two years. So it is hypocrisy for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to bring a matter of public importance like this before the House today.

We nevertheless believe that given the fundamental strengths of the Australian economy and, I think, the increasing perception of the strength of the adherence of the Government to the fiscal management which is embodied in the trilogy, that we can expect through the period of this year there will be, I would expect, a lowering in the level of interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are his full stops?

—Well, the Prime Minister is not prone to the use of full stops. That statement was made on 11 April, and we were still looking forward to lower interest rates. Only about a week later the Prime Minister came into this House and emphasised a true statement-that the Government and this country are living beyond their means, and as my colleague the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) mentioned, the expectations that that situation generates is the great difficulty for policy. Interest rates will remain high and firm while ever the Government's massive Budget deficit continues and while ever such expectations remain that the situation of the economy is delicately balanced and could so easily move into a spiral of increased external deficit, further depreciation of the exchange rate, internal inflation, further deficit in our balance of payments, further devaluation and further inflation. There would be an upward spiral of inflation and a fall in activity. It is that sort of expectation that primarily underlies the record high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Government's response? First, there was the response of the mini-Budget last week. It was appropriate that the Government should try to respond in that area. In that the massive Budget deficit of the Government is a major contributing factor to the country's 'living beyond its means' it was important that something be done. Headlines such as 'Unconvincing knife work' in the Australian Financial Review and comments such as 'The mini-Budget was about as hard as warm butter and twice as slippery' by Terry McCrann writing in the Age, tell the story. The only point I want to make in that respect is that the Government has not properly addressed the base figures from which we can assess what has been done. We still do not know what the cuts are supposed to be cuts from and, therefore, what they might contribute to achieving the sort of Budget deficit of, say, $5.5 billion, which is necessary if in fact, as I have said, the confidence of overseas investors as well as Australian investors and consumers is to be restored.

We talk about 'arms' of economic policy. We have talked about fiscal policy. Monetary policy is another important area to which the Government should address itself. In this area we have a continuing refusal to reinstitute monetary targets and that has very powerful implications for expectations about inflation and, hence, higher interest rates. While it is true that in a context of financial deregulation the meaning of monetary aggregates is not so clear, nevertheless the fact is that the prevailing climate in international markets is that monetary targets are necessary to assess monetary policy performance. If the Government is not going to have anything to do with them, the view is that it is trying to hide something. Unless and until the Government does something in that area also interest rates will continue much higher than they need otherwise be, even in the light of the factors to which I have been referring.

The most important, and in many ways, the fundamental aspect about which assessments are being made is the crucial area of wage policy. As I have said, the country is living beyond its means. This is not just a matter of the government. We have, as a result, a massive deficit in the balance of payments, reflecting the tendency of going overseas to meet the demand for goods and services. It is essential that that demand directed overseas be contained. There is the deficit and then there is the devaluation which acts as an automatic corrective if it is allowed to work itself out. It works itself out in terms of reducing living standards, in a temporary way, through the rises in prices-of about 2 to 3 per cent-that it brings about so as to set the scene for living standards to rise again and for sustained growth to be obtained. What do we need for that to be effective? We need for there to be no national adjustment to wages and salaries for that price rise. As has been said, there should be a 'discounting' of the increase in the national wage case. However, apparently the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government's master, says that discounting for devaluation is not on. I would enter a plea for a different word to be used, if that is so offensive to the trade union movement.

The plain fact is, as the Government has acknowledged, that we are in a situation where the country is living beyond its means. In that circumstance the Government, as it has recognised, has to pull in its horns. We get a mini-Budget. I cannot judge how effective it will be. I and many other people have our doubts about its effectiveness. However, the mini-Budget is doing something. But it is not only in that area that the tendency to exceed what the economy can give arises. It also arises from what ordinary consumers and business spend and what the country owes. If we do not have modified adjustment of wages and salaries to counter the devaluation effects, the situation will work itself out in some other way. There is no gain-saying it. It will work itself out in ever-higher inflation and ever-higher unemployment. If the competitiveness of the economy is not restored, the situation will work itself out in higher unemployment.

That is the economic record that honourable members opposite were talking about so proudly. Why is there such a boom in the housing industry? It is because we have made finance readily available because the first home owners scheme is such a success and generally because of improvements in economic conditions.

What is the Opposition's alternative? Is it to hark back to the days of the Fraser Government with harsh monetary policies, economic activity forced down and depression? Is that what honourable members opposite are talking about? They have not given us any alternative at all in this debate. The bottom line on all the figures that have been thrown around this House during this discussion is the level of economic activity. It is clear that economic activity is on the increase, that the figures indicate growth and confidence in the economy. I refer to comments made by the business sector itself about the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last Tuesday night. I repeat for members of the Opposition some of those statements reported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Parliament on 15 May. Mr White of the Business Council of Australia said:

The Council strongly supports the early indication of a firm direction to fiscal policy in 1985-86 embodied in the Treasurer's statement today . . . The fact that the Government has exceeded its target of $1 billion in expenditure reductions is evidence of its determination to succeed in the task of restraint for 1985-86.
Sir Arvi Parbo, speaking on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, said:
Well, I thought the general thrust of what the Government is trying to do and what the Treasurer was saying was most welcome . . . I think it is going to be seen as a good beginning.
Mr Ken Court, the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, had this to say:

The Federal Government's economic statement is a positive and constructive first step in a longer term program of expenditure reduction and reform at both the Federal and State Government levels. The economic statement in many respects amounts to a concerted first attack on waste and inefficiency in Federal public spending. This is to be warmly applauded.

I could go on. So when it comes to the bottom line there is public confidence in the economy. Everybody in Australia except members of the Opposition has confidence in it. The Opposition members' assertions are false. Their records speak for themselves. In 1982 the level of home loan interest rates was 13.5 per cent, the interest rate on bank bills was 21 per cent or more and the rate on the largest overdrafts was 17.5 per cent-all higher than today's interest rates. The current interest levels are based on a number of desirable conditions. The Government has a firm monetary policy accompanied by a firm fiscal policy, support for the exchange rate and strong growth in the economy in both consumption spending and investment. The Opposition's alternative is to return to monetarism-a credit squeeze and high interest rates. That is what this country will be looking at if it ever returns the Opposition parties to government. There is a clear difference between the policies of the Opposition and the Government. The Government is getting the results. The economy is sound, employment growth is up and confidence is high. SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to extend the operation of the nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy and the phosphate fertiliser subsidy schemes at current rates for a further 12 months until 30 June 1986. The two fertiliser assistance schemes were introduced in the mid-1960s as a means to stimulate agricultural production and have been extended with some modification on several occasions since that time. They were due to expire on 30 June 1985.

In July 1984, the Government asked the Industries Assistance Commission to inquire into and report on whether assistance should be provided for the consumption and production of fertilisers in Australia and, if so, the nature, extent and the duration of such assistance. The Commission, in an interim report submitted to the Government in March 1985, recommended against continuation of the current subsidies for consumption of nitrogenous and phosphatic fertilisers after 30 June 1985 and recommended that short term assistance be provided to local phosphatic fertiliser manufacturers. The Government has rejected these recommendations.

In deciding to continue the fertiliser consumption subsidies for further 12 months, the Government was particularly mindful of its request that the IAC consider in its final report, firstly, the current levels of assistance to industries within the farm sector, relative to levels of assistance to other industries and the Government's commitment to maintain and improve the international competitiveness of Australian rural industries; and, secondly, the effectiveness of the nitrogenous and phosphatic fertiliser subsidies, or any other approaches which it considers would be appropriate, in assisting industries within the rural sector. The fertilisers subsidies are the single largest item of Commonwealth Government assistance to industries in the rural sector. In 1984-85 they are expected to cost the Commonwealth some $55.3m. Nevertheless, the overall level of assistance to rural industries is low by comparison with other sectors. A comparison of figures for 1981-82, the latest year for which comparable IAC figures are available, indicates that primary industry assistance is 9 per cent compared to 26 per cent for secondary industries.

In recent discussions on farm costs the Government has agreed with the National Farmers Federation that the farm sector does suffer a cost impost arising from protection of secondary industry by tariffs, quotas and other mechanisms, and while there has not been agreement on the extent of this cost impost it is in the order of $6,000 to $9,000 per farm each year. This is significant given that average income per unit of family farm labour in 1983-84 has been estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at only $7,000 per year.

The Government has been actively working on measures for industries in the rural sector which will maintain and enhance their productivity. Some changes have been necessary, an inevitable adjustment given the entrenched protective position into which some industries have withdrawn, but most important for their future efficiency and competitiveness. Our rural industries continue to provide about 40 per cent of export earnings, a most important contribution to the national economy and reason enough for the Government to maintain a reasonable balance between the assistance it provides to respective sectors of industry and the community generally.

There has been much debate on the effectiveness of the fertiliser consumption subsidies as an assistance measure for the rural sector and this is reflected in the Commission's interim report. Given the terms of reference the IAC has for this inquiry, the Government expects to be in a better position to consider the options including their continuation or their replacement by other measures following receipt of the final report which is due in October. The subsidy rates to continue in 1985-86 will be paid at the rate of $20 per tonne of contained nitrogen and $12 per tonne of single strength superphosphate or $138 per tonne on the available phosphorus content of other phosphatic fertilisers. The measure is expected to cost the Government about $55m in 1985-86. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
