SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege to speak on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1985 and the cognate Bill, having returned from the dreamtime of the heavy sittings of the Labor Government last week, proceedings on this legislation having been adjourned at 3 o'clock on Friday morning. No doubt by then most Aborigines would have been asleep around their campfires.
—What about the cockies?

—Most of the cockies were, too. This is most important legislation. I believe that it is sad for Australia to be handing a national park back to the Aborigines. I believe that there is more than sufficient land in that part of Australia to cope with any land claims that may have been put in. Under the 1976 Aboriginal Lands Rights (Northern Territory) Act it was not possible for these Aborigines to make claims, and that is why the legislation has to be altered. The 1976 land rights legislation has to be amended to allow the Aborigines to take this course. Under the previous Act Aborigines could not make claim to national parks, and nor should they be able to. No other Australian is given that privilege. I do not believe that because one is an Aboriginal one ought to be able to put in a claim for a national park wherever it may be, State or Commonwealth. It always amuses me how the greenies make such a hue and cry about the State Government of Tasmania wanting to build a dam in Tasmania. I have not seen the same sort of activity being carried on by any conservation groups in Australia against this national park being handed back to a group of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I also note with interest that the only other national park in the true sense, a Commonwealth national park, is in Canberra. I wait with interest the day when the Aborigines put in a claim for that national park. I imagine the people of Canberra will not be very keen to hand that back to the Aborigines. I believe that Namdadgi National Park on the Cotter River is the only national park in Australia that is controlled by the Commonwealth. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in his second reading speech said that the Kakadu National Park is of similar nature. But that is not the case because Kakadu was not in existence prior to the 1976 Land Rights Act. It has been built up since that time and handed back to the Aborigines. I am of the same opinion about that piece of land. I believe that as a national park, and as a national park which the Commonwealth Government has seen fit to place on the World Heritage List, it should be owned by all Australians, administered by the Government of the Northern Territory and not just owned by a few.

It is interesting to note that not only is Ayers Rock included in the park but so are the Olgas. Most of us, I imagine, have been to that part of the world. One travels many hundreds of miles across flat, featureless plains and comes upon the false rock-Mount Connor-first of all. Many people think it is Ayers Rock. Ayers Rock is a majestic, interesting place with lots of sandhills and beautiful oaks and the area is mystic to all of us, not just the Aborigines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party believes it is no longer part of Australia.

—It is true that the Labor Party has unfortunately handed it back to a group of people called the Mititjula group with whom the discussions took place. It is interesting to note that it has always been associated with the Docker River and other Aboriginal holdings. Once upon a time they were cattle stations. They are now run down and no production takes place on any of these cattle stations in that part of the world. In fact, the Federal Government is paying to have cattle slaughtered on a cattle station which is half way between Alice Springs and the Rock. A small meatworks has been set up there. Twenty or 30 head of cattle are slaughtered every couple of days and flown to the Aboriginal settlements.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the sorts of regressive moves we are making in relation to Aborigines. Only 10 or 15 years ago Docker River station ran 20,000 head of cattle. It now does not run a hoof. They have all been eaten or let starve. Obviously, the Aboriginal people who have been coming and going around the Rock claim that they are the owners. But in fact the area was named after Maggie Springs, a Yunkantjatjance name. These people come from near Ayers Rock. The Yunkantjatjance group is not the only group with a special interest in the Rock. Many groups of Aborigines are interested. The Government has negotiated with not just the Yunkantjatjance group. Most Australians are not in favour of the Rock being handed back to the Aborigines. Any poll one likes to take will show that 70 per cent of Australians do not want the Rock handed back. This has been one of the turning points which has fortunately created some sort of a backlash. Let us hope that some sanity will prevail from this socialist Labor Government's proposed national land rights legislation, which is a total farce. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is sitting at the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fresh from New York.

—Fresh from New York or fresh from Indian reserves. I do not know what they have to do with Australia. The Minister seems to have enjoyed travelling around that part of the world and coming back here and making all sorts of statements about mineral rights, et cetera. I was at Charleville on the weekend. My mate Sugar Ray Robinson is a resident of Charleville. He represents the great area of Maranoa on the National Aboriginal Conference. He gets a motor car to drive. Sugar came out with a great statement and I support him 100 per cent. I think it is the only sensible thing he has said: He said that Ayers Rock ought to be handed back to all Australians.
—Charming! A real charmer.

—I say to the honourable member for Melbourne that I support that. The honourable member is the very good former Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I have been able to well educate him in Aboriginal affairs since he has been Chairman of the Committee. The honourable member comes from the middle of Melbourne. We have had many good and interesting educational trips. We have been to these areas. I guess we do our best to try to help the Aboriginal people. The land rights movement and the backlash it has created are not helping the Aborigines at all. Sugar lives in my electorate of Maranoa and he has come out with this big statement. The Minister has just disbanded the National Aboriginal Conference, so poor old Sugar is clean out of a job. He does not have a motor car, a job or an office. He will have to give up his telex machine which he has in his office in Charleville.
—Do you have a telex?

—No, I do not have a telex. But Sugar has one and he has to give that up. So I am feeling a bit sorry for these people. But that is the way this Government has been treating Aborigines. It fills them with promises and then withdraws all the jobs, telex machines, motor cars-the lot. We have heard motor cars mentioned in this place before. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has come to the table. When I was in Charleville we had a big meeting with all the kangaroo shooters. Many Aboriginal people are employed in the roo industry. I must praise the Minister because he has agreed to meet with the shooters and, hopefully, with some people from the National Parks and Wildlife Service in Queensland. He will see whether we cannot sort out some of the problems with the quotas on kangaroos.
—Hear, hear! I hope he bashes some sense into some people.

—I say to the honourable member for Gwydir that 250 shooters turned up. Of course, I suppose they would have liked to lynch the Minister. But I stepped in and saved his neck. I agreed to talk to the Minister, which I have already done. He has agreed to meet one of these people who represents many Aboriginal people in that part of the world who exist by shooting kangaroos. As the Minister has said, unfortunately they developed roo shooting into an industry which earned them a living. Of course, if one takes away that living they bitterly complain about it. One cannot blame them for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to Ayers Rock. There are a lot of roos around Ayers Rock, too. Many Aborigines sit around there and try to make a go of things. The whole situation is pretty hopeless in one sense. We have supposedly handed back the Rock, set up a committee and agreed to pay rent. The people of Australia will pay $75,000 in rent. The Aborigines will get 20 per cent of the gate takings, so to speak. But the Government still has agreed to pay the expenses of the committee and I guess that includes the Aborigines. I often say that I believe we ought to leave these people alone. If we are going to hand back the Rock, which I am opposed to, I believe that the Aborigines ought to be left alone entirely to see whether they cannot manage their own affairs.

One can be dead sure that these people will not have their pensions and benefits assets tested. That is another thing I speak out very strongly against. I believe that all these handouts to Aborigines ought to be means tested. One can be dead sure that these people have been given the park and 20 per cent of the gate takings, but one can be sure that they will not be means tested and that they will continue to wait for payday every Friday when they get the dole cheque.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—That is true, and the honourable member for Melbourne knows that. He knows that that is how the system operates. Stations have been set up there. Every day aeroplanes fly meat to these people. The whole thing has degenerated into a hopeless state. The more money we give them the worse it gets. The Minister knows that. He has talked to the NAC representatives. He has had the Australian Federal Police into the NAC office to inquire into the goings on. Of course, we have not heard anything about that.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. A whole range of issues has been raised in the last couple of minutes. They have no relevance to the Bill whatsoever.

—I remind the honourable member for Melbourne that we are debating two Bills cognately. One of those is the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill and the other is the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to speak to the point of order. I believe that the honourable member was correct in that the honourable member for Maranoa has raised a number of issues which are totally irrelevant to these Bills. Whilst I am interested in his views on kangaroo shooting, they do not have a lot to do with Ayers Rock.

—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Maranoa has made the link between the national parks and wildlife conservation issue and has referred to Aborigines who rely on rural activities. I think he has made the connection. I call the honourable member for Maranoa.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As you know, there are many kangaroos around Ayers Rock. I have mentioned that fact. No doubt the Aborigines still depend on them for meat. Sometimes they go out and get the odd roo. They have a bit of a chew on the kangaroo. They are tough eating, but they are not bad. The honourable member for Melbourne has never eaten kangaroo. He would not know what they taste like. I still have to educate him. He has been a good Chairman. I am disappointed that he is taking points of order; he still needs educating. Do not worry; I will have done that by the time I have finished with him. We have also had the Premier of Queensland-the great Joh-and the Leader of the National Party in Queensland support Sugar. When Sugar made this great statement about Ayers Rock being given to all the people of Australia, the Premier of Queensland made this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: We are still seeking entirely separate rights and privileges for those available to other people in Australia. I am interested in equal rights, not land rights.

I think that is a perfectly good statement by the Premier of Queensland. We have a very good record with Aboriginal people in Queensland. No other State in Australia does more for the Aborigines than Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better ask them that.
—The Minister knows that. Wherever he has travelled--
—You have the same record with them as you have with kangaroos.

—I expect the Minister to give us an increase in that kangaroo quota. When he comes to Queensland I will take him to Charleville. He will meet all these Aboriginal shooters and he will give them an increase in the quota because there is a heap of roos in Queensland. The last couple of winters we have had have been excellent seasons and the roos have really multiplied in number.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I conclude I would like to refer to the preferred national land rights model. It is about the tenth model the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has put out. No doubt the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) had a hand in writing this. He is still endeavouring to get some sort of national land rights model. I believe that he should forget it.

While I am on my feet I point out that the other day I very strongly made the point to members of the Department that I expect them to make sure that any pastoral leases which expire are renewed and that claims are not allowed to be made in respect of them. Another thing to which I am opposed is pastoral excursions. In the Northern Territory, around Ayers Rock and in other places Aborigines are being allowed, under the new national land rights Act, to make claims for excursions into pastoral holdings. I believe that all that will do is decentralise the stations, making it harder for management to operate the stations, and make it much more expensive for us in government to do something for the Aboriginal people. That is all I have to say on these two Bills. I support the Opposition's proposed amendments and reserve my right to speak at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard from honourable members opposite a great deal of heat but not a great deal of enlightenment in this debate so far. I concur with the comments of the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) when he said that the speech that we just heard was full of irrelevancies. I think, as well, that it was insulting to the Aboriginal community at large. In addition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) tried in his speech to inflame the House with some fiery rhetoric, included in which was a statement that a ban had been placed on photography at Ayers Rock. If the honourable member were more aware of his shadow portfolio he would know that regulations under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act require a permit to be issued before commercial filming is carried out. Applications for permits are assessed against a set of guidelines agreed between the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the traditional owners, Northern Territory Government agencies and other interested bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that problems arise when film crews are insensitive in their actions or fail to adhere to conditions of approval for their activities. One must say, in regard to that, that the greater percentage, the majority, of applications for commercial filming have proceeded smoothly, although there have been one or two unfortunate incidents when those filming have not paid regard to the sensitivities of the Aboriginals in the area.

There has been an Aboriginal presence in the area for thousands of years. It was in 1920 that the Petermann Aboriginal reserve was established for the protection of Aboriginals inhabiting the area in the vicinity of Ayers Rock. In 1958 the land now forming the Uluru National Park was excised from the Petermann reserve. I remind the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who made references to that aspect, that that event is historically important. Had that land not been excised from the reserve, it would have been included in Schedule 1 of the Act, as was the case with other reserves, and consequently granted with the remainder of the land in that reserve in 1978.

There can be no doubt as to the significance of that area not only to those persons directly descended from the original inhabitants but to Aboriginal people generally, and to the wider Australian population, as well as to visitors from overseas. Mr Justice Toohey, the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, in his report on the Uluru National Park commented:

Both Uluru and Katatjuta are of enormous significance not only for the local descent groups immediately responsible for them but for the claimants generally and for a wider range of Aboriginal people.
He went on to say:
. . . so many witnesses spoke about the significance of both places. The attachment of all Aboriginal witnesses was obvious.

He meant the attachment they had to the land. It is clear that those people living in that area have strong traditional ties. They live according to traditional standards of government based on consensus and group consultation.

There are 23 sites of significance to Aboriginal people at Uluru and eight at Katatjuta. The importance of these sites and of the area generally is reflected in the perseverance with which the Aboriginal people have pursued the land claim over the past few years. It is because this Government recognises the just and legitimate claims of the dispossessed people of Uluru and Katatjuta that it is proposing this amendment to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. At the same time, this Bill recognises the importance of these areas to the Australian people as a whole and, despite the bogus fears of some honourable members opposite, allows for continued access to the area by all Australians. The Aboriginal people themselves acknowledge the importance of the area to Australians generally and have agreed to maintain the area as a national park on the proposed basis of a 99-year lease to be administered by an 11-member board of management. This board will comprise six Aboriginal representatives nominated by the local community, two members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a nominee from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, a nominee from the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism and the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In addition, it is proposed that an annual rental of $75,000 plus 20 per cent of the entrance fees be paid.

The recognition of traditional Aboriginal ownership in the management of park areas is not a new concept-not even for the Northern Territory. Despite the misleading information given by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), there are two examples in the Northern Territory where title has been transferred to the traditional owners. The Kakadu National Park is one; the Cobourg Peninsula is another. The traditional owners of Kakadu have in turn leased the park back to the Government for the purposes of maintaining and operating the national park. This has proved to be a most successful partnership. It gives the lie to those who said that it would not work. There is no reason why the current proposal should be any less successful.

I draw the attention of the House to another example which was enacted in legislation by the Northern Territory Government in 1981. The Cobourg Peninsula area is held under freehold title by the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land on the basis that it be used as a national park. Given that both of these examples-Kakadu and the Cobourg Peninsula-were introduced by the Opposition when in government and the Northern Territory Government, under the man who is now the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) respectively-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why have they changed their minds?

—We do not know. I think the only answer is 'political opportunism'. That is the only rationale for their action. It would seem reasonable to assume that the Opposition should support the current amendment. Further evidence to support this assumption can be gleaned from a speech in July 1982 to the National Press Club by the honourable member for the Northern Territory when he was Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. At that time his intentions in respect of Uluru National Park were crystal clear. They are less than crystal clear today. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Territory Government will give title to Uluru National Park, including Ayers Rock and Mount Olga, and make an arrangement whereby it will continue as a National Park.

What is his attitude now? I will wait with interest to hear his speech on this Bill. Finally, the granting of title to the Uluru-Kakatjuta Aboriginal Land Trust is consistent with this Government's preferred model on land rights. This proposal is a serious attempt by the Government to redress the injustices suffered by the people of Uluru-Katatjuta while preserving access for all Australians and for those overseas visitors who wish to see this unique and remarkably beautiful area of Australia. I support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us legislation which will set the seal on the fate of this Government. Throughout Australia people are watching the passage of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and they are angry, justifiably angry, that this Government is about to give away the best known and best loved symbol of our Australian heritage in a tradeoff to its left wing. Ayers Rock does not belong to this Government. It is not the Government's to give away. Ayers Rock belongs to all the people of Australia. It cannot be bartered in the political market-place of factional trade off. Australians will resist that, whether this legislation passes or not. Do not be deflected by the red herring of Cobourg Peninsula National Park. If the Northern Territory Government had not come to an agreement with the Aboriginals at Cobourg we would have lost it altogether. All Northern Territory national parks are under claim. The Northern Territory has always opposed that situation. In the case of the Katherine Gorge National Park, it has opposed the land claim. In the case of Cobourg, we were advised that there was no chance of success and, therefore, negotiations took place to perpetuate the state of national park.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) says that 'Ayers Rock is of great cultural significance to the Aboriginal people'. Of course it is, but it is also of great cultural significance to all Australians. White Australians are not culturally deprived. Ayers Rock is their heritage. It is Australia, just as are the Blue Mountains, the Great Barrier Reef and Sydney Harbour. All Australia is of great cultural significance to Aboriginals, as it is to all Australians. Shall we give it away? We had better not. It is our land. We cannot turn the clock back. We are all Australians together. The Minister says that while Ayers Rock is of great cultural significance to Aboriginals it has also become 'a magnetic attraction for tourists from within Australia and overseas'. Here we see how this Government thinks. Under the philosophy of this legislation non-Aboriginal Australians are viewed by the Government only as tourists. The Australian people will answer that. They will answer it with the anger of a people whose trust has been betrayed. I want to quote from just one of hundreds of letters that have been printed in the nation's media since the decision to hand over Ayers Rock to the Mutitjulu community was announced. A letter published in the Australian of 27 March 1985 stated:

I never realised that Ayers Rock meant so much to me until confronted with the news that absolute title to this natural wonder is shortly to be given to a small community of Aboriginal Australians. I felt that sudden sense of shock, then grief, that comes when you are about to lose something very precious, previously taken for granted, the true value of which does not become apparent until after it has gone forever . . . The stroke of the pen that will allow people to physically possess the spiritual heart of this nation is a knife thrust that wounds every Australian.

I am sure that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) have hundreds, if not thousands, of similar letters on their files. If the Ministers have bothered to read them they must know what an irony the ministerial title, Arts, Heritage and the Environment, is today. The Minister has, in introducing the Bill, abrogated his responsibility to represent the interests of Australian art, Australian heritage and the Australian environment. He should be ashamed of himself for carrying out the bidding of the breast-beating Left of his Party. I know what the Minister will say. He will seek to defend his action by siting my decision to accept that recognition of Aboriginal title to Uluru would have to form part of a negotiating package between the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory Government and land councils on changes to the Northern Territory land rights legislation. I reluctantly made that commitment because it seemed that it was the only way to attempt to salvage the interests of territorians, squeezed between the demands of the land councils, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Services and the Commonwealth.

The Northern Territory position has long been that Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park should be vest in the Northern Territory Conservation Commission, but our top priority was to secure amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, and it still is. On 28 July 1982 I put forward a 10-point package to attempt to resolve the problem that afflicted the territory. I seek leave to table a speech made by me which was referred to by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard).
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the legislation there was to be a tradeoff by both sides, but the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, almost immediately on assuming office, forgot about reconciliation and consensus and threw the 10-point package out the window. In November 1983 this Government, without any prior consultation with the Northern Territory, announced its sell-out of Ayres Rock. I have always believed that Ayres Rock belongs to all the people of Australia, and I know that the people of Australia believe that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal briefly with some of the details of this issue, but honourable members opposite should not be too distracted by these details. The only real matter for them to keep uppermost in their minds is that if they support the give away of Ayers Rock they vote against the wishes and interests of the people of Australia. They should keep that in mind and remember it when they are soundly defeated at the next election and are wondering how it happened. The Minister has said that the House 'is in the fortunate position of having a former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory here to speak on this issue'. It is most fortunate that I am here to put the record straight, otherwise honourable members might be misled by the subtle and devious strategems adopted by the Minister in his second reading speech.

The Minister has sought to identify himself with the Yulara tourist facilities that have given Ayers Rock its rightful place at the very centre of Australian tourism growth. After stating how he first became actively involved in the area in the late 1960s, he continued by reading a selective history of events concerning Uluru. To listen to the Minister, one could be forgiven for thinking that it was because he became actively involved that the $150m Yulara development now stands near Uluru. The facts are that during umpteen years of Commonwealth control of Uluru, there were hundreds of pages of totally predictable reports on the need to protect Uluru environmentally and to promote tourism to the area.

That was the result on paper. On the ground things were somewhat different. A motely group of prefabricated buildings sprang up at the ecologically least desirable base of the rock, providing inadequate tourist accommodation and an environmental eyesore on the landscape. That was what the Northern Territory inherited from the Commonwealth at self-government-pages and pages of reports and a township of shanty hotels to which the Aboriginals were attracted. Again I refer to the letter I tabled in this House earlier this year from Mr William H. Liddle dated 14 September 1947. That is hard evidence that no Aboriginal lived at Ayers Rock. I should add that I attach no blame to the pioneer operators of those hotel facilities. They struggled to provide some facilities in the face of a lack of any power, water, sewerage and road infrastructure, no secure title, and neglect and inaction from the powers that be. The Northern Territory made environmental protection of Uluru and international class tourism facilities a top priority of the early self-governing years. We put together the necessary financial package. We involved a world-wide hotel chain. We provided what the Commonwealth had been unable to provide in years of committee meetings and reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —With Commonwealth money.
—Baloney. Not a cent; not a cracker.
—It was part of the settlement that you were set up with.
—Not a cent. The money is borrowed.
—Why don't you tell the truth for once in your life?

—Why does the Minister not find out some facts? The Minister's attempt to shift credit for this enterprise to his Government is an insult to the intelligence of the people of Australia. This history of neglect and inaction from the Commonwealth authority continues. For years now the Northern Territory has been trying to wrest control of Uluru and Kakadu national parks from the dead hand of the ANPWS empire. Even in the Australian Capital Territory the Government will not let the ANPWS control its national park; only in the Northern Territory is that wasteful and unnecessary empire let off the leash. If the Government wants to save money let it wind up the ANPWS because, as honourable members may have noticed, the Service cannot even eradicate the feral cats in the parking lot at the back of this Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give the very briefest resume of ANPWS inactivities in administering the plan of management for Uluru National Park, which this House approved to come into effect on 22 September 1983. The plan says that the Director:
. . . shall perform his functions and exercise his powers . . . in accordance with the plan and not otherwise.

This is a requirement of the Commonwealth's Act. Yet, the Minister, by his refusal to delegate authority, by his failure to act, has frustrated and hindered the expressed wish of this Parliament. The Minister is responsible for the inaction of his officers. I ask him to explain to this House why, when we are nearly half way through the life of the plan, the most important single first step the establishment of the Uluru aboriginal advisory committee-has not taken place. In more than 20 months since the plan took effect, the most basic arrangements have not been put in place. I will save the Minister the trouble of responding. It is simply because Canberra head office will not stomach any divesting of power from its own immediate control. An Aboriginal advisory committee might have short-circuited this. These decisions are not small ones. They include such matters as plans for the preservation of sites of significance, plans for the control of dogs, plans for the control of fires and soil erosion-all paramount matters concerning the environment protection of Uluru.

The Minister has given this House no assurance on such matters, although he has announced a new plan of management for the park to come into effect 'when the present plan expires in 1987, or beforehand, if the new plan is ready'. Will the Minister explain what action he proposes to ensure that the existing plan of management will be carried out as this House has directed? When will the existing plan of management be carried out? Members of the media and members of the public are well aware that to date several international and national media organisations have been forbidden to film and photograph Ayers Rock since this Government announced the great give-away. I have detailed these events before. The Herald newspaper and a British Broadcasting Corporation film crew, amongst others, have been told that they may not photograph Australia's Ayers Rock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paul Hogan.

—The shadow Minister has reminded me about Paul Hogan who sat out there while the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) rang me to see what I could do to get permission for him to film at Ayers Rock. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has given no assurance other than to say:

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing to suggest that the scheme proposed will not operate to the advantage of Aboriginals and all Australians alike.

He said that there will be no selective and irrational bans placed on the rock in the future. I understand, and it is significant that I must gain this information from sources in the Northern Territory rather than from the Minister, that negotiations for the give-away include a requirement from the Aboriginal owners that they will not deny access. If this is true the Minister is easily fooled because such assurances have been given before. We have seen the extent to which they have been followed. Indeed, one need not wonder why. I quote from Mr Justice Woodward's second report:
One of the most important proofs of genuine Aboriginal ownership of land will be the right to exclude from it those who are not welcome.

What will this assurance be worth when the crunch comes? One of the Aborigines' advisers is already on record as having said that the park may have to be closed for upwards of a day at a time. What sort of havoc will that play with our international tourist industry?

Time is running out and there is much more I would like to say. However, there is one issue only on which this House needs to focus its collective mind. Ayers Rock is indeed a great tourist attraction. However, to all Australians-I emphasise all Australians-it is more than that. It is an awesome geological feature-the largest monolith in the world. But to the Australian people it is more than that. It is a symbol of strength. But to Australians it is more than that. It has been an inspiration to Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal artists; it is an inspiration to all Australians. But it is more than that. It is at the heart of our great country, a cultural and spiritual symbol to all who call themselves Australians. If this legislation is passed the Hawke Government will be remembered for this act-the hand-over of Australia's best-known, best-loved, cultural and spiritual symbol to a small group in the community. This Government will be remembered for it. It will be cursed for it. At the next election it will be damned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that on an issue as important as the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) should follow other speakers in using terms such as 'give away Ayers Rock', and talk about its spiritual significance to all Australians. Of course, it is of significance to all Australians. What is the Government doing in terms of this legislation? It is bringing to finality a series of discussions and negotiations that have been going on for almost a decade and which were begun during that period of the Fraser Government. The Bill in essence does one thing, and one thing only; it recognises the pre-existing ownership and the spiritual significance of Ayers Rock to our Aboriginal citizens.
—Which ones?

—Of course, we have heard from my colleague the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), who has said that there may be some doubt as to whether one can recognise the traditional Aboriginal owners. What is the authority for that proposition?

SPEECH.PARA: The authority is one Aboriginal person by the name of Mr Liddle. The shadow Minister and other honourable members opposite of course have not bothered to look at the investigations carried out by Mr Justice Toohey when he was investigating the relationship of Aboriginal people to Ayers Rock. He not only emphasised its spiritual significance, he recognised a very large number of traditional owners. He recognised 104 traditional owners and another group of 57.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not giving it to them.

—The honourable gentleman has said that I am not giving it to them. I ask the honourable gentleman who his sole authority is. Did Mr Liddle give evidence to Mr Justice Toohey? Of course, he did not. Mr Liddle just happens to be the so-called authority who advises the honourable gentleman opposite. It is no accident that he just happens to be the Chairman of the Liberal-National Party in Alice Springs. He is a token Aboriginal.
—That's disgraceful.

—I have had a gutful of the honourable member and Mr Liddle. Let us be clear about it: On the basis of being promised political preferment, Mr Liddle will say anything to demean Aboriginal people and their claims. Let me quote the authority that the honourable member relies on. Mr Liddle is reported as having said of himself when giving advice to his daughter:

SPEECH.PARA: I used to be nice and never got anywhere; now I'm a ruthless bastard and making heaps of money.

That is the authority that is brought into this House on the basis of contesting the legitimate claims and hopes of Aboriginal people. The honourable member will have to do better than that. The honourable member should look at the judgment of Mr Justice Toohey which clearly recognises the traditional relationship, the traditional owners and their rights in respect of this.

Of course, we heard the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who for some years was the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. For most of the period when the Fraser Government was in office considerable negotiations went on, during almost the entire history of that Government, to determine the relationship between Aboriginal people, the Northern Territory Government and the Federal Government. To hear honourable gentlemen opposite one would think that somehow or other the decision made by the Government and contained in this legislation was dragged out of the hat, that it was a decision taken in a political vacuum without any regard to the negotiations and discussions that have preceded it. It is all very well for the honourable member for the Northern Territory to say that we must not quote him out of context, that we must not misunderstand what he was about. On 13 February 1980, in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, what was the position of the then Chief Minister, the present honourable member for the Northern Territory? He said:
The Northern Territory Government has been attempting to negotiate with the Aboriginal people through the Central Land Council in respect of the Uluru National Park exactly the same arrangements--
honourable members should listen to this-
for the last 12 months as we are now negotiating with the Northern Land Council with respect to the Cobourg Peninsula.

If we were to believe the honourable member for the Northern Territory now, on what basis would he be negotiating with the Central Land Council? On 13 February 1980, did this honourable gentleman believe, as he said in the House today, that the Rock is of such special significance to all Australians that there is no basis upon which one could possibly recognise any claim from Aboriginal people? If that is the case now, how is it that on 13 February 1980, as Chief Minister, the honourable member engaged in detailed negotiations? To do what? Virtually to recognise the title of the Aboriginal people and create a board of management upon which they would have a majority. That is exactly the situation that was created by the Government of the honourable member for the Northern Territory in respect of the Cobourg Peninsula. It is no good his coming in here and saying: 'We had no choice in respect of Cobourg'. What was his choice in respect of Uluru at that time? It is no good his coming in here and talking about conceding the position to the breast-beating Left. Is that an adequate description of the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser?

There were endless discussion in respect of this matter by the former Prime Minister. At that stage, as honourable members opposite know, the argument that was being advanced by the Northern Territory Government was not an argument against giving Aboriginal people title; it was an argument about the Northern Territory Government wanting to give them Northern Territory title. That is what it was about and the record shows that that was the position which was arrived at on 16 April 1982. There was a whole series of discussions. No fewer than three former Federal Liberal Ministers-Mr Viner, Senator Peter Baume and Mr Wilson-were involved at various stages in detailed negotiations. Honourable members should ask themselves the very simple question: Why would they need to negotiate? Why should they be involved if the argument were as simple as the argument we have had put here today, namely, that under no circumstances would the Northern Territory recognise the very special relationship that exists between the Aboriginal people and this monument of great significance to them? One cannot describe the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, as a breast-beating leftie.

Let me come back to the argument. What was the argument about? The argument being advanced-the honourable member for the Northern Territory knows it-was that the Northern Territory Government was prepared to recognise the relationship of Aboriginal people to the Rock. Of course it was because at that stage the evidence was overwhelming and even the Northern Territory Government recognised it. Secondly, it was prepared to give title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't they?

—That is a very interesting question. The reason the Northern Territory Government did not give title to the Aborigines was, I suspect, that Prime Minister Fraser did not trust it any more than we do. It appears from the record Mr Fraser, a member of the former Liberal-National Party Federal Government, advised that the Commonwealth would not abrogate its responsibility for the park until a satisfactory conclusion was reached with regard to negotiations between the Northern Territory Government and the Central Land Council. Honourable members should think on that. A conservative Prime Minister said: 'We will not abrogate the Commonwealth's responsibility in respect of this park until we are satisfied about the arrangements that are reached between the Northern Territory Government and the Aboriginal people'. He went further than that. He went on to suggest that there be an agreement similar to the Cobourg arrangement which would help to satisfy the Commonwealth's requirements concerning the protection of Aboriginal interests. What is the Cobourg arrangement? The Cobourg arrangement involves Aboriginal people in the management and control of the park and a recognition of their title. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.PARA: The records are available. That is the record. The Labor Government came to office with that background of negotiation, with that background of discussion, and with a recommendation of a very distinguished judge recognising the cultural and spiritual relationship between the Aboriginal people and Uluru. There was no question about that at that stage; Mr Liddle was not anywhere on the scene. We decided to follow the course of those negotiations and take them to their logical conclusion, and that logical conclusion is in this legislation today. How is it that all of a sudden the Liberal Party and the National Party, which once had a commitment to land rights, which once recognised the long-standing tradition of Aboriginal people, suddenly start talking with shock and horror about the enormity of what we are doing? What are we doing? What we are doing is very simple. We are recognising that long-standing ownership, that long-standing cultural relationship. We are entering into an agreement which is not dissimilar to the agreement which was reached in respect of Kakadu, where the title of the traditional owners was recognised and land was leased back to the Commonwealth so that the land could be conducted as a national park. It is as simple as that.

As to the lease arrangements, it is palpable nonsense to suggest that the average Australian will feel a sense of deprivation or a sense of loss. The average Australian who visits Kakadu does not feel any sense of deprivation or loss. The average Australian who visits Cobourg-if he can get in-does not feel any sense of deprivation or loss. The average Australian who visits Uluru will feel no sense of deprivation or loss. What he will feel is that there is a Government that has been prepared to bring these long-standing negotiations to a head and recognise the rights of our indigenous people.

To hear honourable gentlemen from the backwoods carry on one would think that the Australian Government was the only government on record which could do such a thing. I was in America recently. Shock, horror! The Grand Canyon, one of the great tourist attractions of the United Sates of America, is on Indian land. Does the average American citizen or the average overseas tourist who visits it feel any sense of deprivation or loss? Of course not. I shall finish on one point. No examination of the record here indicates that we have not followed the course, and brought to a logical conclusion the negotiations that had been going on under the previous Fraser Government for almost seven years. I say with regret that the response of the Opposition, rather than being a responsible one, is that they have had about half a dozen positions in half a dozen weeks. When I had announced the conclusion of the negotiations and stated that the terms of the lease were agreed, the Opposition shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Higgins, on 14 March, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, not only condemned this arrangement but went on to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I condemned it.

—Yes, but what did the shadow Minister go on to say? He said that sacred sites should continue to be protected-there is no argument with that-but that the monolith itself should remain with the Commonwealth on behalf of the Australian people.
—That's right. I said that we are now giving it to the Territory.

—I see. How is it that when the shadow Minister first considered the matter-and we are looking at March, only a short period of time ago-there was absolutely no doubt in his mind that sacred sites would be protected, but the Rock must remain with the Commonwealth. What happened, of course, is that 'casino' Everingham, the member for the Northern Territory, who is absolutely expert at giving other people's properties away, went into the Party room and said-
—Oh, get it right.

—Honourable members opposite know that they have changed their position on this, not for any reason of principle and not for any reason of logic, but to meet what honourable members opposite perceive as the current political climate under which they might pick up a vote or two.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the matter was raised in debate, I finish on the point: The Government was taken to task in this whole area for not endeavouring to produce a bipartisan policy. I think in this area there ought to be a bipartisan policy. When I became Minister, one of the first things I did was to introduce a motion into this House to establish the basis for the creation of such a policy. The reason that there was a bipartisan policy on the question of land rights before was because there was a Liberal Government which had a commitment to land rights and an Opposition that had an equal commitment-probably a far stronger commitment. How is it that we could have a bipartisan policy under a Fraser Government but it is more difficult under a Hawke Government? The reason is very simple. I went to the former shadow Minister and said 'That is our statement. We do not regard it as being the final statement, but if the Opposition has any reasonable amendments, we will be very happy to look at them'. The reason that motion was never proceeded with was that the range of amendments proposed would have meant that there would be no consensus, that there would only be another ranging debate. There was no point putting forward a motion which was supposed to provide the basis for consensus if in fact the reality of the situation was that we were going to engage in a hard debate emphasising the differences. Basically, the issue would be determined by a ringing of the bells and a counting of the numbers. That was no basis for consensus. Therefore, we did not proceed with the resolution. How can there be consensus?

I am entitled to ask the shadow Minister whether the Opposition supports the principle of land rights? The reason there is no bipartisan policy is very simple. The conservative parties in this House which once held this commitment no longer-

TALK.START.PARA: —Equal rights.
—I hear what the honourable gentleman says and of course what he is making perfectly clear is the shift in his position.
—No, I have always believed that. You know that I have always believed that.

—The honourable member was not so vocal when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister. I say to the honourable gentleman that we cannot establish a bipartisan policy on an issue like land rights if the Government is committed to land rights and the Opposition is fundamentally opposed to granting them. We cannot create a basis for bipartisanship on these issues when the Leader of the Opposition refers to the racist policies that have been promoted by an organisation like the Australian League of Rights. It is well that he does not necessarily agree with all of it, but it is running in parallel with the Opposition. I simply make the point that it is absolute humbug and hypocrisy for members of the Opposition to come in here and say how important it is to try to get a bipartisan policy when they, by their own actions, have moved away from any concept of bipartisanship when they moved to a situation-
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, I am amazed by the tenor of this debate because what has happened is that the Opposition, by its campaign, has raised all the fears of racism amongst the community at large in a manner that I believe would horrify most people in this House. What we have seen, frankly, is a load of old cobblers. What is it exactly we are doing that is so terrible? We are in fact acknowledging the ownership of Ayers Rock by the Aboriginal people. We are acknowledging their long history of association with that part of Australia and their emotional and spiritual commitment to it. In acknowledging that long relationship with that area, we are prepared to come to an arrangement with them that that is their land and they are re-leasing it back to us for the management of that area as a major national park.

SPEECH.PARA: Listening to members of the Opposition one would think that what we are doing is something strange and new. My colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has already gone over the example of Cobourg National Park, negotiated by the former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who is now the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). However, in view of the hysteria I would like to give the example of Kakadu National Park. As a result of the recommendations of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry the Liberal-Country Party Government of the time amended the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to enable Aboriginal Land--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us that $130m, Barry.
—I beg your pardon?
—Back in 1983, $130m-don't you remember it.

—Why does not the honourable member listen to what I have to say instead of shouting out in the middle of the debate. I will take as long as the honourable member likes. As I said, in 1978 the previous Government amended the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to enable Aboriginal land in the Alligator Rivers region to become part of a national park. We arranged that the granting of land rights in the area was subject to the lease of the land to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for national parks purposes. We decided that the Director could take Aboriginal land in the region on lease for a period not exceeding 100 years. We agreed to pay an annual rental of about $7,500 to the Northern Land Council for the Aboriginal land in the park. Who was that done by? It was done by the Fraser Government and the honourable member for the Northern Territory was the man who leased, under a similar arrangement, Cobourg National Park from the Aboriginal people. This is the third time an arrangement of this nature has been entered into by a government to establish a national park and to lease the land from the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for the Northern Territory made great play about the history of the Ayers Rock development and the fact that I said in my second reading speech that I had been involved and interested in this project back in the late 1960s when I first became a member of the Parliament. I followed with interest the work that had been done by the Harris Kerr Foster report in 1965 on the travel and tourist industry in Australia and later by the Pannell Kerr Foster inquiry. As the unofficial spokesman on tourism at the time I developed the policy of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still are.

—There was no shadow spokesman at the time and I later became the shadow Minister from 1978 to 1980. I was one of the few people at that time who were interested in tourism in this Parliament. There was very little interest in the Federal Parliament in the question of tourism. I pushed and prodded when we were in government to get that development going. The whole project was started. However, when the Fraser Government came to office in 1975 through the coup it abandoned the project. Later on it resurrected it. An amount of money was set aside for the development of the Ayers Rock project as a result of the settlement between the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government. So the honourable member for the Northern Territory should not say that the Northern Territory provided the money. In fact, 89c in every dollar the Northern Territory got came from the Commonwealth Government. The honourable member should not talk about what the Northern Territory did. We are talking about Commonwealth funds. The honourable member for the Northern Territory said that the development at Ayers Rock had been shabby, and I could not agree with him more. How did that happen and under whom did it happen? Do not let us forget that since 1948, for all but five years, conservative governments have occupied the Treasury bench. So if there was no development, lack of development or bad development at Ayers Rock, whose fault was it? It was certainly not the fault of the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also asked why we had not set up the advisory board. We cannot do most of these things until this Bill is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—Well, I am sorry, but it is so. The advisory committee, which is mentioned in the current plan of management, was not set up. It has been superseded by the introduction of this Bill, which seeks to give the Aboriginal traditional owners greater involvement in the management of the area. The advisory committee can be set up as soon as the Bill is passed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), who is a previous Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, asked why Ayers Rock has remained under Commonwealth control. The simple fact is that the Fraser Government would not trust the Northern Territory Government with either Uluru National Park or Kakadu National Park. We know full well what would have happened to those parks. All sorts of fears are being raised in the minds of the Australian people that, somehow or other, after this legislation is passed something terrible is going to happen to Ayers Rock. What do people think we are going to do with it? Take it and flog it off to overseas interests, like coalition governments do with everything else in this country? Ayers Rock will stay as it is now and as it has for the last million years. It will be there for the next million years. The Australian people will have full access to the rock, as they do now. The idea that somehow or other, because the rock is now nominally owned by the Aboriginal people and leased back to us, the average Australian is not going to have access to the rock is nonsense, and honourable members opposite know it. Just as people now have access to Kakadu National Park, they will have access to Uluru National Park.

The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, complained about the excessive rental. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) talked about the large amount of money the Aborigines were going to get. I point out that $100,000 is going to be shared amongst all Aborigines who now inhabit the rock area.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are there?

—I understand that there are 300 to 400. These people are hardly going to be taking international trips on the money they are going to get out of this. The total is $75,000 plus a per- centage of the rental-roughly $100,000-and indexed for future increases. We do not hear the honourable member for Maranoa talking about means testing for some of his country colleagues when they get too much money. He believes that it is bad to give money to Aborigines but not to cockies. It is very simple-one rule for the cockies and one for the Aborigines. Give nothing to Aborigines because it spoils them. Is that what the honourable member was saying?
—Never.

—That is what I and everybody else here heard. Let us talk about the question of photography. If ever there was a furphy, it is this one about photography-that people now will not be able to take pictures of the rock. To repeat what I said earlier, that is a load of old cobblers. The simple fact is that any tourist can take any photograph he likes. He never has had to, and never will have to, get permission. However, what is essential-this applies not only to Ayers Rock but to every other national park in Australia that is run by a State or the Commonwealth-is that permission has to be obtained from the State or Commonwealth national parks and wildlife service to film a commercial operation.
—Is Mr Toyne on that?
—If the honourable member must make an interjection, would he make it an intelligent one?
—Order! With a great deal of respect, the Minister did in fact invite an interjection. I point out to him that the honourable member for O'Connor needs no such invitation.

—That is true. Mr Deputy Speaker, that is one of the greatest pieces of wisdom to come from that chair since I have been here. Let us talk about the photography. There is a great deal of what one might call amnesia on the other side of the House. When in opposition, honourable members opposite forget what they did when in government, and we have a whole set of new rules. The whole question of the leases in respect of Uluru, Kakadu and Cobourg did not happen apparently. In fact, the guidelines for photography in Uluru National Park were set up during the period of the previous Government by my predecessor the honourable member for Darling Downs. If one wanted to carry out a commercial operation one had to go through a process of applying to a national parks and wildlife service. In the case of Ayers Rock, one has to go through the consultative process with the Aborigines of the Mittjulu Association and so on, and permission is then granted. Exactly the same procedures have been followed since we came to office. Unfortunately there have been some irresponsible people among the media, some of whom I suspect wanted to create an incident because that would give them a nice run.
—Oh, Barry!

—With all due respect, I am not going to name them. However, the honourable member knows the position as well as I do. In fact, his successor, Mr Hatton, made it very clear to me at a meeting we had a few months back that he believed that a couple of the incidents that occurred at the rock were set up for the purpose of creating a television incident. I mention a couple of examples such as Val Doonican, Simon Townsend, the Willesee Show and the Italian people. All the problems could have been overcome by simply sticking to the procedures. To avoid that happening again we now have for the first time two Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service officers on the ground at Uluru. We did not have this arrangement before because the park itself, although owned by the Commonwealth, is run by the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Service. From now on there will be two Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service officers at Uluru to ensure that that sort of confusion does not happen or, if it does, we will be able to sort it out much quicker. I repeat that the guidelines are the same as have applied over the last 10 years and were set up by our predecessors.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we proceed to the Committee stage of the Bill, I would like to say that, if ever there was a case of a beat-up in this Parliament to raise fears in the minds of the Australian people that somehow or other they are being denied access to what I agree is one of our great environmental and cultural assets, this debate is it. There is no reason in the world why we cannot both provide full access to Australians and international visitors and at the same time acknowledge the Aboriginal people's long, historic, spiritual and emotional ties with Ayers Rock.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Shipton's amendment) stand part of the question.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
