PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this general Committee stage, we are taking as a whole the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill which transfers Ayers Rock, Uluru, to a particular group of Australians, the Mititjula community. I repeat, as I said in the second reading debate, that the Opposition opposes this legislation on the basis that Ayers Rock is part of the heritage of all Australians. It is a national monument and a symbol for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians alike. We oppose the Government's course of being selective and of handing the rock to one particular community when the traditional ownership is in doubt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has said that this is part of the total land rights debate-he said that when talking to a group of Aboriginals who were occupying his Department's offices at Woden last week. I repeat that he has unreasonably raised the expectations of the Aboriginal community by making promises that he is unable to deliver in relation to land rights. By so doing he has destroyed any hope of a bipartisan debate on this matter by promising something to Aboriginal communities that he cannot deliver. This legislation is very much the second prize and he is pinning his great hopes on this legislation because he knows he cannot deliver on the other things he has promised.

I have also pointed out that this is a very sensitive time as this is a fragile issue in the community. By unreasonably raising the expectations of the Aboriginal community, the Minister has exacerbated the debate and has created a backlash in the Australian community. This makes it much more difficult for those who are trying to achieve real gains in the advancement of Aboriginal people.

I would like to ask the Minister about proposed new section 4 relating to grants of land to land trusts which refers to 'an agreement' with the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The Minister has not brought such an agreement before the House, he has not tabled it or annexed it to the legislation. Apparently that agreement will provide the terms and conditions of the lease of Ayers Rock-Mount Olga National Park. We need to know clearly the terms and conditions of that agreement or lease. Apparently there are to be renewal conditions every five years. We want to know whether the rent can be increased every five years and what are the terms and conditions of that rent. It is irresponsible of the Minister not to have brought such an agreement containing the lease before the House. He is giving land away to a particular group under an agreement or lease which has not been tabled in this Parliament and which is not known to the people of Australia.

The Minister rejected my appeal for an anthropological study and quoted Mr Liddle to whom I referred in my speech. I think that was most unfair. It was cowardly of the Minister to refer to Mr Liddle as a token Aboriginal. When an Aboriginal does not agree with him, he then describes such a person as token. That is a dangerous state of affairs in this country when a Minister describes somebody as token just because he does not agree with that person.

The Minister was very selective in his quotations. I quoted Strehlow, the well-known anthropologist, now deceased. I quoted an article he wrote in 1969 for the Inland Review supporting the view that landscape-and this is my argument-is more important to non-Aboriginal people than it is to Aborigines. The Minister chose to ignore my quotation of Strehlow and my argument based upon it. The Minister also failed to take into account what I said about the well-known Aboriginal National Aboriginal Conference member, Mr Ray Robinson, who called for Ayers Rock to be handed to all Australians. The Minister selectively attacked Mr Liddle which I think is unforgivable.

The Minister , in his second reading speech, referred to the Toohey report, 'Seven Years On', and said that Opposition members were not aware of it. I am of course aware that Toohey looked into the matter and said that there were a number of claimants, such as the Jankuntjatjara, the Pitjantjatjara, and the Matuntara linguistic groups. But it was the Minister who forgot who these groups were because he gave the rock to the Mititjula community, which is a community formed for administrative purposes at the rock. It does not represent any of those traditional linguistic groups referred to in Toohey's report. It is the Minister, not the Opposition, who has made mistakes. I would ask the Minister to state in this place what are the terms and conditions of the agreement and lease.

I raise two final matters with the Minister. One relates to the photography ban. Can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs guarantee that photography will be able to take place at Ayers Rock and that incidents of the type concerning Val Doonican, Paul Hogan, the Melbourne Herald and others will not happen again? Also I mentioned the subject of a life saving alarm system that was arranged to be installed at the rock. There have been a number of accidents on the rock whose face is very steep indeed, as the Minister might know if he has climbed it. I think that there have been some 14 accidents over the years and some nine heart attacks. Other people have fallen and lost their lives on the rock and there may have been heart attacks as people have come off the rock. A life saving alarm system was to be connected at a number of points. There is a telephone at the bottom of the rock. A life saving system was planned at the top of the climb, but the Mititjula community apparently was against that installation. I would ask the Minister to take up that matter and to have the system installed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to speak earlier on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1985, and went to some trouble to prepare what I considered a worthwhile speech but, as time is so short for this debate, unfortunately that speech will not be made. It is another speech to be filed away.
—Blame the Leader of the House; he is hopeless.

—Why does the honourable member for Mitchell not sit in his right seat if he wants to open his mouth? Throughout last Thursday, and again this afternoon, we have listened to Opposition spokespersons who have attempted to be critical of the Government for its action in granting the land at Uluru National Park to Aboriginal people. They have raised a number of points to which I want to address my remarks. One matter is the entitlement of the people in that area to this land. The Aboriginal people established their rightful claims in front of Mr Justice Toohey.
—Come on, Gerry.

—It is very difficult to speak while the honourable member for Maranoa is interjecting. He came into the House and made a contribution in which he talked about every conceivable issue except the one we are debating. He talked about unemployment benefit, kangaroos and a whole range of other unrelated issues. If he would like to be quiet he might learn something about the Bill in the course of the Committee stage. The purpose of the Bill is to provide a grant of title to the land in Uluru National Park to an Aboriginal land trust and to provide for an arrangement whereby the Aboriginal land trust is required to lease back the land to the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to hold for the purpose of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. I think two points ought to be made about that lease. The second reading speech of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The lease-back arrangements agreed with the traditional Aboriginal owners of Uluru provide for the traditional owners to lease Uluru to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife for a period of 99 years, and an annual rental of $75,000 plus 20 per cent of gross park entrance fees-

I do not think that is an unreasonable situation to have us agree to. In fact, it gives the Aboriginals representation on the board. Also, I think it ensures that the park will be managed in accordance with the wishes of both the Aborigines and the general non-Aboriginal community. I want to refer to the speech in the second reading debate of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), who is the Opposition's spokesman on this subject. He talked about creating division in the community. Since last week he has been known as old riotous Roger because of his performance in the front of this place. We have been through that a number of times. I do not want him to get excited, leap to his feet and take a point of order. But, quite frankly, his performance the other day surprised me. It surprised me that he would get into that sort of behaviour.

Whilst I am on my feet I would like to pay a tribute to certain people who are in the gallery-Pat Dodson from the Central Land Council, Rob Riley from the National Aboriginal Conference and some of the other people from that area. I hope they are taking note of the remarks being made by the Opposition members in this debate who have been parading around as the great defenders of the Aboriginal community when, in fact, they are doing exactly the opposite. I will not go into the other points raised in the speech of the Opposition's spokesman. He talked about traditional owners. I think the reference to Mr Justice Toohey quite clearly overcomes his problem.

I want to make some remarks about another speaker, and that is the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). He has left the chamber and I am sorry about that. Perhaps I will get another chance to speak after the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I am sure that his contribution will be a rip-roarer. I do not think he will pay a lot of heed and attention to the legislation. We all know his background and his attitude to Aboriginal people. We are all waiting with bated breath for what he has to say. I am sure that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, who are sitting at the table, will do what they normally do with the honourable member for O'Connor when he talks on this issue-wipe the floor with him.

I will get back to the honourable member for the Northern Territory. In this House today he talked about this proposal to give Aboriginal people title to Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park and about how wrong it all is. In the Northern Territory News on Saturday, 11 May 1985 the honourable member's remarks were reported. The article was headed: 'Plan for The Rock criticised'. The article stated:
Canberra-The Aboriginal community who wanted to reclaim Ayers Rock was 'a tiny vested interest group of very unsophisticated people who are totally manipulated by a couple of smart white advisers'-

I know a couple of those white advisers. The honourable member for O'Connor, by way of interjection, talked about one adviser, Phillip Toyne. I am glad and proud to be a friend of Phillip Toyne. The honourable member underrates Aboriginal people when he puts down and criticises these white advisers. Aboriginal people are not stupid. They are not able to be manipulated by white advisers. Phillip Toyne would be the first person to point that out to the honourable member. When he has a go at Phillip Toyne and other people he is having a go at Aboriginal people. It is unfair and very unjust of him even to suggest that. Let me come back to the honourable member for the Northern Territory. It is very interesting that, as has been quoted, in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly on 13 February 1980 he said:

The Northern Territory Government has been attempting to negotiate with the Aboriginal people through the Central Land Council in respect of Uluru National Park exactly the same arrangements for the last twelve months. As we are now negotiating with the Northern Land Council with respect to the Cobourg Peninsula.

The honourable member came into this House and criticised this Government for achieving what he attempted to do in 1980. In 1982 he put the infamous 10-point package to Aboriginal people but, again, Aboriginal people were not what he thought they were. They saw through this Mickey Mouse approach by the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory to try to con and mislead them, and they rejected it. It is interesting that the honourable member says that he has never offered land to these people under the same sorts of programs. I will be attempting to get room in this place to show a videotape I have. Honourable members opposite are quite welcome to watch it. There we have the former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, now the honourable member for the Northern Territory in this place, making an offer to grant freehold title to Aboriginal people. Yet for cheap, opportunistic purposes he came into this place today and tried to tell the people of Australia that this is wrong and will divide the community.

Why was he, as Chief Minister, prepared to hand out his pamphlet-it is all on there-along with Malcolm Fraser and suggest that the Aboriginals should have freehold title? Why do people who parade around in other roles have a different set of rules and principles? Then the honourable member came to Canberra and landed on the Opposition benches. I point out to people that even Joh Bjelke-Petersen did not want the honourable member for the Northern Territory. He has been quoted in the media as saying that the reason the honourable member is in the Liberal Party is that the National Party did not want him. He probably will not be here for terribly much longer because the people of the Northern Territory, and certainly the Aborigines, will not be voting for him next time because they have seen through him. He talks with a forked tongue. He says one thing in the Northern Territory and comes to Canberra and ingratiates himself with the racist elements which exist within the Northern Territory-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a first class member.

—He is not a first class member. If he was, the honourable member would not have to keep saying that. He would be able to prove it himself. The point is that all this is on the tape. It is a pity that I cannot incorporate it in Hansard because it shows members of the Liberal Party for what they are. They are phoneys in the extreme.
—I did not think you blokes would mention the word 'tape' again.

—Here is the old iron bar basher, the man who goes around the countryside and has other people hold Aborigines while he hits them with an iron bar. He should not start talking about Aboriginal affairs. He is an outrageous disgrace to this place and his record speaks for itself. Not to be outdone, again in 1984 the honourable member for the Northern Territory, in his capacity as Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, indicated his preparedness to recognise Aboriginal claims to Uluru by offering perpetual freehold title under Northern Territory law. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am ready to resume discussions with the traditional owners . . .

Earlier in the debate we were told that there are not any traditional owners. That was what was said today. In 1984, 1982 and 1980 there were traditional owners. It seems to me that by calling divisions honourable members opposite are wanting to get their names on the record as having opposed this measure, as honourable members opposite have been doing. That tactic is designed purely to get on side with people in the community who are definitely opposed to Aboriginal people. I want to touch again on the remarks of the honourable member for the Northern Territory because I think it is important that we point out a couple of things about him and understand why he has come to this conclusion. My time has almost expired but there will be another opportunity to talk about some other issues of which people are becoming aware in regard to the honourable member for the Northern Territory. I will be raising them in other debates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to get some comment from that great urbanist, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), who has had about four or five-
—Urbanist?

—Yes. He has urban tunnel vision, what is more. He has spent about three weeks or maybe six months of his life-certainly a few weeks collectively-dealing with the problems of Aboriginal people and he thinks he is the full bottle. He wants to talk about my involvement-
—On a point of order-
—This will be a frivolous point of order, Madam Chairman. I heard your remarks on that today.
—The remarks of the speaker are incorrect-
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor need not give his advice to the Chair. I do not need it. I call the honourable member for Melbourne.
—My point of order is that what the honourable member cited as my experience in this area is not correct.
—The honourable member does not have a point of order. He will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—I repeat: The man has urban tunnel vision. If he wants to talk about my position over a period, he can say at any time that I have a conviction for assaulting an Aboriginal person. I will repeat it for him: The man was a gangster. He used to bash up people of his own race frequently and at that time he had eight convictions for doing that. I will protect an old lady, whether she is black or white, from a gangster. The honourable member would not understand that. His politics are the politics of bash. Let us get that straight when we talk about people. That is what is wrong with this Bill. The honourable members thinks that no white person can protect old ladies from a black gangster. That is his view and that is his problem. He is hung up.
—It does not give you the right to hit him with an iron bar.
—I did not; it was something else, and it was necessary because he could fight.
—It was necessary to hold him, too.

—It was, but do not let us worry about that. Plenty of that happens around areas the Minister would know well. The honourable member also talked about divisions. Let us talk about hypocrisy. I know why divisions are wanted. We want to get a group of Western Australian members on the record because they do not speak in this place like the honourable member for Melbourne. They have not come into this debate. Those members know what the feelings are of Western Australians, the people who elect them, and they are conspicuous by their absence.
—I spoke.

—The honourable member for Moore had a few words of a very moderate kind to say, but the others are not here. I remember on a previous occasion challenging the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), then Minister for Aviation, to debate me on this subject in the Ascot Inn right in the heart of his electorate. He has never taken me up on the issue and he is not likely to. I can tell him how his constituents feel on this issue. That is why I am on my feet.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members become members of this place with numerous responsibilities, not the least of which is the responsibility to represent here, in debate and by vote, the needs, aspirations and requirements of the majority of their constituents. It is not for politicians to claim that their election to office allows them to force their opinions on the electorate. It is not for policitians to force the views of their electorate committees or their branch secretaries upon the community. It is not for politicians to claim a right to impose the opinions of some foreign constituency upon their electorate. It is often not possible to meet all the demands of the constituency. Financial constraints may make it impossible. In most cases, nevertheless, we fail to meet the demands of our constituencies only by failing to give what they desire. Only occasionally do we give them things that clearly they do not want.

These Bills now before the Parliament, which will transfer Australia's best known natural monument to an ethnic group with very limited proven rights to such an area, should any such thing have a moral status, are not the result of community demand and in fact face overwhelming community opposition. The legislation is not wanted by the majority of Australians, whether they be counted across the nation or by electoral division. Australians are outraged and enraged by the Government's intentions. Whereas Australians tolerated and, in some cases, supported previous actions to create and grant ethnic land title, it was the announcement by Prime Minister Hawke of the granting of title to Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal co-operative that dragged them from their apathy. To those, particularly in Victoria and New South Wales, who were secure in the knowledge that 'it could not happen to us', the shock was immense. Ayers Rock is a piece of every Australian's backyard. To claim that it is not the property of all who have Australian citizenship is to take an irreversible step in the partitioning of Australia. If the Government does not believe that, there is a simple solution: It can hold a referendum on the matter and can gamble with me on the result.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had an election.

—Yes, but have a referendum on that issue and see how you go. The Government is denying the Australian people what they want of it. This irreversible step is not the first step. That step was taken long ago but was generally ignored. The partitioning of 40 per cent of the Northern Territory was just too remote for urban Australians. They thought that they lost nothing directly, and this apparently worthless gesture made some feel good. The granting of title to Ayers Rock is the irreversible step in the partitioning of Australia. It is the step that puts a mental partition in the minds of most Australians.
—Partitioning? What nonsense!
—The Minister wants to talk to the people who vote for him.
—We did, at the last election.

—How many? It is a partition that puts Aboriginals apart. No longer will the Aboriginal be seen just as socially different; he will now be seen universally as having taken something that belongs to all Australians. This will be aggravated further by power-hungry white advisers who have already demonstrated their stupidity by denying access to media groups and others.

SPEECH.PARA: When one adds to this the disastrous mismanagement of Aboriginal funding, which daily appears worse, one need not wonder why that gap will widen. When it is all over, we might ask: What is in it for the Aboriginal community? What is in all of this land rights business for the individual Aboriginal? Why should the previously steady and patient moves to accept and cement integration be disrupted by such moves as the granting of the title to Ayers Rock? This legislation creates a lease-back which will transfer $100,000 per annum to an Aboriginal co-operative. That might help Aboriginals in some way, but I am somewhat interested to look at how they have been helping themselves to date. I looked for land council reports, but I found that I could not get a report from the Northern Land Council. It has not put one out for three years, although it is thinking of putting out a composite effort now, so I cannot tell honourable members how they have been helping themselves except that I know that the royalties and other payments going to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account are in the order of $17m per annum. All I can find out is what is going to the Central Land Council, which I congratulate on an excellent report. At least it has put something out for the last two years, but of course it deals with only $2.5m of the $17m. I find that total income is $2.596m and then all of a sudden I find how it is spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it that whites object to about Aborigines getting money?
—I am talking about doing some good for Aboriginals, not giving them a bureaucracy. That is what I am talking about. Let us look at how the money is spent. When I look at that revenue--
—What has this got to do with the Bill?

—It is about the $100,000 the Government is going to give the Aboriginals. Let us see how it will disappear. When I look at the expenditure I find that they spent $237,000 on consulting fees, $19,000 on information and public relations, $30,000 on land administration, $158,000 on meeting expenses, $96,000 on office expenses, $41,000 on payroll tax, $939,000 on salaries and wages and $254,000 on travel.
—What is wrong with that?

—I just want to know when the Government is going to do some good for the Aboriginals. At the end of all that, $1.9m has been spent out of $2.5m and not a penny has been spent on housing, education or health-the things that people want. The Central Land Council is a bureaucrats' benefit. The Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account is a bureaucrats' benefit trust account. That is where the money is going and that is what I am attacking the Government for.
—On a point of order--
—Oh, come on! As soon as it starts to hurt, Barry--
—It has nothing to do with this Bill.

—Of course it is about the damn Bill. There is $100,000 of rent in this Bill. The Minister knows it is there and I am telling him how the Government let the money be wasted. I have been criticised. I sat on committee after committee in Carnarvon and built 40 houses for Aboriginal people. We had to summons the Western Australian Minister for Health to achieve that. I worked very hard to get people the things they needed-housing, education and proper health services. That is what I worked for in my community. With my fellow councillors, I got the Aboriginals out of the reserve; we got them out of their horrible conditions. That is how we did it. We served a summons on a Liberal State Minister. I am talking about the good we can do for Aboriginal people-not the rubbish that the Government comes up with to grant them title to Ayers Rock, to give them nothing else, and then to let the land councils have money to spend on administration and nothing on anything else. The two reports of the Central Land Council show that $25,000 out of $5m was spent on housing. Yet the Minister reckons he can administer things. The only problem is that whenever he walks past a bit of corruption he thinks he is back in Richmond.

—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I point out to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, in relation to when he was thinking of raising a point of order, that very few members have actually spoken to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to address myself to some of the remarks that have been made. I am pleased that there are some Aboriginal people present in the chamber on this occasion, because I think it will give them some insight into the approach of the Opposition on these matters. Reduced to its simplest form, what has been suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is that all we really need to do for Aboriginal people is give them a house and a feed and see that, if they get problems with their tonsils or some disease, they are looked after. The honourable member for O'Connor and his colleagues, with the sense of paternalism which came right through every word, said that they will determine what Aboriginal people need and want; they will determine what Aboriginal aspirations and hopes are in terms of achieving some measure of social equality.
—What are you doing?

—The first thing I will say is that the honourable member ought to recognise that in 1985 this Government recognises that Aboriginal people are able to determine for themselves their aspirations and hopes. They do not need someone like the honourable member for O'Connor to interpret their hopes and aspirations for them.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. The one point that has not been answered by any member of the Opposition is that the decision in respect of Uluru was not a decision taken in isolation. It was a decision which virtually culminated some seven years of negotiation between a former Liberal government and a conservative administration in the Northern Territory. What we have seen today is an attempt by the Opposition to achieve the very thing that Malcolm Fraser as Prime Minister and a Liberal conservative coalition government would not concede in government. That is the reality. What a previous Liberal-National party government said was that the Northern Territory Government could and should negotiate with the land councils, which have been the subject of disparaging remarks by honourable members opposite, for the purpose of granting an Aboriginal title. It appears from the records that the only difference between the Northern Territory Administration and the former Government was ultimately resolved. There was no question about title being handed over to the traditional owners.

The Northern Territory Government-honourable members can have it in black and white if they want it-wanted to give a Northern Territory title. That was the very clear import of a statement made by the then Prime Minister. What could be clearer than this? I refer to a statement made in June 1982 by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the present honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). He did not make very many statements, so this is a collector's item. After the intervention of the then Prime Minister he said:
A land rights package being pursued by the two governments--
that is, the Northern Territory Government and the then Federal Government-
would include provision for ownership of Uluru by Aborigines by way of a grant of Northern Territory title to Aboriginal trustees and for the area to be declared and managed as a national park.

The only difference now is that there will be a Federal title. There is a Federal decision in respect of Federal property and title will issue under Northern Territory laws. During the entire period of the Fraser Government Administration, the principle of recognising the claim of Aboriginal people was never in dispute, either by the previous Government or the Northern Territory Administration. That is the simple, undeniable fact. So what we have here today is a disgrace to a party that once stood for land rights. It is an absolute disgrace because what we have now is a mawkish, latently racist exposition. I exclude the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), from that. The honourable member for O'Connor said: 'Oh, what we must do is look at the balance sheets of the land councils'. I say this: The balance sheets of the land councils, imperfect as they may be, would not compare with some of the balance sheets of the backers of the Liberal and National parties-the tax dodgers who were not too anxious, when there was a Bill in the Senate, to retrieve half a thousand million dollars defrauded from the Commonwealth. Were the honourable member for O'Connor and honourable gentlemen opposite concerned? Did they say: 'We must retrieve those ill-gotten gains fraudulently taken from public revenue'? Oh no! They said: 'That would be retrospective. We must not do that'. But let an Aboriginal land council present a public balance sheet which shows that it is doing its duty and the honourable member for O'Connor says: 'Hang on, we can't have them running their own affairs. It is up to us to say whether they are sick or well. It is up to us to say whether we will give them a house or an education'. That latent racist attitude has no place in Australian society.

I would say very simply this: The decision on this issue has been taken by the Parliament today. It is a decision which flows logically from the previous negotiations that have taken place. It is a decision in principle which says to all Australian people that we not only recognise the relationship our indigenous people to this important part of Australia but also believe that the management processes which we are putting in place will operate not merely for their benefit but for the benefit of all Australians. I dismiss the mean and despicable utterances of some honourable gentlemen opposite.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

'the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall that at about 2.30 on Friday morning, when we were debating the second reading of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill, I made a number of observations about the reasons why the Opposition is opposing this legislation. I think it is worth noting in that context that the principal political problem with this Bill is that the Australian Labor Party built up unreasonable expectations in the Australian Aboriginal community. The point was made in the previous debate that in fact negotiations for the handing over of control of the Uluru National Park to the Aborigines were initiated both by the Northern Territory Government and by the previous Fraser Government. No one has ever denied that discussions were conducted between those two authorities. However, it is only a question of time before the Northern Territory achieves statehood. On that ground alone this legislation creates an opportunity which the Hawke Government should be taking to proceed with the devolution of responsibilities from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What the amendments to the enabling legislation, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill, do is to install in the Act provisions by which the Commonwealth will continue to control national parks in the Northern Territory for a substantial period. While this Government quite clearly does not wish to see the Northern Territory reach statehood, the simple, inexorable fact is that in time it will. The actions and initiatives which have been taken by this Government in our opinion fly in the face of reality. In addition, the Opposition believes that the government, by handing over this national monument to one section of our community, is reducing the rights of the remainder of the Australian community.

It has been said by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) that the Fraser Government had an approach to land rights which is not shared by those on the Opposition benches today. May I go a step further and make the observation that the views of the Fraser Government are certainly not shared by the current Minister or by the Party in government. If that were not the situation I think we would have overcome in the last 2 1/2 years what has become a serious problem in Australia, which, to a large degree, has been created and developed by the Minister and by the Party of which he is a member.

As I have said, the Australian Labor Party built up unreasonable Aboriginal expectations for land rights in Australia. I think it is worth noting that it was the previous Government which, over its seven years in office, put land rights in place, something that this Government has failed to do. Surely in some respects the time has come to review the implementation of that legislation and to see how it has affected land rights and other economic and social activities in areas which are related to it, in particular, of course the Northern Territory, where the question of mining, has created considerable difficulties. It remains very much a canker in the mind of the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I trust that in due course he will do his best to overcome it.

The Fraser Government accepted the significance of Ayers Rock and the Uluru area to the Aboriginal community which resides there. It is for that reason that on 24 May 1977 the Uluru National Park was proclaimed under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. This provided a means of safeguarding access to the wider Australian community while, at the same time, ensuring that the sacred sites and the significance of the area as a whole would continue to be protected. Those of us who were still awake at about 2.15 on Friday morning will recall an observation made by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in response to a comment I made as to why it was that we were debating this legislation more or less in vacuo, because so much of the information about negotiations which had apparently been conducted between the relevant Ministers and the local Aboriginal community had not to this date been made available to this Parliament. It is not, in my opinion and the opinion of the Opposition, a sensible basis upon which legislation of this importance should be debated unless we have access to all that information.

The amendments which have been incorporated in this legislation refer to the question of plans of management. I made the observation in my speech at the second reading stage of the debate that the Opposition does not even know at this stage whether the local Aboriginal community is prepared to accept the existing plan of management and, if not, what amendments it wishes to see in place. I recall the Minister making an observation which he later denied. However, the simple fact of the matter is that there seems to be substantial doubt in the minds of members of the Government as to what exactly they are trying to achieve in this area.

I think that most significant in terms of plans of management is section 11 of the Principal Act, as amended, which puts in place arrangements by which there will be a majority of Aboriginal membership on the board responsible for plans of management. This Government has established a very interesting situation which can only be described as a sleight of hand. While on the one hand it says that it favours Aboriginal land rights, by which it apparently means that the overall control of an area should be under the administration of the local Aboriginal community, the fact of the matter is that under the amendments to this legislation the Government will achieve precisely the opposite. It has made an arrangement by which although a majority of Aboriginals is on the board the key decisions will be made by the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and, in cases where there may be disagreement between the Aboriginal community-that is, the majority on the board-and the Director the decisions can then be made by the Minister. All we have, as a sop, is that management plans will be tabled in the Parliament at some future date.

I find this a rather extraordinary situation. The Government's desires to maintain Commonwealth control indefinitely, by using subterfuges while at the same time saying to the Aboriginal community: 'We are giving you power to determine your own future but we do not really trust you so we are putting a mechanism in place which makes sure that public servants, based in Canberra, with the support of Ministers who are again in Canberra, will determine the welfare of the Aboriginal community and the wider welfare of the Uluru Park'.

These are precisely the reasons why the Opposition is not supporting this legislation. We do not see that it is consistent with the objective to devolve power from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory. We do not see it as consistent with the overall responsibility of any Federal Government which is to look after the interests of all Australians. I think it is fair to say that surely Ayers Rock is truly Australia's symbol of solidity and strength and as such it must belong, and be seen to belong, to all Australians. For this reason the Opposition opposes this legislation because it gives title of the Uluru National Park to the Aboriginal community and thus negates the belief that many millions of Australians see the rock as belonging to their nation, in fact belonging to us all.

The Bill proposes that the Commonwealth will lease back the park from the Aboriginal community but that the park must be managed, as I have said, by a board on which the Aboriginal community will have a majority membership but no effective power. It is a matter of regret that because of the Government's failure to provide information we are debating this Bill in a vacuum. All we have been told is that the lease back will cost taxpayers $75,000 a year plus 20 per cent of the park's takings, which represents a further $20,000-odd.

For those members of the Government who have gained some pleasure in this debate from trying to brand the Opposition parties as being anti-Aboriginal land rights, they would do well to check realities against what they may like to think. It was the coalition Government which introduced land rights legislation; it was the Hawke Labor Government which destroyed the National Aboriginal Conference. It has been the Hawke Labor Government which, to date, has failed to put in place the Aboriginal policy upon which it was elected and that was to continue an effective system of Aboriginal land rights in Australia. All we have seen in the 2 1/2 years that the Australian Labor Party has occupied the Treasury bench has been constant fights with its State counterparts, especially in Western Australia. Consequently, is it unreasonable for the Aboriginal community to feel surprised and somewhat concerned as to its future? All one can say is that the government has given it every reason to feel that way.

Therefore, the problems of the future as far as land management is concerned should rest with the Northern Territory. That is precisely the reason why we believe that this legislation should not be passed and it is why I move:
Schedule, page 12, omit the amendment to sub-section 7 (11A).

This is a very relevant and important amendment because it gives the Commonwealth power to extend parks within the region. The region as far as this legislation is concerned is not just Uluru but also the Alligator Rivers region and, of course, the Kakadu National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not until the last few seconds of the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) that he talked about his amendment. I am not going to canvass all of the matters that he raised in the first 9 3/4 minutes of his speech because they have already been canvassed widely in the debate so far. He referred to sub-section 7 (11A) which, as he points out quite correctly, applies to Kakadu National Park as well as to the Uluru National Park. The Fraser Government introduced the present sub-section 7 (11A) in 1978. The intention of that action was to implement a recommendation of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, that the declaration of a national park within the region should be exempt from public representation requirements. This was justified at the time in view of the considerable public discussion which had already taken place during and preceding the inquiry. I remind honourable members that probably no issue in the history of this Parliament was ever more widely canvassed than this issue through the Fox inquiry. That was the reason why this section was put in. As I said before, it was a sensible section because it had been very widely canvassed in public debate and it was pointless to have further public debate on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, recent legal advice has suggested that sub-section 7 (11A) of the Act is too vague and that it could exempt from public comment not only proclamations creating parks within the region but also proclamations removing land from parks. This interpretation conflicts with the intention of the sub-section. The reason why we have suggested this amendment is to clarify the legislation. The amendment expresses the original intention of sub-section 7 (11A) by clearly providing that the exemption from public representations will not apply to proclamations whereby land would cease to be park or reserve. Furthermore, only land within the region could be made park or reserve without public representations, as was the case under the Fraser Government's original sub-section 7 (11A). The amendment would also enable land already in a park or reserve to be incorporated in another park or reserve without the need for public representations. This provision would apply only where the status of the land would not be changed by the proclamation. Therefore, we reject the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), we believe that the proclamation is necessary because it gives an opportunity to the public to have notice and it is very important that there be notice in these matters. We have seen the problems of excessive power with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife in relation to the photography ban occurring at Ayers Rock. We believe that the amendments that the Government is proposing enable the Commonwealth to transfer land within a park, reserve or wilderness zone to another park, reserve or wilderness zone without having to comply with section 11 of the principal Act-the public notice section-without the need for proclamation. We believe that that is unreasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) and also the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) to again provide the terms and conditions of the agreement under the previous Act and the lease, which would be relevant under this Act, as to the terms and conditions upon which the park is to be owned by the lessor and leased. We clearly need to have those terms and conditions before this Parliament. The other point I make is that there seems to be a difference as to the treatment of the Uluru National Park under the legislation introduced by this Government and that of Kakadu National Park. Under the Government's definition, the future traditional owners of Uluru have a say in the management decisions of the park but under the Kakadu arrangement there is a different arrangement in relation to consultation. Is the Government intending to change the situation in relation to Kakadu?

The Minister has indicated that he wants me to repeat the point I made about the difference between Kakadu and Uluru. Under the proposal, as I understand it, and we have not seen the lease and the agreement, it is proposed by the Government that the traditional owners-I understand that they will be the members of the Mititjula community, but the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has not told us in this House to whom it is going to be transferred-will have a majority say at Uluru in the management decisions of the park but the traditional Aboriginal owners of Kakadu do not have the same power. They are only consulted. In fact, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service seems to have the say there. I ask the Minister whether there is a difference in control over the management of the park? For instance, does that have something to do with the placing of Kakadu on the World Heritage list?

Whilst the Minister is getting the answer to that, the other point I want to make is in relation to the Northern Territory Conservation Commission, which is a dedicated organisation with officers who are really dedicated to protecting the environment for which they are responsible. I believe they have played a fine role in relation to Uluru National Park and that they have an excellent relationship with the Aboriginal community which lives there. However, they have been chopped off and cut out and there is no role for the Northern Territory Conservation Commission in this new proposal. I think that is outrageous and scandalous because it is a dedicated organisation, managed and run by dedicated people who feel strongly about the environment in the broadest sense of the word. I believe that to cut them out and to put in Canberra bureaucrats is really nothing short of outrageous and irresponsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be as brief as I can. I could not quite follow the reasoning of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) at the end when he said that the Northern Territory Government is not going to be involved.
—The Conservation Commission.
—It is going to run the Uluru National Park.
—It is not on the management committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF REVIEW INTO AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LAW AND SYSTEMS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, and seek leave to make a statement.
—Is leave granted?

—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence. In giving leave, I comment that we are giving a quarter-of-an-hour dispensation. I understand the problem, but I stress that in regard to the business of the House it facilitates consideration if, normally, we have the two-hour notice of the statement about to be made. In those circumstances, we give leave, given the problems that existed.

—We have been almost scrupulous in following that convention of the Parliament. We are 15 minutes out on this occasion, but let me remind the Parliament that in the lead-up to 1983 the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, completely disregarded that rule. He never gave us his speeches two hours beforehand, and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) was part of that.
—Order! There seems to be a certain indigenous restiveness around the place tonight. There being no objection, leave is granted.

—The report of the Committee of Review I have just tabled is the result of a wide ranging and fundamental examination into Australian industrial relations law and systems. The Review Committee had as its Chairman Professor Keith Hancock, and Messrs George Polites and Charlie Fitzgibbon as members. The background and experience of the Chairman and members is well known. The terms of reference of the review were unanimously endorsed by the National Labour Consultative Council and had the bipartisan support at the political level of all of the States and the Northern Territory, being ratified by the Conference of Labour Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The charter of the review, as specified in its terms of reference, was to examine, report and make recommendations on the development of a more effective and practical industrial relations system in accordance with social, economic and industrial changes which have occurred and are taking place in Australia. In short, the review was to make a detailed examination and report on the strengths and weaknesses of the Australian industrial relations system. In the light of its investigations, the review was commissioned to recommend changes so that the system can better respond to developments during the rest of the century. Nothing in its terms of reference prevented the Committee from a complete reassessment of the current system and, if it was seen as warranted, recommending its replacement with some other system capable of providing better results.

The report addresses fundamental issues in this respect. These include the type of system we should have; the objectives of the system; the economic impact of industrial relations; and the specific institutional and operational components which go to a practical and effective system. Of equal importance to the recommendations themselves is the detailed examination of our industrial relations system in all its aspects that forms the basis of proposals for change. Quite correctly, the review has taken a very broad interpretation of its terms of reference to examine the industrial relations system in its social and industrial dimensions and its operation at the Federal and State level and at the level of the work place. The Committee has also provided a detailed examination of the economic issues involved in wage fixation and has addressed specifically the frequently made claims for a more decentralised deregulated system.

I note that the Committee even went so far as to arrange a conference on 'Alternatives to Arbitration' which brought together academics and practitioners specifically to address the alternatives such as a deregulated approach to industrial relations based on collective bargaining. I welcome the approach of the Committee to its terms of reference and that such a wide range of views were put to it from major sectors of the business community, economists, lawyers and the like, as well as from the established industrial organisations, both employer and union, both big and small, operating nationally and at the State level.

These organisations and individuals demonstrated a willingness to put submissions forward, and for both orthodox and radical views to be the subject of critical examination by a representative group of our most experienced and distinguished individuals in the industrial relations and economic arena. It was therefore a real opportunity for the critics of the system-and there have been many in recent times-to put up or shut up. It is a major finding of this report that these vocal critics failed to put up any workable alternative, despite being given ample opportunity to do so. Insofar as alternatives were presented, they gave little consideration to how they could be given practical effect in the real world of the Australian labour market.

The fundamental finding of this report is for the continuation of Australia's system of conciliation and arbitration. The Committee thoroughly examined arguments for change and concluded that no realistic proposals nor compelling arguments to abandon the current system had been put forward. The Committee specifically warned against accepting the 'grass is greener' fallacy-the assumption that because given arrangements have defects there must be some preferable and available alternative. In the Committee's view, change should be attempted only if there is reasonable ground for the expectation that present problems will be overcome and worse problems will not be created. Clearly, the Committee did not find this to be the case with arguments for abandoning our present system.

In this context the report refutes the suggestion that there is any conflict between deregulation of financial markets, as pursued by this Government, and the continuation of a conciliation and arbitration system. The report rightly argues that there are fundamental differences between labour markets and financial markets-in particular, the fact that labour markets are subject to concentrations of power through the organisation of trade unions. This finding has particular validity given that the Chairman of the Committee, Professor Hancock, was a member of the Martin Committee which examined the deregulation of Australia's financial system.

One of the main advantages the Committee sees in our system of conciliation and arbitration is that it affords a mechanism for a centralised wages policy. In reviewing our recent history of wage fixation-since the beginning of the 1970s-the Committee notes that wage 'explosions' have occurred during periods of decentralised wage determination. It points out that wages policy, as part of incomes policy, provides an important avenue for government management of the economy which can curb inflationary behaviour other than by restricting aggregate demand. In short, wages policy, together with other arms of economic policy, can provide means by which governments can do more to increase output and employment. The report specifically points to the unattractiveness of the alternatives to an incomes policy which offer continuing, and possibly escalating, inflation and reliance upon demand management with its corollaries of higher unemployment and reduced output.

The Committee undertook a most comprehensive examination of evidence concerning the question of whether wage relativities encourage or impede the adaptation of the labour force to structural change, and the influence of the conciliation and arbitration system on the Australian wage structure. The report highlights the inconclusive nature of many of the economic studies that have been undertaken. It found little to support the assertion that the arbitral tribunals have damaged the economy by their influence on wage relativities; nor does the Committee consider that the allocation of labour depends heavily on flexible relativities. Claims that our wage system is too inflexible to adapt to changing economic circumstances are not borne out. However, acknowledging that a given set of wage relativities are unlikely to be 'right' forever, the report considered it desirable for the industrial relations system to have the capacity to accommodate changes in relativities to reflect changes in work value. With regard to assessments of work value, there was a need for effective reviews to occur wherein the force of comparative wage justice was restrained in favour of the reassessment of absolute pay levels.

The Committee also supports in principle, and subject to certain constraints, the retention in the system of a capacity for the wage fixing tribunal to have regard to the particular circumstances of threatened industries or firms, to allow wage levels below those which would otherwise be prescribed as a means of protecting employment. The Committee also believes that a review of juvenile relativities might be appropriate but emphasises that it is mistaken to see in the present levels of juvenile rates the major cause of juvenile unemployment and to hold high expectations of the beneficial effects of their reduction.

It can be seen from my brief outline of the Committee's discussion of the economic and wage policy issues that these matters loomed large in the Committee's considerations. Its conclusions in this regard form an important basis for its general recommendations to retain our system of conciliation and arbitration and not to adopt the alternative of wholesale collective bargaining. However, because economic and industrial relations issues come into play at all levels of our industrial relations system, the Committee recommends that in all proceedings of the Commission the public interest be taken into account and for that purpose regard be had to the state of the national economy and the likely effects of any decision on the level of employment and on inflation. In the fundamentally important area of wages policy, therefore, the main thrust of the report gives strong support for the Government's approach.

The review unanimously concluded that conciliation and arbitration should remain the mechanism for regulating industrial relations in Australia. It is likely that the critics of conciliation and arbitration will assert that that would have been expected of the Committee. Such an assertion fails to address the arguments in support of a conciliation and arbitration system on their merits. As the Review Committee found, these arguments are substantial. They go to community acceptability, the attitudes of the parties who participate in the industrial relations system, the achievement of macro-economic policies and the maintenance of an orderly and equitable framework for the resolution of industrial conflict.

An important element of the system is the process of dispute resolution. The Committee has made recommendations going to more certainty in the use of the processes of conciliation and arbitration. The Committee places greater emphasis on conciliation as a first step and upon the parties accepting responsibility to resolve their difference. The recommendations also deal extensively with means by which more direction can be given to the parties' own relationships in dealing with work place disputes and for effective resolution rather than their being turned into industrial action.

The Committee has also made other significant recommendations concerning dispute resolution including the concept of industry consultative councils, different means of dealing with demarcation problems and the application of sanctions for unacceptable industrial behaviour. With regard to sanctions the Committee recommended that all provisions providing for fines or imprisonment for persons engaged in strikes, lockouts or other forms of industrial action be repealed. Such provisions have, of course, been inoperative since 1979. The Committee has, however, recommended streamlined provisions for cancellation and suspension of awards and deregistration of organisations as a more effective form of sanction.

Perhaps the most controversial recommendation of the report is that the Act should be amended to allow the parties to enter into an agreement for the resolution of disputes by their own agreed processes of conciliation and arbitration, and for the terms and conditions of employment resulting from these agreed procedures to exclude Federal awards and State prescriptions. Whilst appreciating the increased flexibility that such a provision could bring to the system, it would be necessary to ensure that disputes settlements arising from this process did not destabilise the wages policy being pursued in the formal system.

The Committee has devoted considerable attention to changes in the structure of the institutions within the system. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is to be replaced by an Australian Industrial Relations Commission which emphasises the role proposed for the new body in all matters pertaining to industrial relations, including consultative processes, consideration of the public interest and the promotion of industrial harmony.

Further, the Industrial Division of the Federal Court of Australia will be replaced by a new Australian Labour Court made up of suitably qualified persons who will also hold concurrent commissions as deputy presidents on the Industrial Relations Commission. It is also proposed that the Chief Judge of the Court will be President of the Commission. These changes would provide the scope for the highest degree of integration of Federal arbitral and judicial powers. The Court would have the role of interpreting and enforcing the decisions and awards of the Commission. The report also recommends a complete recasting of the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act to provide a more ordered and simplified framework for the operation of the Federal system. Any proposals which make the system more understandable to ordinary men and women are to be welcomed.

The Government accepts the general thrust of the review recommendations. It believes that the parties within the industrial relations systems, once they have examined them, will also endorse the thrust of the great majority of the recommendations. The Government believes that the wider community will also endorse the report when it has understood the complex, detailed but cogently argued investigations, analysis and recommendations of the review.

An important aspect of the review's work has been devoted to an investigation of the manner in which the Federal and State industrial relations systems might better interrelate. The review has recommended as a long term measure that the Australian Government initiate discussion with the States with the view to putting an integrated system of industrial relations into place. In the shorter term it is recommended that the Federal-State system be improved by building in more co-operation and co-ordination into the existing dual system.

The Government is moving immediately to give effect to the report's recommendation. The Premiers and Chief Minister are being invited to agree to the placement of an item on the agenda of the next Premiers Conference so that more detailed work can then be undertaken by the Conference of Labor Ministers and officials. Side by side with this activity the Government has arranged for the National Labour Consultative Council to immediately begin an assessment of the report and participate in the development of legislation to give effect to the recommendations.

The Government is also aware of, and welcomes, the organisation by various interest groups, including academics and the media, of a series of seminars and conferences to discuss and debate the report and recommendations of the Committee of Review. These conferences and seminars, along with the detailed investigations to be carried out by governments, and the parties to the industrial relations system, will play an effective and practical role in assisting to develop an acceptable and workable system of industrial relations for presentation of the necessary legislation to parliament.

In conclusion, I should like to place on public record our appreciation of the work of the members of the Committee as reflected in their report and recommendations. In many respects their investigations have encompassed and been exposed to opinions which range across the complete spectrum of economic, political, community and industrial relations viewpoints. I congratulate the members of the Committee for their fairness and independence in receiving and assessing these submissions and views, the comprehensiveness and clarity of their report, and in presenting us with unanimous conclusions on virtually all matters. I present the following paper:
Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems-Ministerial statement, 20 May 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me state at the outset that the coalition is resolutely committed to a real improvement of Australia's industrial relations system. There can be no greater necessity for a future coalition government which will have as its fundamental priority the economic revitalisation of Australia's economy, the restoration of full employment and the social well-being and prosperity which can flow from these achievements. When we gain office at the next election we will with great resolution embark upon real improvements necessary in our industrial relations system for these goals to be achieved. It is my task tonight on behalf of the coalition to present our broad and initial action to the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. It is an enormous report running to some three volumes and just over 1,000 pages. We did not receive a copy of the report until this morning. The Government has had it since 30 April. Honourable members will therefore understand that I will be presenting only the coalition's broad initial response to the Hancock report. When we have considered all 148 recommendations and the total 1,000-odd pages in detail we will be in a position to articulate our detailed position on it and will do so in this House and in other forums.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition believes that there are two matters central to a positive improvement of Australia's industrial relations system-two matters which must be addressed if we are to pull ourselves out of the economic hole into which we have fallen and appear to be disappearing deeper and deeper. I refer to the question of accountability between employers and employees who are parties to industrial relations agreements and to the need for the creation of a second stream in our industrial relations system based on voluntary, contractually-based collective bargaining. The three members of the Hancock Committee all have a long and intimate involvement with Australia's centralised industrial relations system. They were commissioned by a Labor government headed by a Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who similarly has a long and intimate involvement in that centralised system, as does his Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). It therefore comes as no surprise to this House that the Committee concentrated on how the centralised system itself, widely regarded as being deficient in several key respects, could be improved and made to work in a more effective manner.

To the Committee's credit it has recognised that the present Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has for many years been incapable of ensuring any accountability or discipline in adherence by unions to the Commission's own awards and rulings. The Committee has also recognised the need to create a mechanism through which parties who wish to make their own agreements outside the centralised system could opt out of that system. I draw the attention of honourable members to recommendation 21 of the Committee's report which says:

Part X of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act be amended to provide that parties who wish to make their own arrangements for the prevention and settlement of disputes by conciliation and arbitration may do so, and that the terms and conditions of employment resulting from those agreed arrangements would be able to operate to the exclusion of federal awards . . .

Recommendation 21 is not the coalition's idea of the ultimately desirable policy approach on the creation of a dual industrial relations system. Nevertheless, we commend the Committee for its courage in making that recommendation at all knowing that its report was destined for the hands of a government which is unable to be consistent in its handling of economic deregulation and which is shaking the very foundations of the market place with uncertainty as a result.

Let me clearly foreshadow that it is the coalition's clear intention to pick up where the Hancock Committee left off. We will be going into the next election with a very clear policy which will provide the necessary legislative framework and protection for employers and employees to voluntarily opt out of the centralised system for a system of collective bargaining based on mutual accountability and responsibility. Similarly, with respect to accountability within the centralised system, we commend the Committee's willingness to be candid about the present Commission's shortcomings as far as ensuring its adherence to its own rulings is concerned. We agree that the creation of a new system not tainted by the long history of compromise and impotence that the present Commission is saddled with is a desirable option. Indeed, the abolition of the present Commission and its replacement with a new tribunal has long been a central plank in the coalition's industrial relations policy. Regrettably, however, here too the Committee has not gone far enough.

On the matter of accountability, the coalition has profound doubts that the threat of union deregistration will be enough to ensure accountability on their part to the proposed new tribunal's rulings. The coalition's policy proposes that parties who break industrial agreements may be sued by the offended parties for damages arising from the breach of the agreement. We believe that this very direct method will be the most persuasive way of turning accountability between parties to industrial agreements into a habit instead of a very infrequently observed exception to the rule. Australia can no longer afford the luxury of having an industrial relations system which allows one side consistently to flout the umpire's decision with little or no penalty. We cannot afford it from an economic standpoint and from a social standpoint, for nothing so encourages the displacement of labour by capital as irresponsible and unreliable employees. There can be no doubt in anyone's mind that industrial relations anarchy is a powerful disincentive to employers for the hiring of new employees or the maintenance of existing work forces.

One further aspect of the Committee's report which heartened the Opposition is its proposal that the new tribunal be forced to give priority consideration to the public interest in its decisions and to the economic impact of its rulings. Regrettably, the report does not have any detailed recommendation as to how the proposed new tribunal should do that. Nevertheless, this is another area in which the Committee has drawn on proposals contained in the coalition's industrial relations policy and which we will ensure when next in government.

To summarise the coalition's view of the positive aspects of this report, bearing in mind our reservations that I outlined earlier and will deal with specifically later: We are heartened to see the adoption of some of the coalition's approach to the improvement of Australia's industrial relations system. I refer specifically to the abolition of the existing Commission and its replacement by a new tribunal; a new emphasis on the public interest and economic ramifications of the new tribunal's decisions and the recognition of the existing system's failure to secure real accountability between parties to industrial agreements; and, thirdly, a recognition of the need to create a second industrial relations stream, as suggested and alluded to in recommendation 21, which effectively proposes the amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to create an opting out clause.

Let me flag briefly some of our more specific concerns. I look forward to having the opportunity to be able to spell these out in greater detail later. In respect of Commonwealth-State jurisdictions, we would not support the transfer of powers from the States to the Commonwealth, which was one option proposed in recommendation 8, to achieve integration. Joint legislation through consultation is the only proper avenue. In respect of recommendation 17 which deals with reinstatement, we reject the awarding of reinstatement powers to any Commonwealth tribunal. If an employee claims wrongful dismissal, he or she should seek damages according to the normal legal processes. With respect to recommendation 19, which deals with independent contractors, the coalition rejects any extension of a Commonwealth tribunal's jurisdiction over sub-contractors. One of the strengths of sub-contract labour has been its flexibility and ability to avoid being bogged down in any commission or tribunal proceedings. This is partly the reason for the spectacular increase in the demand for the services of sub-contractors. The freedom of sub-contractors to remain outside the system must be protected. The Hancock report calls for the establishment of a new Australian Labour Court. We have concerns about the seemingly incestuous nature of the proposal. In our view, enforcement of awards might be better achieved by a court acting more at arm's length from the proposed new tribunal. We have a doubt that the accountability can be ensured as is recommended.

In respect of conscientious objection, which is dealt with in recommendations 84 to 86, the coalition feels that the Committee has got the wrong emphasis entirely with respect to quasi-compulsory union membership. Its recommendations in this area continue very much in the vein of the past, which dictated that employees who did not wish to join a union had to demonstrate conscientious objection. The coalition is planning strong legislation to guarantee the free association of employees, including the freedom to join or not to join a union. In respect of sanctions, which are dealt with in recommendations 135 to 144, as I outlined earlier, the coalition places great importance on re-establishing accountability within any industrial relations system. We are afraid that the Committee's handling of this accountability question is inadequate. The threat of deregistration can only achieve so much. Our policy proposes that damages be awarded against parties which breach an award or a contract of employment. Action along these lines is clearly necessary if true accountability is to be re-established between employers and employees.

Industrial relations is an area where there are clear and very important differences between the Government and the coalition. We are most concerned that government at the Federal level in Australia is being conducted in an improper manner. From our observation the Hawke Government is operating under undue influence from the trade union movement via the leading spokesmen of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. For many weeks we have watched the very sad and extremely serious degeneration of the Government's capacity to devise and develop public policy for the benefit of all Australians. We have seen this with respect to the Queensland blockade whereby the Hawke Government left the citizens of an Australian State out in the cold, leaving them to suffer at the hands of an ACTU inspired and organised campaign of persecution. We have seen it more recently in respect of taxation policy. The Government is unable or unwilling to stand up and advocate the tax package it regards as the most equitable and most effective for the Australian people. Instead, it hangs on the approval of the ACTU. The Government has not had the courage or the fortitude to stand up and take a position on tax reform independently from the ACTU. We have seen it most seriously on the question of wages policy. Despite the informed opinion urging the Government to abandon full indexation based wage fixing, the Government continues to weakly and expediently put forward the approved ACTU line. The Hawke Government is not fulfilling the duties and responsibilities which the electorate imposed on it at the last election, namely, to govern without fear or favour in the interests of all Australians, not merely on behalf of some powerful sectional interests. It is time this Government started living up to its proper role.

In government, the coalition would see the clear necessity to go significantly beyond the mere patching up of the centralised stream of Australia's industrial relations system. It is vital that the system be improved substantially so that it can facilitate rather than frustrate our capacity to take advantage of the opportunities that are thrust upon us. The recent devaluation of the dollar is a graphic case in point. It is widely acknowledged, and with great alarm, that if the Government sticks to its course on the question of discounting it will be sending Australia's economy and any hopes for reducing our very high continuing unemployment down the shute. While we support the improvement of the centralised stream of industrial relations in Australia, we believe, along with many others, that it is simply not enough. The development of a strong and vigorous decentralised stream, with all its attendant beliefs in terms of stimulation of labour demand and economic growth in general, is essential if the economic and, therefore, the social revitalisation that the coalition so fervently desires is to be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill concerns the Government's decisions on the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board, and certain elements of the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 which require amendment so as to conform with complementary State legislation or to correct minor irregularities. The Wheat Marketing Act 1984 gave effect to wheat marketing arrangements to apply for the five-year period from 1 October 1984. Under that Act, the term of office of all Board members expires on 1 October 1985. No provision was made for the process by which grower members of the Board of the Australian Wheat Board were to be nominated for appointment after that date.

Since 25 October 1984, the Board has comprised 15 members including two grower members from each mainland State.
