Following a recent review by me of the Board's operations, the Government announced a restructuring package including an 11-member Board comprising a full time grower chairperson, one grower member from each mainland State, a government member and four members with a high level of expertise in at least one of finance, marketing or industrial relations. Also, an alternate grower member was to be appointed from each mainland State.

In a change from previous selection arrangements the Government foreshadowed the formation of a nine-member Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee, comprising an independent presiding member selected by the Minister, five members nominated by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation, the Australian Wheat Board chairperson and two nominees of the National Farmers Federation, including the President. The Minister would retain responsibility for selecting the chairperson and the government member with the grower members and four specialist members being selected by the Committee.

Amendments to the Bill in the Senate propose arrangements which differ from the previously announced restructuring package in a number of important respects. Government amendments had regard to the views of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation by providing that the Selection Committee should determine whether alternate grower members are to be appointed to the Board of the AWB. The Government also agreed to vary the categories of skills required of members with special qualifications, substituting the broader field of grain movement logistics for industrial relations. Finally, the two NFF members of the Selection Committee are to be nominated by its President, who may also serve on the Committee if he so decides.

The Bill before the House retains the essential elements of the Government's restructuring proposals as previously announced with one important exception. This concerns the acceptance by the Senate of an Opposition amendment which reduces from four to three the number of members of the AWB Board with special qualifications. I foreshadow a Government amendment to the Bill to restore a proper balance of skills available to the Board.

The Government rejects moves by the Senate and the industry to dilute expertise on the Board. We believe that boards of statutory marketing authorities-SMAs-should have an appropriate balance of skills and adopt a corporate approach, both in respect to the commercial functions of marketing and finance and in resolving problems affecting the interests of wheat growers in disparate locations in a manner consistent with the interests of the industry as a whole. I have examined Board minutes going back two years and it is my view that the number of times a decision has to be taken on the basis of a vote or that growers have to have a majority, is infinitesimal. The fact is that the key financial decisions are taken by three people and that the Board acts as a consensus organisation often with too little debate.

The Government's proposals for restructuring the AWB reflect the broader policy objectives which have been set down to apply to all SMAs. That is, SMAs should have independence and flexibility, consistent with safeguarding the Minister's responsibility to Parliament, to allow them to respond effectively to the demands imposed by operating in a competitive commercial environment. This involves substantially relinquishing ministerial controls.

I would like to stress at the outset that the control of the AWB remains firmly in the hands of growers. The Government's proposed 11-man Board comprises a majority of growers. Growers are also in the majority on the AWB Selection Committee. Should the Committee decide that there should be alternates to State grower members, this is provided for in the legislation. Under the Selection Committee arrangements, growers will now have a major influence on the nomination of members with special qualifications, as well as grower member nominations. There is also a formal link between the AWB and the AWF through the consultative mechanism provided for in the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 giving growers the opportunity to be fully informed on Board policies. To avoid conflicts of interest which could arise, the Government does not intend to appoint a serving President of the AWF to the Board of the AWB. It is also open to the AWF as the representative of growers to make representations to me on any matter affecting Board membership and policy.

The Board has a State based grower majority under the Government's proposals. What we want is a balance of skills such that the Board has appropriate expertise to provide overall direction to Board staff so that commercial advantage is maximised and risks minimised. The potential for error is great and we wish to reduce risk in the growers interests. The Government could not accept a Board comprising two grower members from each mainland State because of the struc- tural imbalance which it could impart to the Board. The Board size would militate against it acting in a corporate manner and hence reduce the effectiveness of decision-making.

The advantages of having four members with special qualifications on the Board become apparent from a consideration of the size and scope of the Board's major functions of marketing and finance. The Board's annual report for 1983-84 which I tabled recently records revenue from wheat sales during that year of $2.67 billion, making it a major commercial marketing entity by any standard. The Board faces significant marketing challenges in disposing of the record crops of recent years and it is obvious that it will continue to be faced with major challenges in the years ahead. Against long term average wheat crops of 15 million tonnes, AWB receivals in 1983-84 and 1984-85 of around 22 million and 18.5 million tonnes respectively were the largest crops received by the Board. Eighty per cent of Australian wheat production is sold on overseas markets which are depressed by surplus stocks held by major producers such as the United States of America and the European Economic Community. World wheat prices have declined in real terms. Predatory credit and marketing practices of major overseas competitors increase the marketing difficulties faced by the AWB.

While supplies of wheat are in excess, demand from traditional purchasers of Australian wheat has declined. China has reduced its purchases because of its increasing degree of grain self-sufficiency and has not renewed a long term agreement which expired last year. Sales to the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics are down considerably on last year with increasing emphasis being placed by USSR negotiators on countertrade.

The AWB is called on to make decisions on a day to day basis on the price, timing and conditions of sale for wheat, having regard to the high cost of storing and financing unsold wheat. Sound commercial judgment borne of extensive high level experience is necessary at the Board level to guide management in its marketing task. Under the Wheat Marketing Act 1984, the AWB is required to make advance payments to growers of a guaranteed minimum price. Grower payments for handling, storage and freight and all AWB costs are met by borrowings which are repaid by sales receipts over time. During 1983-84, the AWB borrowed and rolled over on short term domestic and international commercial money markets in excess of $6.5 billion. The AWB's borrowings involve the establishment of domestic and overseas funding facilities totalling over $4 billion to cover the current season's payments and to service outstanding debt on wheat of previous seasons. Negotiations with the international financial institutions concerned may directly involve Board members. It is essential that adequate provision be made at the Board level to ensure continuity of expertise.

The floating of the Australian dollar has added further emphasis to the importance of currency risk management to an organisation such as the AWB. The financial difficulties experienced by the Queensland Graingrowers Association due principally to exchange losses, should serve as a reminder in this regard. Also, trading decisions on the currency, interest rate and futures markets in which the AWB is empowered to operate, have significant implications for grower returns and the Government's underwriting liability. As well as ensuring that the AWB Board has an appropriate balance of skills, growers and Government can only be confident that their interests are being protected if the best available persons are appointed to those positions.

I regard the Selection Committee as a vital element in efforts to ensure that the most effective Board is appointed. The Committee will have an independent Presiding Member and the power to engage staff and consultants to assist it in its task. It will determine selection criteria against which the Committee can objectively assess the suitability of prospective appointees and which must be addressed by the Committee before it puts forward its nominations. It will be critical to ensure that conflicts of interest do not arise. I realise that the grower organisations have an agro-political problem in respect of the Committee. This was best exemplified by the fact that the AWF wanted up to 26 different growers to be involved in the selection of nine people on the Board. Another proposal involved about 50 people to select nine people. I know that the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation are critical of all governments for excessive bureaucracy, but having 50 people to pick nine or 26 to pick nine is going just a bit too far. But the Government is not so concerned for the problems of individual agro-politicians as it is about the interest of individual wheat growers, the industry generally and the public interest.

The Committee will operate in a similar manner to the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee. Costs, estimated at $100,000 to select a full Board, would be met by the AWB. These additional costs could be expected to amount to less than 1c per tonne when spread over an average season's pool. In comparison to the potential costs of errors of judgment in the financing and marketing areas, the amount is inconsequential.

I turn to the other elements of the Bill which amend the current Commonwealth legislation so that it conforms with complementary State legislation with respect to provisions governing the delivery of wheat and the operation of the permit system for stockfeed wheat. The delivery provisions in the Bill are similar to those contained in the now repealed 1979 legislation to be consistent with State decisions after the passage of the current Commonwealth legislation. This will facilitate the AWB's administration of delivery provisions of the national wheat marketing arrangements. Consistency is also required in relation to the eligibility of applicants for stockfeed wheat permits. Subject to the amendment foreshadowed concerning the number of Board members with special qualifications, I believe that the provisions of the Bill relating to the AWB structure will assist the AWB effectively to meet the significant marketing and financing challenges it faces. The Bill also ensures consistency of approach with the States on matters affecting wheat receival and domestic marketing. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has made a number of important amendments to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. The first change corrects an imbalance in the proposed structure of the new Australian Wheat Board. Secondly, the criteria for selection of Board members with special expertise were considered too narrow and have been expanded. Thirdly, the Senate has given the Selection Committee clear powers to appoint alternates of Board members. Fourthly, the National Farmers Federation President is given the option of appointing his nominee to the Selection Committee. An apparent mistake in a reference to the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has also been corrected.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government proposes to reduce the number of grower members on the Wheat Board from 10 to five and appoint four members with special industry expertise. I endorse the argument advanced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that the world marketing outlook is highly competitive and changing rapidly, and that there is a case for some Board members to hold special qualifications in such areas as finance and marketing. Arguably the greatest challenge facing the Australian industry over coming years is the green revolution in Asian countries. Who would have said with any confidence a decade or two ago that India and China would today be approaching self-sufficiency in wheat?

Over recent years the Chinese Government has been progressively introducing elements of private enterprise through incentives to the farmers and the results are quite dramatic. The Chinese experience gives some emphasis to the old adage that two main forces motivate people-one is incentive and the other is fear. There is no greater engine of human propulsion than providing people with incentive. Indeed, this is why Australians could well prosper from a flat tax system. Since 1980-81 production in China has risen 48 per cent to an estimated 83 million tonnes in the 1984-85 season. This year China will import just 10 million tonnes, down almost 30 per cent over the same period. The challenges of the international market demand specialist knowledge. The Opposition concurs with the view that the Wheat Board can benefit from marketing and financial expertise.

At the same time, this Parliament should not lose sight of the need for the wheat growers to maintain control over the administration and marketing of their crop. While it is invaluable to have members on the Board with special qualifications, there can be no substitute for those who have had the direct involvement and experience in wheat growing and handling. Last financial year the wheat industry was Australia's second largest export industry. More than $2.3 billion in foreign exchange was earned from a record crop of 22 million tonnes. Many growers have expressed their concern to me about losing grower control of their marketing body under this legislation. There is great depth of feeling on this issue among the wheat growers of Australia. I believe these concerns are justified. At present 10 grower members sit on the Board of 15. The number of members on the Board was increased from 14 to 15 last October when the Minister appointed a member to represent the Commonwealth. Of the 15 members, three have been appointed on the basis of their specialist expertise.

To summarise, the present Board has a Chairman, with 10 growers, a government member and three members with special expertise. The Government intends that the Board should comprise a grower chairperson appointed by the Minister, five grower members, a government member and four members with special expertise. That is, the grower members are cut from 10 to five and members with special expertise increase from three to four. Grower members selected by growers will number five of the 11 Board members-five out of 11-whereas growers presently have 10 out of 15. It may be argued that the growers will maintain their majority on the Board because the chairperson will continue to be a grower. The limiting factor, of course, is that the Minister, not the wheat growers, appoints the chairperson. Alternatively, the argument could be that growers have a majority on the new Selection Committee. The limiting factor to this is that the people appointed will be experts in specialist fields.

The initial reaction of the industry to the move to cut producer numbers by half was one of extreme disappointment and widespread anger. Despite this, the industry has taken a very conciliatory attitude. It has accepted a reduction in the size of the Board by limiting one grower representative from each mainland State. At the same time, I am concerned, and I know that the vast majority of the industry shares this concern, that growers will no longer elect their own representatives, at least in some States, under the Government's legislation. Yet in the second reading speech the Minister was at pains to stress that he was the one relinquishing controls over marketing authorities. No matter how the Minister does his sums, the growers no longer appoint their majority on the Wheat Board. The Senate's decision to accept three Board members with special expertise does not provide a grower-selected grower majority, but rather a grower-selected grower equality.

I call on the Minister and honourable members opposite to recognise the very valid request of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation, endorsed by the Senate, by supporting the appointment of three specialists out of 10 rather than four out of 11 on the Board, as proposed by the Minister. Somewhere along the line there is some reason why there should be some negotiation on a matter of this character. It seems quite incredible that the Minister should be seeking four out of 11 rather than three out of 10, especially in view of the fact that the Wheatgrowers Federation, the representative of the wheat industry, has been prepared to have the Board numbers reduced from 15 to 10.

The Senate has also accepted amendments to the criteria for the selection of the three members who have expertise in one area. I commend the Minister for accepting some of the amendments. The reference to finance and marketing is retained, but industrial relations is expanded under the amendment to incorporate the wider problems of handling and transportation under a new category, grain movement logistics. Other amendments have clarified the powers of the Selection Committee to appoint alternatives to Board members and changed a reference from the Australian Wheatgrowers Association to Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. A further amendment, to sub-section 33I (1), gives the National Farmers Federation President the option to nominate someone in his place to sit on the Selection Committee. Under the Bill in its previous form the President had no option but to sit on the Committee and it is most unfortunate that the Government did not adequately consult with him before inserting that provision in the Bill.

The Opposition proposes to move an amendment in this House relating to the composition of the Selection Committee to improve further the voice of the growers in administration of the Wheat Board. This provision is sought by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and its constituent organisations. The Bill allows for a Committee of nine, made up of a presiding member, selected by the Minister, the Board Chairman, the National Farmers Federation President or his nominee, and one other NFF nominee, and five wheatgrowers nominated by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation.

My amendment retains the basic elements of the Selection Committee, but divides the five wheat grower members into two groups to perform the two quite separate functions of the Committee-to select the grower member of the Board from each State and to select the members with special expertise.

There is a very good reason for introducing these changes, and the extra costs to the Board resulting from the changes would be minimal. Certainly, the longer term benefits would outweigh any such costs. The Opposition proposes, firstly, that in selecting those Board members with special expertise the Committee remain as constituted under this Bill, that is, with five AWF nominees. For the purpose of selecting the Board's grower member from each State, these five Federation nominees would be replaced by five nominees from the Federation's individual State affiliates. In the case of New South Wales, for example, the State grower member would be selected by a committee which includes five nominees of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales.

As the Minister has stated, the Board deals with grower finances of up to $3 billion every year. It does not seem too much to be asking for each State to have a majority say in the appointment of its Board member. The Australian wheat industry is spread over a vast continent, and there will always be regional considerations in decisions affecting the national industry. It is unfortunate that the Australian Democrats have not joined the coalition parties on this proposal, although they have taken a commendable stand on the other matters I have raised.

Beyond these amendments, there is a further matter on which I would seek the Minister's response. In the second reading speech by the Minister's representative in the other place, we were told that the Minister will determine-and the emphasis is on 'will determine'-selection criteria against which the Committee can assess the suitability of applicants. I prefer the interpretation set out in clause 10, page 4, line 10 of the Bill, which states that the Minister may determine these criteria. It would be helpful if the Minister could clarify this apparent contradiction of terms.

To understand the importance of the Opposition's amendments it is necessary to understand the marketing framework in which Australia's 60,000 wheat growers participate. In 1983-84, $2.3 billion, or 88 per cent, of total earnings were drawn from international markets on the basis of figures recently presented in the Board's annual report. It is to the industry's great credit that this result has been achieved in spite of fast rising costs of production and a general decline in farmers' terms of trade.

It is a result achieved without significant protection. While the manufacturing sector continues to enjoy an average rate of effective protection of 25 per cent, wheat growers operate in an environment of negative to about plus 5 per cent protection. The protection rate has been negative for about half the past decade. Therefore, let no one say that the rural industries are propped up by the generosity of other sectors of the economy. Not only has the wheat industry enjoyed little or no protection, but also it has competed on an extremely vigorous world market. As I have said, China and India are moving towards self-sufficiency. World wheat production has increased by 50 per cent in just 15 years. An efficient, aggressive Wheat Board is vital, not only to the industry, but for all Australians.

So far in 1984-85, the current account deficit is $7.6 billion, which is $3 billion more than in the corresponding period last year. For the full year 1984-85, the current account deficit is expected to be about $11 billion, which is 30 per cent higher than for last year and 50 per cent higher than for 1983-84. Over 20 per cent of export revenue-over double the amount earned from wheat exports-will be required just to pay the interest on the foreign debt alone.

To recover some of our economic lost ground, our nation must dramatically increase its export earning capacity. Rural industries, earning an average $8 export income for every $1 spent on rural imports, are a key element in this recovery. For wheat, as with so many other primary industries, the first step must be to raise our international competitiveness. In particular, we must focus on lowering farm costs, raising productivity even further than its already high levels, gaining access to the latest technology and developing efficient service industries including storage, handling, shipping and finance. I know that the Minister has placed a lot of emphasis on each one of those factors and I think he deserves some credit for it because they are the areas that must be concentrated on in the years ahead if this industry is to stay abreast of other producing countries. Clearly, Australia is a price taker on the world market with about a 14 per cent share of exports. We must look in the first instance to what we can do for ourselves to improve our competitive position.

Only a fortnight ago another snap meeting of primary producers was called at Moree, one of the major wheat growing centres in my electorate of Gwydir, to express concern regarding government policies. It is yet another pointer to the increasing unrest among primary producers. This Government has done nothing about the concerns raised by the National Farmers Federation at the farm costs summit. It was a dismal failure. Great expectations were built up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the election campaign about this farm costs summit, and frankly is was a disappointing fizzer. It met on two occasions but argued about the basis on which the National Farmers Federation had established the actual cost of protection that was being transferred to each family farm. Summit is hardly the word now that producers are sliding further down the slippery slope of declining terms of trade.

Fuel costs were allowed to increase by 10 per cent within days of the last so-called summit. In the wake of devaluation, other costs are certain to rise, but are less likely to fall again if the dollar recovers. No industry is more affected by the price of fuel than the wheat industry. Since the Hawke Government came to office, fuel excise has risen by 56.6 per cent and fuel costs generally by 32.5 per cent. Then, of course, more recently country people, except those in extremely remote areas-have lost the benefit of the fuel freight subsidy-up to another 4c a litre. It is interesting to note that in the wheat growing belt in the Gwydir electorate, an electorate that I have the privilege to represent, every centre that has a subsidy on its freight for fuel has lost that subsidy as a result of the mini-Budget last week. The industry has been diddled with the reintroduction of the fuel excise rebate for off-road use. The Hawke Labor Government froze the off-road excise rebate for farmers in its 1983 Budget and of course caused an uproar. Since 1983 there has been a gap between the amount of excise and the level of rebate available to off-road users such as farmers, miners and foresters.

In a sneaky fashion in 1983 the Hawke Labor Government increased the excise by 1.5c a litre and made it subject to automatic six-monthly indexed increases, but cunningly left the rebate unadjusted at 7.155c per litre for 18 months. The cost to farmers is estimated to be of the order of somewhere between $20m and $25m but worse still the gap has widened from the original 1.5c a litre because of the indexing of the excise. Today the gap is 2.3c a litre. Indeed, unless altered, the gap will continue to widen. We will seek to amend other legislation shortly to undo this sneaky travesty of justice.

The other incredible injustice to wheat growers and country dwellers generally emerged in this week's mini-Budget where the fuel freight subsidy has been abolished, as I said earlier. The removal will add up to another 4c a litre on fuel costs, which is the third rise in fuel costs in two months. One would hope Labor members representing rural seats will screw the arms of their anti-rural mates to accept our amendments.

This Government cannot even see its way clear to take the most obvious step to help the wheat growers, which is to abandon that wretched harvester tariff and replace it with an equally effective bounty costing 86 per cent less than the tariff. Another effect of tariffs and quotas on essential farm inputs-such as grain harvesters, farm machines, and chemicals for which there are no realistic substitutes-and sales taxes on other inputs, is to raise the price of those inputs to Australian farmers above world prices and consequently, to reduce our international competitiveness and farm profitability. Despite the Government's failure to date to take up these concerns of wheat growers, the industry remains willing to increase its contribution to research programs in order to help raise this competitiveness level.

I note that the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation presently has before the Minister a submission for an increase in the wheat research tax from 30c to 35c per tonne for the 1985-86 harvest. Here is a fine example of primary industries' self-help approach. Let us hope that the Government can respond to this request by the growers, by allowing them to raise their own contribution of $4.7m in 1984-85 towards their industry research programs.

It is clear that the new Board should have a balance of expertise to confront the marketing challenges ahead. However, let there be no illusion. The coming years are going to be the most challenging ever faced by the Australian wheat growers. I think it is essential therefore to have a situation where they are able to appoint their own representatives and it is essential for them to have majority control. Not only has the green revolution arrived, but European Economic Community exports have quadrupled in seven years-now outranking Australia-and there are strong fears that subsidised credit to United States producers will also increase the pressure on Australia's export market shares. Recent changes, such as the granting to the Board of power to borrow overseas to finance the guaranteed minimum price show the need for ongoing expertise in specialist areas at the Board level. Of greater importance, however, is that the growers should maintain control over their statutory marketing authority.

The Opposition believes that the amendments it is advancing will further enhance the changes made by the Senate and will work in the best interests of the industry. We hope the Government will give a positive and constructive response to the Opposition's and the Democrat's endeavours on behalf of the Australian wheat growers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985 I must say that I always find myself a little astounded at the great love for bureaucracy which seems to emanate from the rural socialists on the other side of the House. I think it is self-evident to any thinking person that if one is to get efficiency in an organisation one really has to have a tighter organisation. I believe that anyone who attended the rural outlook conference in Canberra in January would have been concerned at the performance of the wheat seminar. I think that this was in stark contrast with the great professionalism that was exhibited by the Australian Wool Corporation. The attitude seemed to be-I think I can paraphrase the Chairman pretty accurately-one of: 'We have always sold the wheat in the past and if the growers produce the wheat we will sell it in the future'. Things are changing and they are changing very dramatically.
—Are you attacking the Chairman of the Wheat Board?

—I am saying to the wheat growers of Australia that they desperately need expertise. The job of wheat growers is to grow wheat as efficiently as possible. They need all the expertise that they can get to help them in this area. It is not just in the areas of finance and marketing that they need expertise. They need expertise in the areas of industrial relations, transport and co-ordination. Perhaps they need someone with expertise in barter trading, in respect of which the Australian Wheat Board has not had any experience so far.

SPEECH.PARA: The wheat harvest had a gross value of just over $3 billion. Of that amount about $1 billion was used up in transport. This is a substantial amount. I am sure that there is room for a reduction somewhere in that bill. It is interesting to note that the only State that has had a reduction in real terms in the cost of transport of wheat has been Western Australia under the dynamic leadership of Julian Grill, the Western Australian Minister for Transport. It is also worth noting that Western Australia is, of course, a Labor State.

Co-ordination is another area in which I think there is a lot of room for consideration. We hear a lot of talk from the Opposition about the high cost of tariffs. Of course tariffs are a very high cost and no one argues against that. One must look at tariffs in a historical context and just remember who institutionalised them. Of course, it was the National Party of Australia. The National Party bequeathed to the Australian farmer the very high cost of production that he has today. This cost was hidden for many years by the very high returns that wheat growers were getting. I would say that since those days the terms of trade have continued to run against wheat farmers.

I would suggest that if we had a co-ordinated approach across the whole of Australia, there would be many things that the various wheat handling authorities could buy as a body to reduce cost. Just consider the number of front-end loaders that are used across Australia to handle the wheat crop. The number must run into hundreds. If they were bought on a uniform basis one would have a chance to go to Australian industry and say: 'Here is a product we want. We will give you this contract. Produce them for us at a competitive price'. Until we have in Australia industries which are competitive, we have no hope of dismantling tariffs on inefficient industries. Honourable members opposite can sit there and lament the mistakes that they have made until they are blue in the face, but until we have in this country a situation in which we have industries employing people and taking the place of those inefficient industries nothing will or can happen. It is interesting to note that the only Government which ever tried to do something about that was pilloried and crucified by honourable members opposite. This is something which is remembered by the thinking farmers in the community.

I turn to barter trading. I am sure that there are countries to which we could substantially increase our sales of wheat if we were prepared to take something from them. For instance, Yugoslavia makes under licence a very good Cummins diesel engine which it cannot sell in Australia because of a licensing arrangement. But if Australia could purchase these diesel engines the cost of truck production in Australia would be substantially reduced. This would be of benefit to farmers. The money that we paid the Yugoslavs for the purchase of these engines would flow straight back to Australia in enhanced trade. I think that we will have to look at those areas because we are entering into a very difficult market situation.

One of the other areas with which I must say I find myself very disappointed is the lack of productivity increases in wheat farming. We are just not getting the increases per acre that other countries achieve. There is no doubt that we do not get sufficient rainfall to produce massive increases. However, it is interesting to note that this year, for the first time ever in Australia, a 10-tonne per hectare crop was grown in Tasmania. That crop was grown on heavy clay soil which the local experts said was unsuitable. A farmer grew that crop with expertise directly imported from the United Kingdom. I think this foreshadows a change that is going to take place in Australia. It is a change with which the industry must come to grips. A movement from the traditional grain growing areas to the higher rainfall areas will have a traumatic effect on the wheat industry generally. If that is where productivity can be achieved, that is inevitably what will happen. It may be that we should have another look at plant variety rights. Maybe this is the way in which to improve productivity. All I am saying is that our record to date in this area is not good.

Another area that should be looked at is the cost of fuel. There is no doubt that fuel costs are high. I am aware of that because my electorate is probably affected more than any other electorate. I was instrumental in getting incorporated in the Labour Party's policy the fact that fuel produced on the farm would not be taxed by a Labor government. In the United States of America ethyl alcohol based fuels are produced in large quantities at less than 20c a litre, which represents a dramatic reduction in cost. The farmers of Australia may not need actually to produce this product. If they go to the Government and say 'we have done the research and this is our intention' they would be in a much better position to negotiate some deal in respect of a reduction in fuel costs. I would have thought that such an initiative would be self-evident and could be taken. It is a matter about which I have recently written to the Primary Industry Association of Western Australia (Inc).

Another problem that I see is with the mishmash of misinformations that is provided by many honourable members opposite. Members of the Opposition lament the high cost that farmers face. Of course costs constitute a real problem for farmers. The fact is that the cost of production last year rose by 6 per cent. Certainly, this significant rise cannot be sustained. However, it is half the average rate of the last 10 years. I would just like to read the figures into Hansard. The rate of increase in the price of farm inputs for 1984-85 is approximately 6 per cent, compared with an average rate of increase of 12.6 per cent experienced in the previous six years.

The single most important step which the Government can take to help the rural sector is to manage the domestic economy effectively. This view is shared by the National Farmers Federation. The Government has been successful in this approach through such key policies as budgetary restraint and the prices and incomes accord. As a result, inflation has fallen from 11.5 per cent in 1982-83 to 5.1 per cent in the calendar year 1984. These figures are significant and all farmers will tell us how they are affected by these factors. There is no doubt that this Government has done much better than its predecessor did in this regard. There is no doubt that in the long run it is only a healthy economy that is going to make farming a viable industry.

The devaluation of the Australian dollar has been very significant. It is this which has put a windfall gain into the pockets of farmers this year. Whilst we are applauded by some of the people opposite for this initiative, it is an initiative which they themselves were never prepared to take. I think it is recognised in Australia that we as a government are doing what is necessary. We are clearing the way and reducing bureaucratic interference to make it that much easier for farmers to survive in very difficult circumstances.

Let us take the cost of superphosphate, a significant input. In 1977, the cost of a tonne of superphosphate as a percentage of the cost of a tonne of wheat was more than its cost against the first advance received last year. Yet honourable members opposite will interpret that fact by looking at the rise in the price of superphosphate in money terms and lamenting the difference. Most farmers, certainly thinking farmers, realise the facts but, of course, for many it is much easier to pick up the rhetoric of those opposite who purport to represent people in the country.

One of the great dilemmas of this country-I have said this many times-is that Australia is a very urban place. The great majority of the population-about 92 per cent-lives in the cities, and there is bound to be a slanting towards the interests of city people. That slanting applies across the entire political spectrum. I believe that that is something that must be addressed, but it is not helped by the mindless rhetoric put forward by some of the people who sit opposite. I believe that it should be self-evident to anyone that there will not be any dramatic reduction in unemployment in this country unless there is a visible manufacturing sector. The trick is to make that sector self-sufficient and competitive in world terms, which means that we have to look at some of the new industries. I believe that without these there is no hope. Without these, I believe, there will be enormous and continuing pressure from the cities to increase costs. That, I am afraid, is a road down which the Argentine went and it is a road which I have no desire to follow. I ask members of the Opposition to take this risk very seriously and to try to be more constructive in their attitude and a little more honest in their interpretation of history. Then, hopefully, we will together be able to do something to enhance the viability of farming for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to start my remarks on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill by taking up a point that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) made in his rejection of the amendments passed by the Senate. He mentioned that the structure he has proposed for the new Australian Wheat Board would be similar to or the same as that of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Possibly, he proposes to have the same number of people on the Board but apart from that there are certainly some very major differences. I will point out a couple of them. There will certainly be no representation from each State on the Meat and Live-stock Corporation and one of the 11 members of the Board of that Corporation will be the Managing Director, who is selected by the Board but appointed by the Minister. So there is quite a difference between the two bodies. I hope that the Minister will recognise that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is still here in the House. I guess that he is used to being the lone voice in the wilderness. On this occasion he was the lone back bencher in the House listening to his speech. While I agreed with some of the points that he made, I was interested to hear him talk about government bureaucracy. The whole point of the Opposition's amendment is to reduce the size of the Board, so I do not see how he can talk about our increasing the bureaucracy. The honourable member complained about the lack of increase in production per acre in the wheat fields over the last few decades. I must admit that I agree with him but I also take up a point that he did not touch on, that is, that we do not have plant variety rights in Australia. I know that plant variety rights in respect of wheat may be a long way down the track even if other agricultural industries get them. Nonetheless, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has raised a very important point. I hope that the Government and the Minister in particular will speed up the review of this industry. We seem to have one committee after another thinking about plant variety rights. When one comes up with a recommendation that recommendation goes to another committee for consideration. The whole matter is becoming quite a farce. The initial plant variety rights legislation was put on the table in 1981 or 1982, and we still do not have it in its final form.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie also spoke about farmers in the United States of America producing farm fuel for around 20c a litre. I must admit that I am amazed at that figure. I would be very interested to see how they do it. On most of the figures I have seen-I must admit that they were produced a couple of years ago-it was costing United States farmers 60c to 70c a litre, and as that was some years ago, I dare say that with the effects of inflation and so on the cost would be even greater. But, if the honourable member can find that solution, I think that every farmer in Australia will be rushing in to make his own fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a greater cost problem than we have.

—Exactly. I thank the honourable member for Mallee. In speaking to this Bill tonight, I wish to reinforce a few of the points already covered by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt). I think he has covered the whole ambit of the industry very well. I just remind the House that over 80 per cent of production from the wheat industry is exported. Wheat is the second largest export earner in Australia and it is expected that the value of exports this year will be in excess of $2.7 billion, which is over 20 per cent of our export earnings. There is no question about the wheat industry being an efficient industry. The February 1984 Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, put out by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Wheat production-
that is in Australia-

is one of the most efficient of all Australian industries. The level of assistance to the industry in recent years has been low (or even negative) and, except in occasional years of drought, the industry has continued to grow-

This is a very significant point. It is important to remember that fact, especially in light of the fact that the current prices being received on the world export markets are, to put it mildly, fairly low. In fact, wheat prices have increased in real terms by only about 2 per cent per year over the last five years. It is interesting to compare that figure with the rise in farmers' cost. If we look at the terms of trade, that is, the ratio of prices paid to prices received we see that farmers' terms of trade have declined by 20 per cent over the same period.
As to the outlook for wheat, the Bureau of Agricultural Economic paper presented to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference in January this year stated quite clearly:
World prices are expected to ease again by the middle of 1985.

In other words, the outlook for wheat is very ordinary, working from a fairly ordinary level of prices. The problem facing wheat is a farm cost problem. I have already mentioned the fact that over the last five years there has been a decline of 20 per cent in farmers' terms of trade. I think it is important to note that some constructive suggestions have been put forward on how farm costs can be reduced. I refer to the National Farmers Federation submission to the Government on farm costs. We have already touched on the efficiency of the wheat industry. It is interesting to note that the National Farmers Federation, in its revised figures, is still talking of protection levels to secondary industry costing every farmer $9,000 per annum.

The farm cost submission goes on to talk about specific ways of cutting these costs. One that it touches on in particular is fuel costs. Let us look at what has happened to the prices of fuel over the last month or so. First of all we have seen the effects of the devaluation and then, to top it all off, we have seen the Government removing the freight equalisation subsidy, which means that fuel costs in country areas will rise by up to 4c a litre. When we look at the way in which the Government very kindly removed the diesel fuel rebate for off-road users and then reimposed it without indexing it for three or four months, we realise that farmers now pay a hidden tax over and above all the others of over $25m a year, representing the difference between the road price of fuel and the cost that should apply if the fuel rebate were returned to off-road users.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie touched on freight and handling. There is no doubt that there is considerable room for improvement in efficiency and costs. I hope that the new Wheat Board, when it gets a right structure, will put more emphasis on trying to solve that problem. But in talking of the costs to farmers of protection and in particular of returns and levels of efficiency, I would be interested to read a short section of a speech. I think that the House may find this very enlightening. It states:

. . . the overall level of assistance to rural industries is low by comparison with other sectors. A comparison of figures for 1981-82, the latest year for which comparable IAC figures are available, indicates that primary industry assistance is 9 per cent compared to 26 per cent for secondary industries.
The speech continues to talk about discussions between the Government and the National Farmers Federation on farm costs. This is the part of the speech that is extremely important:

. . . while there has not been agreement on the extent of this cost impost it is in the order of $6,000 to $9,000 per farm each year. This is significant given that average income per unit of family farm labour in 1983-84 has been estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at only $7,000 per year.
In other words, depending on which level of figures one takes, support to secondary industry could cost each farmer more than he is getting in income each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will get less now with the assets test.

—The assets test is an added problem. I commend the Minister for Primary Industry for this statement. It is a very frank statement and I hope that many of his colleagues will read it. It provides a stark assessment of what is happening in primary industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to the level of government involvement. It is very important for all honourable members to realise that although the Wheat Board is a statutory marketing authority and the Government provides 95 per cent underwriting of the guaranteed minimum price-that level of underwriting being worked out on the estimated market returns for the current year plus the returns in the two lowest years of the last three years-to date the Government has never had to pay out on its underwriting. That is a most important point. As I have said, the wheat industry is efficient. It has government underwriting, but that costs the Government nothing. However, it provides the industry with a considerable benefit. It provides security for the Wheat Board in its borrowing requirements for the first advance. With that sort of security the Wheat Board is able to obtain better terms and better rates.

In the light of all these points, the question has to be asked of the Minister: Why is he so keen to take away grower control of the Australian Wheat Board? After all, the Board is grower funded; the industry is self-sufficient and it is not costing the Government anything-certainly not so far as the Board itself is concerned. There is grower involvement in the direct marketing of the industry. I hasten to point out to the Minister that the Opposition amendments still allow for three specialist members with the sort of expertise for which the Government is looking and which the industry would welcome. In fact, it already has it now. I suggest that if the Government is serious about helping the wheat industry, it should look at farm costs. I have touched on some of these costs, including fuel and freight. The major matter of which we keep reminding the Minister, but he appears to be rather deaf on this aspect, is the cost of wages. While he is keen to deregulate some sections of industry and to talk about deregulation of financial markets and the floating of the Australian dollar, we hear a deathly silence on the subject of deregulating wage costs.

I note that the Minister is again saying that he will not accept the Opposition's amendments. I wonder what his reaction will be this time in the light of his reactions on the previous occasion when the Opposition decided not to accept the Government's structure for the Wheat Board. I refer to the speech made by the Minister on 4 October last year, when he said:
But I remind the Opposition that this is a package of legislation and if it is held up growers will not be paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blackmail.

—I agree that was a form of blackmail. I wonder whether the Minister will threaten us again? Will he threaten the industry again as he was prepared to do on that occasion? Finally, I ask the Minister to accept the Opposition's amendments which were passed by the Senate. All the industry is asking for is grower control and I do not believe in the light of what I have said already that it is an unreasonable request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate, albeit briefly, in the debate on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. In the few comments I intend to make I wish to pick up a few points made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I felt it unjust of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie to accuse either the Liberal Party or the National Party of participating in this debate in defence of the Australian Wheat Board. My intention tonight is not to defend the Wheat Board but the wheat growers. I take up the excellent point made by the honourable member for Wannon. The cruel reality for wheat growers across Australia is that they have seen a real increase in the price of their product of little more than 2 per cent for the last five years. No other industry in Australia has been asked to wear that sort of product price increase in the face of rising prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Some employees use productivity gains as a means of assessing what their increase in wages should be. If the wheat growers of Australia were to make that calculation over some decades, we would discover that they currently should have wealth to rival the oil cartels of the Middle East. This is an industry in which growers have been prepared to put all into increasing their productivity. We have seen extensive wheat breeding programs, the astute application of fertiliser to enable the Australian wheat industry to grow and be more productive. It is easy, as all the farmers on this side of the House know, in the first two years after one has cleared a virgin patch to produce good crops, but it is in the succeeding years when the available nitrogen has been leached from those soils that it calls for great expertise to produce the crops one desires. It has been the capacity of Australian farmers to learn how to live with changed crop rotations, how to minimise nematode damage, how to maximise the plants available to them under the very minimal plant variety rights scheme we have in this country under the present wheat breeding program that has allowed them to keep up productivity increases.

It is this same industry that has become increasingly productive in the face of successive droughts. It is this same industry that has been increasingly productive in the face of fluctuating seasons and all the unpredictability that characterises rural industry. This industry has lifted Australia out of the depths of our last depression. The industry has not been antagonistic to the Hawke Government. In fact, the industry has been remarkably forgiving of the Hawke Government in the light of the way that Government has attacked it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about fuel prices?

—The Government may not have intended directly to attack the industry but the result of being governed by a group of urbanised legislators is that what is most needed by rural industry is often forgotten. Under this Government we are faced with not only spiralling government costs and charges but also a prominence of government, an increase in the size of government. As the honourable member for Wannon said, we have faced increases in fuel prices so dramatic that in some areas the cost of fuel has risen by 12c a litre since the last sowing season.
—How much?

—Up to 12c a litre-sufficient to make wheat growers hesitate to plant an additional area, particularly if they are borrowing the money to buy the fuel needed to plant that area. Tonight I say to the Government that this legislation is part of the frustration the Government is currently heaping on the wheat growers of Australia. If the Government chooses to ignore the amendments which will be introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) that will be a further slight to the wheat growers of Australia. The wheat growers are not being immovably stubborn in their approach to the Government. As I said earlier, they have been exceedingly gracious. The Government, by this legislation, implies that the wheat growers cannot look after their own affairs. The Government, in fact, implies that if the Board's operations are handed over to the accountants, the economists, the computer professionals and the marketing and advertising tycoons the Wheat Board will be better run. We say that the Government really ought to be better aware of the simple fact that the farmers of Australia are already running multi-million dollar businesses. Those farmers who are the survivors in 1985 and who have continued to farm in the face of all the difficulties of the drought years are already running multi-million dollar businesses and making multi-million dollar decisions. Those farmers have already agreed to deny themselves luxuries the rest of Australia takes for granted in order to be more productive. They are the farmers who know what it costs to gear up with the machinery that is needed to be productive in grain terms in Australia today. They are the people who know that in order to run their farms effectively they have to be prepared to buy in advice.

SPEECH.PARA: So the honourable member for Gwydir has appealed, and I support his appeal for the Board's structure to be so amended that the Board will be made up of three specialists out of 10 rather than four specialists out of 11. The Board will buy in the advice it needs to market the crop it has at its disposal. Furthermore, the honourable member for Gwydir has said that we need to expand the area of expertise to include not only finance and marketing but also grain movement logistics. I cannot too strongly support his stand in this area. What was it that so threatened the New South Wales wheat crop in the last harvest? It was the incapacity to move the grain as readily as it ought to be moved. The April 1985 issue of Australian Transport made this statement:
Land transport ranks third behind production and shipping as the major cost to the grower.

We need to recognise the enormous burden we will place on our wheat growers unless we are prepared to look at the land transport logistics we have in those areas of Australia where they are not as efficient as they ought to be. Furthermore, the honourable member for Gwydir on behalf of the Opposition has appealed for some greater flexibility in the composition of the Selection Committee. In fact, we have called for the appointment on the Selection Committee of five members from a State affiliate of the National Farmers Federation. Why did the honourable member make this appeal? Simply, it recognises that there are vast differences between the States, a fact that ought to be self-evident to the Government, a fact which is conspicuously apparent to everyone on this side of the House. Australia is a vast continent. There are enormous differences in the wheat producing areas. For example, the 10-year average of wheat grown in New South Wales is five million tonnes per annum. The 10-year average of wheat grown in Queensland is one million tonnes per annum.

Because of the time constraints I do not wish to pursue the arguments I had originally intended to pursue, but I want to restate my point: The Opposition is tonight not defending the Wheat Board but expressing a vote of confidence in the capacity of the wheat growers of Australia to continue to manage their business ably, just as they have done in the past. They have been prepared to accept reduced representation on the Wheat Board. They simply seek the right to manage a board successfully, just as they are currently successfully managing their farms in the face of rising costs and falling farm incomes. This Government has been of no help to the wheat farmers of Australia. As the honourable member for Wannon skillfully outlined, we have seen cruel rises in fuel prices. We are seeing the farmers currently being denied plant variety rights. Yet, they continue to be successful. We want to see that sort of success have a majority voice on any future Wheat Board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments to be moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), which were so ably supported by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I recognise the value of the need to introduce a board to oversee Australia's wheat industry, a board that is smaller and quite possibly more manageable than the present Australian Wheat Board. However, I do not agree with the outcome of this change being made by the Government, which will, in effect, see the wheat growers of Australia lose control of the Board that manages their industry and their livelihoods. For this reason I support the proposed amendments because they will effectively restore control of the Board into the hands of the wheat growers.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments will still allow the Board to acquire the necessary expertise to manage such a large and important industry as the wheat industry. There is no doubting the argument that expertise is required on the Board. Certainly any industry that has a turnover of approximately $3 billion a year needs expertise. To deny wheat growers the ability to control their industry and, indeed, their livelihoods is just not acceptable. The appointed experts do not have the same accountability to the industry as do grower representatives. Grower representatives have not only a deep personal interest in the industry but also a far more first hand knowledge of its problems and needs than any appointed expert could ever hope to have. To take away from the Wheat Board the elected grower control would be to take away the accountability to the industry of that Board and, indeed, its members. It would run completely against the grain of the whole system of our democracy. If we as the elected representatives of the people to this Parliament found that we were not in the majority in the Parliament, not only would we be justly upset but the people whom we are elected to represent would also be justly upset.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are now.

—That is right; they are. These amendments help to overcome that anomaly and yet still allow sufficient expertise to be made available to the Board. If the Bill goes through this House without these amendments being accepted the wheat growers will have received yet another slap in the face from this Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the Government's track record in the wheat industry one can see that, indeed, it is a very sorry record. Let us just look at what has happened in the two years and a few months in which this Government has been in power. We have seen the price of fuel increase dramatically. It has increased by nearly 11c or 12c a litre in recent months. The price of fuel is a very important component of the wheat industry. Farmers are greatly affected by the cost of fuel and price increases take away their profitability. The Government has cut the 100 per cent depreciation on farm fuel storage. It has imposed a 15 per cent rise in tariffs on imported grain harvesters. To give a quick example of the effect that has had, two years ago a grain harvester was worth about $92,000. By the end of this year it will be worth about $165,000. The Government has reduced depreciation allowances. It has removed sales tax exemptions for oils and lubricants. It has cut the investment allowance.

The Government's so-called farm cost summit was a complete sham. The arguments were ignored. The farm cost summit was purely and simply a political ploy used by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and members of the Labor Party during the recent election to try to curry favour with the rural sector, and it was shown in its true light in recent weeks when it completely and utterly collapsed. The Government is now wrecking any advantages to be gained from the devaluation of the Australian dollar by not discounting wage rises brought on by the devalued dollar. A lot is heard from the Government about how the depreciated dollar will advantage wheat growers, but that advantage is quickly being lost by the rise in the cost of fuel and of wages which will flow on through the various sectors of the inputs that farmers have to pay for.

Of course, real interest rates are now higher than they have ever been. This was the subject of a matter of public importance so ably put by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in the House this afternoon. Real interest rates are at their highest level for the last 50 years. Real interest rates and interest rates in general are a most important cost component for farmers because farming produces once a year income. Farmers have to borrow money to keep going and, therefore, interest rates are very important to farmers. Yet we now have the highest real interest rates for a long time. Of course, the industrial disputation that has gone on in recent months is costing the farmers of this nation a fortune, not only directly by ships being left off our harbours without being able to receive deliveries of wheat but also indirectly by reducing Australia's reputation as a reliable exporter of primary products. That is where the real cost to our farming community will be seen in the future. That cost, while intangible, will be very real in future years.

The list of what has gone wrong under this Government for the farming sector, the wheat industry in particular, goes on and on. All these disasters would be made a little more bearable if the price of wheat had gone up by a substantial amount but, as has been already put quite adequately tonight, the price of wheat has gone up by only 2 per cent over the last five years, and who on earth would accept that sort of rise with the sorts of cost increases we have experienced under the Hawke Labor Government? The reason it has not risen more is that the wheat industry is a price taker, not a price setter. For this very reason what this Government has done for the Australian wheat industry can be described only as a disaster, because the Government has increased the cost of production by its bungling, thus reducing wheat growers' chances of making a profit on their wheat to pay for the other overheads associated with running a farm.

Because the wheat grower is a price taker, it is now even more important that growers have control over the Board that manages their industry. The Australian Wheat Board, in managing the industry's affairs, has great influence over the industry's costs of production. No person or even group of people can be more aware of the need to control costs of production than those people whose incomes and livelihoods depend upon controlling those costs. Mr Graham Peart, a highly regarded agricultural consultant, estimated in an article in the Land in September last year that wheat growers would be left with about $11 per tonne after the costs of production and government charges had been deducted. In fact, the cost of handling, storing and marketing wheat in this country has more than doubled in the last five years. Grain handling and rail freight charges now total about 40 per cent of the total cost of production. These costs of production have climbed dramatically and will continue to grow even more dramatically if the wheat growers lose control of their Board.

The wheat industry is not in great shape, contrary to what some members on the other side of this House might think. However, if the industry is properly managed by people whose interests and livelihoods depend on it, it has a great future sufficient to go part way towards redressing the current account deficit which is growing at an alarming rate. Certainly the industry has a chance of putting this country back on the credit side of the ledger. Wheat growers are a hardy lot. They have learned to cope with droughts, floods, disease and disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Government.

—They have even learned to put up with a Labor government. But they have done it all on their own. If we do not support the foreshadowed amendments we will take away the wheat growers' right to determine the course of their own industry and indeed their own destiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In earlier remarks I said that basically the wheat industry has an agro-political problem. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has just talked about controlling costs. If the wheat growers' federations and the various grower organisations had put all the effort into taking $1 billion off farm costs that they have put into keeping two people on the Australian Wheat Board they would have done the industry a lot more good. We are trying to clothe the Wheat Board with expertise and powers and to give the Board some sort of balance. The situation has changed; we have gone from the Board being financed by rural credits department funding into a highly competitive world where the Board is dealing in very sophisticated financial and marketing areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the comments from the Opposition were really about doing what the farmers want. I have said on other occasions that we cannot govern a country by doing what various groups want. Mr Gallagher wants us to do certain things. The unions want us to do certain things. The business people want us to do certain things. There comes a time when a government has to analyse the situation and take action. I remember that, with respect to the Australian Wool Corporation, poor old Sir William Gunn used to have flour pitched at him because the wool industry said that there could not be objective measurement or a restructured Wool Corporation-those sorts of changes. Now the Wool Corporation is regarded as one of the great triumphs among statutory marketing authorities. What the Government is doing for the Wheat Board is no different from what we did for the Wool Corporation. Sensible agro-politicians realise the wisdom of what the Government is doing.

We are trying to be consistent about statutory marketing authorities, taking into account also the differences between the marketing and the financing of the various commodities being handled or sold. It is almost as if honourable members opposite have forgotten the onslaught on statutory authorities by the Liberal Party. Those opposite want to sell off Trans Australia Airlines, the Australian National Line, Australian National, the Australian Telecommunications Commission and all these sorts of things. A Senate committee chaired by Peter Rae from Tasmania wanted to establish accountability and ministerial responsibility and tried to get statutory authorities better under the control of the Parliament or the industries which they served. Most of my actions in this area, whether with respect to research or marketing, have been taken to try to put growers, the people concerned, on the spot and to move away from ministerial, day to day, hands-on activities. That is what we are all about.

Really there is a need for balance on the Board. It still has a grower majority. There is a need to have a balance between the expertise on the Board and the expertise that the Board buys, as one honourable member put it. I will get on to that in a moment. The situation has changed. The old Board really had not been changed since 1946. The Opposition had let it get to such a state that there was on it a flour miller and a flour millers union representative. Because we exported flour in 1946 there was some sense in having those people on the Wheat Board. But we do not really export much flour now, and the Board has only one finance member. The problem was that more and more weight was falling on that finance member and the finance committee of three people.

With the Government wishing to be consistent with respect to its dealing with the big statutory marketing authorities, the whole problem was with the wheat industry itself because it is quite clear that there is a need for State representation. If there was to be a board of manageable size the question was whether there should be 10 members or five. It was very hard to get an in-between decision without causing all sorts of problems because if any State got two representatives, by whatever calculation or organisation of numbers we arrived at, all the rest would have wanted two. That was the basic problem. The States are involved. It was either 10 or five. The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has been put into the box seat in terms of the Selection Committee. It has to pick nine out of 11 people. I am even quite prepared to have to pick alternatives.

The Wheatgrowers Federation, with which I have negotiated over the past year, could never really get away from the numbers on the Board. It could never see that the Board is a functional body, that it needs to act corporately. I was told: 'You can't have only one from each State because if one person was away overseas that State's interests would be overlooked'. I thought that was a nonsense in terms of my reading of Board minutes. I said: 'All right, you can have five alternatives if you want them and then each State will always be represented at any Board meeting'. Now that I have offered five alternatives the Federation concern has diminished. The next thing it said was: 'If there is only one we will not be able to report back to the industry'. That is why I set up the consultative mechanism for the Wheatgrowers Federation. It is the Wheatgrowers Federation's role, I think, to be a constructive critic of the Board and to represent the growers at that level. It now has a consultative mechanism rather than virtually owning the Board.

One honourable member opposite said that of course we can always buy expertise. The big problem I face there, quite frankly, is that the Board is under the control of the Public Service Board with respect to the amount of money it can offer some of these people. Quite frankly while ever the Public Service Board does have that control we will not be able to buy the best expertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you change that?

—Why did not the honourable member's Government change it? There are problems. We are having an inquiry into it because the amount of money being offered by the very big statutory authorities is way below what can be offered in the private sector. Whereas the people opposite did not do anything about this situation, we are. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) asked about clause 10 of the Bill and referred to the fact that the word 'will' appears in my second reading speech. I draw his attention to the Bill itself and the fact that the word 'may' appears in proposed new section 33D (1) under clause 10.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman opposite raised quite a few questions which are very germane to the wheat industry. The big issue, as everyone knows, is the cost of fuel. I remind the honourable member that under the previous Government the taxation revenue on fuel went up by 300 per cent and the cost of fuel went up by between 130 to 160 per cent in the seven years of the Fraser Government. Honourable members opposite did not whinge then. Reference was made to the 2.3c a litre gap, but at least we did give that concession. Regarding the fuel freight subsidy, some members claimed that the 4c difference now in the fuel freight rate means that everyone will pay 4c more. I point out that that is simply not so. It depends on what level of fuel freight subsidy there was before.

The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) raised the matter of plant variety rights. While I might share his beliefs with respect to PVR when we talk about plant buying, as far as wheat breeding is concerned I think that those people who have concerns about PVR have a very legitimate case. At present nearly all cereal breeding is carried out publicly. We have organisations, such as the institute at Wagga, in which many people are involved in high level scientific work. If there is a problem at present with wheat breeds, it is because of the wheat breeding committees on which there is very strong grower representation. There is also the allegation that there is too much of a bread making representation on those committees. We are looking at these kinds of problems in terms of our research funding proposals.

It is not really relevant to talk about PVR so far as wheat is concerned because we have a system of varietal control and registration. Marketing and handling are in the charge of the Wheat Board and the State handling authorities. So the combined questions of varietal control and segregations mean that the wheat industry itself controls very much the breeding and all aspects of what varieties and breeds will be released on to the market. So it is in the hands of the industry. PVR, if it came in, would have to go through that same system. I could talk at length about this because recently there was one privately bred variety that could not get through the State registration system.

Some honourable members referred to yields in Europe. I point out here that most of those really high increasing yields are for feed wheat, where there is a very high level of fertilisation and high applications of chemicals due to excessive subsidisation. We could achieve that if we were going to produce rubbish wheat, but basically we go for baking quality wheats and high quality wheats at that. Of course, we have to use our fertilisers astutely, as we do.

There has been some confusion about underwriting. I think the honourable member for Wannon said that it really costs the Government nothing. With the 1983-84 crop, at one stage the Wheat Board signalled to us that there would be a a payout of $189m. Then various elements in the international scene turned around and there was not a payout. I make this point only because there is a potential all the time for a big payout. It is terribly important to get 95 per cent gross underwriting, particularly because of the changed financial and financing mechanisms, the changed requirements, put on the Wheat Board. By having a 95 per cent gross underwriting we can still have access to all the world money markets at an A1-P1, rating. That is terribly important.

The honourable member for Gilmore said that we have done nothing for the wheat industry. When we had Rural Credits Department finance, the previous Government halved the interest rate subsidy during the infamous razor gang days. By floating the currency, the Australian Government has actually given tens, if not hundreds, of millions of dollars to the wheat indusrty. More importantly, by allowing the Wheat Board to borrow overseas, we have again saved tens, if not hundreds, of millions of dollars because we can borrow at lower interest rates overseas. Those two measures alone, in terms of what this Government has done for the wheat industry, should not pass unremarked.

There are a few other matters which I could touch upon, but I think there has been a full debate. The Government is opposed to the amendments and will speak briefly on those in a moment. The Government will be moving an amendment in its own name to increase the representation, the expertise, from three back up to four. I thank honourable members for their comments. I thought that most of the comments were constructive, besides the usual level of political argy-bargy. I think that those people who represent the wheat industry in this House, or who have many wheat growers as their constituents, really do realise the question of fuel costs and the question of pressure on the industry to constantly increase productivity to keep up with the cost pressures upon them because they are particularly exposed on the world market.
