The purpose of the amendments is to give each State organisation affiliated with the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation the right to select a State grower representative to the Board. The Bill in its present form makes provision for a Selection Committee of nine members. The composition has been dealt with during the second reading debate. Under the amendments proposed by the Opposition, the Selection Committee is to be divided into a core committee of four, plus five others-as I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage-with the five to be varied according to the purpose of the Selection Committee. For the purpose of selecting the Board members with special expertise, the Selection Committee will remain in the form proposed by the Bill; that is, to select the members with special expertise. Five nominees from the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation are to be added to the core committee.

The change proposed by these amendments is that five grower nominees from the State affiliate organisation of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation be added to the core committee to select the grower member from each State. For example, in New South Wales the core committee plus five nominees of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association would select the grower member from that State. This might seem to be an around about way of doing it. In fact, it may seem a fairly lengthy, illogical process unless one understands the nature and structure of the industry itself. It is a very diverse industry with diverse organisations representing the wheat growers in the various States. The day may well come when the industry itself would be happy to accept what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has proposed in the legislation. However, I believe that the change he is seeking is far too great. I think it is far too much to expect the industry at this time to settle for the proposition he has submitted.

The Opposition's amendments vastly improve the ability of each State to select its Board member. The industry jealously guards its right to select its representatives on the Australian Wheat Board, which after all is the body which has total control of the marketing of that product. On the whole the Australian Wheat Board has done an excellent job. I well remember the crisis that beset the Australian wheat industry in the late 1970s when quotas were introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Late 1960s.

—The late 1960s, rather, and early 1970, when there was a mountain of wheat around the world. There were great stockpiles both here and overseas. There was great concern both within the then Government and outside it that the Wheat Board had very little hope of making sales against the competitive elements in the United States and elsewhere. The truth of the matter is that the Australian wheat grower representatives on that Board did a tremendous job. They displayed enormous zeal and dedication to their task. They gradually secured new markets around the world and were able to dispose of the mounting stockpile of wheat in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Acceptance of the amendments would ensure that each State would have a majority say in the selection of its grower member whereas the Bill in its present form ensures that each State has a minority voice. It is not unreasonable to ask that the States have a clear voice in appointing their representatives to the Board. This becomes all the more important given that the selected grower members will no longer have a majority voice on the Board. I think that is very important.

I also make the point that the Australian wheat industry is spread over a vast land mass. There are and always will be regional considerations to be voiced at the Board level. This is why the Australian industry fought so hard to try to retain that membership of two from each State on the Australian Wheat Board. I feel that the Minister has pushed the Australian industry further than he should have dared. I really think that there is merit in his overall proposal, but to try to push growers from a Board level of 15 down to 11 in the way in which he has done is really to test his skill in handling what is a fairly delicate situation for a very important industry. It is an industry that will not be walked over. Governments have tried that in the past and failed. It is one of the most militant industries in Australia when stirred up. The Australian wheat growers are a very vibrant force in the Australian community. I think it is very important not to upset growers unnecessarily by rushing them into a situation in which they feel that as a result of this legislation they will lose their majority of grower selected members on the Australian Wheat Board.

It is absolutely imperative that the Australian industry have an effective, flexible Board which fully reflects the needs of the various States, apart from a Board having the expertise available to it under the amendments I have moved, which would include three representatives out of 10 with special expertise. There can be too many experts at any meeting. Having too many experts can bring about conflicting views, conflicting attitudes and very often cause more confusion than progress. I think those five practical grower members to be selected to that Board need to be totally representative and seen to be so by the various States. These amendments have the support of the industry. I strongly commend them to the Minister and to honourable members opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments. Nobody is more concerned with the grower representation component of the Australian Wheat Board than the Western Australian industry. It will always be that the Western Australian section of that industry will have a feeling of being terribly remote from decisions taken in this part of the world. Nothing was felt to be more so in this regard than the decision this year of the Australian Wheat Board to centralise its payments to wheat growers in Melbourne, whereas previously payments had been made on a State by State basis from the grain handling authorities. Let us hope that situation will not be repeated. However, this year was a disaster with people waiting literally months for their payments at a time when they were very severely strapped for cash. SPEECH.PARA: To save time in this debate it may be in my interests to add a few words concerning the proposed amendment of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I promise not to stand to speak again on that subject. The reality of what the Minister now proposes to reintroduce by way of an amendment is a return to the original Bill as introduced in the Senate. The Bill proposed an Australian Wheat Board built around five grower members, a grower but Government appointed Chairman, one straight out representative of the Government and four other members each of whom has had extensive experience at a high level in finance, marketing or industrial relations. That has since been amended to provide for three other members each of whom has had extensive experience at a high level in finance, marketing or grain movement logistics.

The Minister may, in introducing his amendment, try to tell the House why that fourth member was needed, when clearly and obviously that fourth member was intended to be a trade unionist. The Australian Wheat Board does not have a great deal of association with the work force. The Minister is well aware that grain handling is undertaken by the State grain handling authorities. They are the agents for the Wheat Board. The Wheat Board is a body which employs substantially fewer people, and certainly people who generally are concerned with industrial relations. These people have more of an executive capacity. The Wheat Board is a marketing organisation. It could be said that the Wheat Board never sees a grain of the wheat it actually sells. There is no need for that. That is handled by another group which clearly needs industrial relations expertise, which, of course, it employs. If the State governments which have some control over the grain handling authorities choose, no doubt they could introduce industrial relations expertise at that level. However, there is absolutely no need in the make-up of the Board for that fourth person to be put there. It is no wonder that the grower organisations are suspicious of that proposal.

I can only assume that the instructions came from the place from which the instructions for the tax package will eventually come and from the place the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and others get their instructions each day-the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is totally inappropriate to introduce this type of requirement into legislation relating to the Wheat Board. In other words, we should remove that totally unnecessary fourth person who certainly would not be there to advise the Board on any of its activities because that person, as I have pointed out, is not involved in that field. If a person of that capacity is not needed, why is the Government so determined to maintain the numbers at four? Admittedly, that gives the Board an odd number. However, I doubt sincerely whether there would be many occasions when the Board would be split five-five on a decision. I do not think it is a board that operates in that way. An even number of members would be all right. Presumably, in those circumstances, an additional vote would be available to the Chairman or he may not vote at all and that would bring it down to a four-five situation. All in all, there is no good argument against having an even number of members on the Board. There is absolutely no reason whatsoever to introduce somebody who has industrial relations expertise to assist the Board in the way it functions. It is not in that business. We ask ourselves: What is the Government on about? Unfortunately, it leaves me with the conclusion I have outlined.

In all of this the Minister is at pains to keep telling us how he arrives at wanting to do all of these things. The Minister has correspondence from me which goes back quite a way. It suggests that I have never opposed the idea of reducing farmer membership on the Board to five. That has never worried me. I can see that there is a saving in that particularly when one has to fly people all the way from Western Australia, provided there is a representative from each State on the Board. I understand that the amendment of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gywdir (Mr Hunt) ensures that that is the case. There are considerable reasons why that should occur.

At the moment growers in my electorate are deeply concerned at the cost burden that the inefficiencies and the industrial relations problems of the New South Wales grain handling system are imposing on them. Obviously, each State has some problems about the activities in other States; so all States want to be represented and that must be assured. Once we have achieved that I see no reason why the number of representatives on the Board need not be five, provided we remember that the Wheat Board is a grower organisation. Clearly, it will be greatly assisted by financial and marketing expertise of a special nature. I have said before in this place that quite often farmers in running their small local co-operatives have really tried, as farmers, to run a grocer's shop when they would have been better leaving it to the grocer. All of those are good reasons but they do not take away the fact that the grower must have the final say. It is his money. If he is prepared to elect people to represent him in handling that money, and they do it badly, that must rest with him. It is not proper for the Government to interfere. The Government might say that it needs to protect the situation because of its guaranteed minimum price commitment. However, that is well down the track. The guaranteed minimum price commitment only protects growers from a dramatic decline in price. A gradual decline in price, of course, does not help them at all.

The Government has, through its fully appointed member, a watchdog. The rest of the membership on the Board should represent the people who go out in the paddock, put crops in the ground and for that privilege pay the Government substantial amounts through fuel taxes. Of course, they take all the risks after the Government has collected the tax. That is not the situation that is needed. Those people, having taken that risk, should be entitled to have the final say in how their crops are marketed and they should have control even over the selection of the other members of the Board. But provided they have a majority on the Board, I see that as a satisfactory arrangement.

I support the amendments of the Deputy Leader of the National Party and I strongly oppose the amendment that the Minister will move to try to change something that the Senate has already decided would be much more in the interests of Australian farmers, that is, that each of the three members on the Board has extensive experience at a high level in finance, marketing or grain movement logistics. That is a function in which the Board should interest itself. It has certainly experienced problems in that regard in recent times.
The other day I was in Newcastle where the Chamber of Commerce Inc. drew to my attention-

TALK.START.PARA: —With me, too.

—Yes, I was with the honourable member for Denison. The two of us were very impressed with what the Chamber of Commerce told us about how it would assist the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales to get out of its problems. I am not an expert in that field; I could not say that its proposal is an excellent one but I do hope that the Minister is aware of it. The Chamber of Commerce referred to the area of the basin coal loader where it is believed that in 16 months and for something like $30m it could achieve what will be done in Port Kembla in four years for a couple of hundred million dollars, a substantially larger amount of money. Although the Chamber did not say that it wanted this as an alternative to Port Kembla-it was quite happy for the State Government to spend its money in Port Kembla if it thought it could create some jobs, or whatever its intention was-the Chamber did point out that it could give an answer immediately to the very difficult position of grain handling in New South Wales, particularly to the fact that it would be even closer to the farmers and would have better and more immediate transport arrangements. I take this last minute to draw that to the Minister's attention. He might choose to answer it. An amount of $150m a year is a huge cost to apply to the industry because of the problems of handling the crop in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a very good opportunity in the second reading debate to go into the finer details of the problems of the wheat industry and the changes to the Board. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 15 May.
Consideration of Senate's amendment.
Senate's amendment-
Pages 1 and 2, clause 3, line 11 (page 1) to line 37 (page 2), leave out of the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be disagreed to.

The Government's main purpose in introducing the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill 1985 was to provide for the number of specially qualified members of the Corporation to be increased from two to four. As previously stated, the Government decided to make this change because of the increasing complexity of international marketing of dried fruit, and in line with its objective of enhancing the effectiveness of statutory marketing authorities. The Senate has negated this essential thrust of the Bill by deleting clause 3 which would have substituted the new membership structure for that existing at present. The effect of the Senate's action, if accepted, would be to maintain the present membership structure of the Corporation, depriving it of highly desirable additional in-house expertise. The Opposition in moving for deletion of this clause stressed that, in 1978 legislation establishing the Corporation, it had reduced membership on the Corporation's predecessor, from 12 to eight to help contain costs. It noted that the Corporation is financed by a levy on the growers and said that, if membership were increased from eight to 10 as the Bill proposed, the growers would lose control.

The Australian Democrats support the idea of providing the Corporation with additional expertise but feel strongly on the point of ensuring grower control of commodity marketing authorities and fear that the membership structure proposed in the Bill would lead to bureaucratic control. I believe that the concerns expressed by the Opposition and the Democrats in the Senate in regard to the so-called loss of control by growers over the affairs of the Corporation stem from a misunderstanding of the situation and can be demonstrated to be quite unfounded. I will explain my reasons for this view shortly. However, first, I would like to address the Opposition position that addition to the Corporation's strength is unjustified because of the additional costs involved.

Over recent years the international market environment for dried vine fruit, like many other products, has become increasingly competitive because of greater government intervention in markets and technological advances. The most striking illustration of intervention is the European Community's production assistance policies and the regulation of the terms of access to its market since Greece entered the EC in 1981. The EC market accounts for half of the annual world trade in dried vine fruit. Also, competitiveness is increasing through technological advances which provide for improved volumes and quality of fruit for example, the ability to reconstitute and sell weather-damaged fruit which previously could not be sold.

These factors present greater challenges to the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, which is charged with the commercial role to promote and control the export of Australian dried vine fruits. To meet this challenge it is essential for the industry's sake that the Corporation be able adequately to meet the spectrum of commercial demands placed upon it.

The Corporation membership is already strong in skills related to dried vine fruits in terms of production, processing and, to an extent, marketing. The existing two specialist positions have traditionally been filled by industry packers. However, the infusion of two additional members from outside the industry with specialist skills in areas such as finance and marketing would inject fresh insights into the issues confronting the Corporation and would considerably broaden the experience and expertise within the Corporation membership. This would strengthen the Corporation decision-making base. When we look at the difficulties confronting the industry and the heavy dependence which the industry has on exports, I believe the relatively small additional costs to the industry will prove to be fully justified. I stress that the two additional members would not be bureaucrats. They would be chosen, after consultation with the Corporation, from highly qualified, experienced persons whose professional ability is recognised within their commercial fields.

I will now return to the question of grower control. There has never been grower control of the Corporation. In numerical terms there are four grower members compared with four other members, one of whom is the independent Chairman who has a casting vote. However, since the establishment of the Corporation, there has been a numerical superiority of industry members. The provisions in the enabling Act are that the four growers members are chosen from Australian Dried Fruits Association nominees and that the ADFA is to be consulted before the two other specialist members are appointed. As a consequence of the latter requirement, the two other members have in all cases been packer members of the ADFA. So it is a hat-swapping exercise.

The Government's proposal would not remove industry control. The proposal would ensure that the industry, through the ADFA, would continue to have a direct influence on the appointment of six of the 10 members by way of nomination and consultation. The Australian Dried Fruits Corporation would be consulted in regard to appointment of the other two specialist members. I urge the Opposition and the Democrats to recognise that the Government's proposal, to improve the effectiveness of the Corporation in an increasingly difficult world market, is in the best interests of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has returned the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill 1985 with an amendment. The Bill has been changed by the deletion of clause 3, which was intended to amend section 15 of the principal Act by constituting a new Corporation Board. The present Board has a membership of eight. The Government sought to increase it by two people but the Senate has refused this request. The additional two Board members were to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry and would have had a background in finance, commerce and marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1978 the Liberal-National Party Government reduced the membership from 12 to the present eight in order to streamline operations and reduce costs. It is quite illogical for the Government to be arguing on the one hand that the industry needs to contract its production against a world market oversupply and yet, on the other hand, moving to increase the size of the Corporation. Of course, since the Government said that, there has been an upturn in the world market situation due to a bad crop in, I think, Greece and Turkey. The international market scene for dried fruit is not as bad as people thought it might be.

On 8 May I stated that it would be disappointing to producers if they were no longer to have an equal say over their marketing arrangements. As with the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, I agree that the world market situation is changing rapidly and demands specialist expertise on the Industry's marketing body. This should not be an excuse to wrest control from the growers. They are the ones responsible for production of the annual $60m to $120m worth of dried vine fruits. They are the ones who should have a dominant say in the work of their Corporation.

As with the wheat industry, the dried vine fruits growers are prepared to accept an equal voice on their board. This, of course, has been the situation with the Corporation since the last changes were made. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) should accept the need to retain a strong grower voice and at least retain a proper balance or weighting for growers on these boards. With regard to the other Senate decisions, I express regret that the Australian Democrats were unable to join the Opposition in its proposed review of the equalisation payment limits in 1988.

With regard to the Bill now before the Committee the Opposition endorses the amendment proposed by my parliamentary colleagues in the other place and calls on honourable members opposite to endorse that decision, particularly in view of the absence of proper and meaningful discussion between the Minister and the Australian dried vine fruits industry. If there had been consultation on this and other legislation many of the Government's amendments, let alone the Opposition's and the Democrat's amendments in the Senate, might have been avoided. The legislation presented to Parliament over the past fortnight has been marked by a lack of consultation. This is a very sloppy way to deal with important affairs of state, in those very important rural industries that provide so much economic substance to the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), in the views he expressed in relation to the Government's action on the amendment that has been moved in the Senate. I point out to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that in relation to the numbers on the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation he was acting once again without consultation. He has been very inconsistent in the action he has taken in relation to a number of the rural boards we have been discussing. I point out to him that this industry is different from the wheat industry when we are arguing about the number of people on the board who are involved in the industry. The dried fruit industry is, in fact, two industries. It is made up of growers and packers. In arguing that there should be grower-controlled representations we are of course referring to the total industry, which includes growers and the packers, who are so important to the success of the dried fruit industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The representation on the Corporation is the least of my problems in relation to the changes the Government has made with regard to the dried fruit industry. I am more concerned about the fact that in the underwriting changes we are including in the scheme only the one variety of sultanas. We are not including currants and raisins. It seems to me to be a most undesirable feature of this new legislation to include only one variety of the dried grapes and not all the varieties that are produced. The area that is of most concern to me is the way the Government has treated the equalisation levy situation. I believe that in this area the Government is, like the Australian Democrats, playing politics with the industry.

I refer the Committee to the speech the Minister made in the second reading debate on the dried fruit industry. Unfortunately, he very clearly showed the intent of the Government on this issue. He gave an example of what he expects to happen to the prices of dried vine fruit on the domestic market. In that debate we pointed out the harshness of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill and the harshness of the adjustment that will take place particularly as the Minister has quite openly stated that he is trying to bring about export parity in relation to the domestic prices in this country. The Minister in his second reading speech suggested that $1,400 may be the level at which the domestic price settles. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that at present the Australian dried fruit industry is receiving some $2,360 a tonne as its domestic price on the local market. If this price were to drop by almost $1,000 as the Minister has suggested, as a result of this new legislation it will, in fact, destroy a major part of the industry.

One of the real concerns that the industry has about this legislation is not necessarily the number of people on the Board, but it is important in my view that the industry in total-the growers and the packers-retain its majority. It has done a good job. We need point to no other example than the position where a few months ago the industry was facing probably the worst crisis in its history. In fact, the Industries Assistance Commission report produced by the Government was formally buried in Deakin Avenue, the main street of Mildura. In just a few months, as a result of changing circumstances we have a situation where export prospects for the Australian dried fruit industry are now potentially the best since the early 1970s. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has said, this has been brought about by changing prospects for dried vine fruits throughout the world, particularly because of the crop shortfalls in Greece, Turkey and South Africa. This will reduce the competition for Australia's market share in the European Economic Community, Asia and Canada for most of 1985. Australia's other major competitor, the United States of America, has large quantities of fruit to offer on world markets but, once again, the continuing strength of the United States dollar is obviously going to constrain the Californian based raisin industry in having the same impact on the world market as on Australia because of its comparative advantage with our currency.

I will not delay the Committee any further. I simply say to the Minister that once again the problem of this industry does not relate to the number, type or quality of people on the Board. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) who is assisting me in this debate this evening recognises that the problems that exist within the industry relate to internal costs and not to the number of people on the Board. The Board over the years has done an exceptionally good job in very difficult circumstances. The coalition, when in government, reduced the number on the Board to enable it to become more efficient and more streamlined. There were people on it who clearly understood the needs of the industry. I see no real reason why the Minister needs to change this Board to such a degree. I see no real reason why the Minister will not accept an amendment that will give the industry, which has suffered very substantially over the last couple of years, some further support in ensuring that the equalisation levy does not bring about the same sort of harshness of adjustment to the industry as will the new marketing scheme and new plan for the dried fruit industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) will now run around with this $1,400 figure. I was giving an arithmetical example showing how 15 per cent could effectively become 48 per cent. There is no expectation of $1,400; it was purely an arithmetic example.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Senate's amendment be disagreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Resolution reported; report adopted.
Committee of Reasons
Motion (by Mr Kerin) agreed to:
That Mr Cunningham, Mr Brumby and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate, I bring up such reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Thereupon the Clerk read the reasons as follows-
The Senate amendment is not acceptable because-

This amendment does not take account of the fact that increasing competitiveness, and complexity, of international marketing in dried vine fruit due to intervention by governments and technology advances dictate the need for wide inhouse expertise for the continued effective performance of the commercial functions of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation (ADFC).

The Government proposal that there be two additional members from the business community, with specialist skills in areas such as finance and marketing outside the industry, would bring fresh insights and considerably broaden the Corporation membership and strengthen its decision making base.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985 seeks to replace the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Act 1976 with a new Commonwealth and States rural adjustment funding agreement. Under the new Act debt reconstruction and farm adjustment and development assistance will be provided by way of Commonwealth interest rate subsidies on borrowings by each of the States and the Northern Territory or commercial institutions. The existing legislation provides for Commonwealth assistance to be provided through loan funds and grants to the States. The term 'States' in the Bill refers to all of the participating States and the Northern Territory. The categories of assistance under the new scheme are essentially the same as under the present scheme. The forms of assistance covered by the scheme are: Part A-debt reconstruction, farm build-up and farm improvement; part B-carry-on finance, and part C-household support and rehabilitation.

SPEECH.PARA: Rehabilitation assistance is currently in part A. Under the new scheme it will transfer to part C of the agreement. Under part A, the Commonwealth will now pay an interest subsidy over seven years equal to 50 per cent of the interest payable on State or commercial borrowings. Under part B, the interest subsidy over seven years will be 25 per cent of interest on borrowings. Part C assistance will continue to be funded from the Commonwealth Budget.

The rural adjustment scheme was introduced on 1 January 1977. Prior to 1977 there had been a number of schemes providing adjustment assistance in the rural sector. The more recent of these were the rural reconstruction scheme, the fruitgrowing reconstruction scheme and the dairy adjustment program. The Fraser Government introduced the rural adjustment scheme following the Industries Assistance Commission's 1976 report on rural reconstruction which recommended that adjustment assistance be provided on a continuing basis under a single scheme operating under a Commonwealth-State agreement. The rural adjustment scheme can be divided in the following manner: Firstly, there are the main measures for farm build-up, farm improvement and debt reconstruction for those farmers who have 'sound prospects of long term commercial viability'. Secondly, there is rehabilitation and household support for 'non-viable' farmers who have been obliged to leave farming or are considering whether to do so.

The assistance provided to farmers has been provided dominantly in the form of concessional loans. The concessional terms have enhanced the long-term prospects of those assisted. The scheme also provides for any loans given to be reviewed at regular intervals with the objective of the borrower being encouraged to transfer to commercial credit as soon as circumstances permit. I would say that the scheme has been a tremendous success. It has helped with a lot of farm build-up and has helped many farmers around Australia who have run into financial liquidity problems as a result of drought and other reconstruction needs.

The Commission recommended that the rural adjustment scheme be discontinued as a generally available scheme for farmers meeting the eligibility criteria. The Commission recommended the assistance provided with each of the measures in the scheme be in the form of grants. The new scheme proposed by this Bill will provide the same forms of assistance as have been available, but under different financing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States. Parts A and B of the scheme are to be funded by State borrowings, the Commonwealth Government's assistance will be in the form of an interest rate subsidy. The Government's concern that funds provided to the States at concessional rates in the past have not been passed on to farmers at the same concessional rates, and at the non-use of surpluses so generated in further help to rural industries, is commendable. I think it is outrageous that some State governments have been pocketing the roll-over funds. I think that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is quite right in endeavouring to try to put a stop to this state of affairs. I know that one State in particular seems to have got away with about $100m and another one with about $30m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably those Nationals.

—I think there is a Labor State involved. The Nationals are not the worst in the world. I am not so sure that the Labor States are not the worst of the lot. The Minister had a very important responsibility to put a stop to this nonsense. I am pleased that he has and I congratulate him for it. The Bill provides for the Minister to submit an annual report to the Commonwealth Parliament relating to the operation and effectiveness of the scheme. The Minister is to base this report on the information supplied by the States at a review meeting for the purposes of monitoring and accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: Part A of the scheme will provide assistance for farm build-up, farm improvement and debt reconstruction. Farm build-up seeks to increase the size of properties which are too small to be commercially viable by either amalgamating them with adjoining properties or subdividing them and amalgamating the subdivisions with adjoining properties. Under these provisions, assistance may be granted in the purchase of an adjoining holding and in carry-on expenses, plant, stock and property development in respect of the additional land. The farm improvement provision aims to assist in the attainment of commercial viability by farmers by providing financial assistance to applicants to improve a farm's effective use without adding to its physical size.

Part C of the scheme provides for household support. This is a welfare-type measure which aims to provide limited assistance to applicants facing conditions of financial hardship who are considering leaving farming. This aspect of the scheme needs as much publicity as possible because undoubtedly a number of farmers throughout Australia are rapidly finding themselves in this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally, they can't get unemployment benefit. That is the reason for it.

—What the honourable member says is absolutely true. Therefore, it is absolutely essential for this provision to be available to sugar producers in Queensland, to the dairy producers in Victoria and other States and to the wheat growers. Certainly, as time goes on with this Government in office, there will be a beaten path to the assistance under this arrangement. The provision applies to farmers who do not have prospects of long term commercial viability. The amount of assistance provided in a year will raise an applicant's total net income to the equivalent of the amount received by an unemployed person in the form of the unemployment benefit. If the farmer who receives this assistance does not leave farming he will be liable to repay with interest the funds he has received. The assistance is limited to applicants who are obliged to leave farming and who face financial hardship. The maximum amount of assistance under this provision is set at $8,000 at 1 July 1985 and is indexed to the consumer price index.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has indicated the expectation that the level of Commonwealth funding for assistance under part A of the scheme will gradually rise over the next seven years from an estimated level of $1.75m in 1985-86 to a peak of around $12m to $13m. This is despite the fact that the Bill sets no actual amounts to be allocated, other than to provide that it will be determined after consultation between the Commonwealth and States each year on the basis of a total amount that the Commonwealth considers feasible to subsidise. In other words, the level of funding available to rural adjustment in this country has not only received a sizable cutback from the $30m provided for 1984-85 but also it is to be in the very risky situation of facing further restrictions in times of budgetary constraint. We all know the Government's attitude to rural Australia when looking for areas in which to restrain Budgets. It is worth mentioning once again that in the mini-Budget that came down last week very close to 77 per cent of the actual cuts in programs and expenditures came out of the heart of the rural areas of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—About 77 per cent. It is typical of the way in which Labor governments have treated the rural areas. Apparently, the rural areas are not voting enough for Labor so it gets to them with an electoral stock whip and gives them the one, two, three at Budget time. It is an outrageous state of affairs. The country people will not put up with it much longer. They will really turn on this Government and give it heaps. The level of funding available to rural adjustment has received a sizable cutback. There is not the slightest doubt about it. It seems incredible that the Government should now be decreasing funds for rural reconstruction and adjustment, making things even harder for State governments. These further cutbacks in funds for rural adjustment will serve only to leave farmers in economic suspension.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding those criticisms offered in a very constructive sense, the Opposition supports the legislation but must draw attention to the arrogant approach of the Government in failing to advise the States of the final content of the agreement until the legislation was brought before the Parliament. I have been asked to convey that message to the Minister. I hope that in the future he will undertake proper consultations with the States and at least send them a copy of the draft of the Bill before it comes into the Parliament. I think it is a matter of courtesy. I have had complaint that that was not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the States?

—From the State governments; I know there has been a lot of discussion at the officer level but the States did not receive copies of the legislation or the agreement until it was brought into this House, and they were not very happy about it. That is what the States claim. Without further ado, I say that the Opposition supports the legislation and will ensure it receives a speedy passage through this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Tuesday, 21 May 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When one considers the plight of many rural industries today, especially in the areas of sugar and dairying, one realises just how important it is that the rural adjustment scheme remains operative. It is also important that the deficiencies in the scheme brought to light by the Industries Assistance Commission in its March 1984 report are rectified. I therefore welcome moves to this end contained in the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin).

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1971 Commonwealth governments have been providing funds to the States and the Northern Territory to assist rural producers under highly concessional terms and conditions. I take the point raised by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) that it is regrettable and unfortunate, especially for those struggling in rural industries, that these highly concessional terms and conditions have not always been passed on by the State governments. I refer specifically to the Queensland State Government. Under the terms of the rural adjustment agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland the funds were lent to the State over 20 years at an interest rate of 8 per cent. Moreover, Queensland was required to pay back only 85 per cent of the funds borrowed and had a four year repayment holiday of principal.

The 15 per cent grant element in the part A funding program for debt reconstruction, farm buildup, farm improvement and rehabilitation was intended to cover bad debts and rehabilitation assistance. Despite the repeated claims by the Queensland Government that it has a special commitment to the rural sector there is clear evidence to demonstrate that for years the National Party State Government in Queensland has been robbing rural producers blind, robbing them of their just entitlements by way of the assistance under the rural reconstruction and adjustment scheme.

While the Commonwealth has forgone 15 per cent of money borrowed by the State, allegedly to cover bad debts, those debts have been extremely small. They have been minimal. The Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board annual report for 1983-84 indicates that the write-down of redundant assets, the write-off of irrecoverable debts and loans converted to grants, amount only to $114,873 for the rural adjustment scheme and $251,839 for the rural reconstruction scheme. In the six month period from 1 July 1984 to 31 December 1984 bad debts totalled only 0.5 per cent. Clearly, the Queensland Government has been making enormous profits out of the 15 per cent non-repayable component of the RAS loans. In addition to the straight out savings, the State has been pocketing the interest earned on the deposits held. It is no wonder that the Queensland Government has generated such handsome surpluses when it is realised that while it was generously lent the money at 8 per cent, it re-lent the money to the rural producers of Queensland at between 13 and 14 per cent.

Part of the agreement with the Commonwealth was that the State was given a four-year repayment holiday of principal. However, that moratorium was never passed on to the farmer. To make matters worse, even though the Commonwealth loan was over 20 years, the Queensland National Party Government locked Queensland farmers into short repayment periods. This is the way the National Party has helped farmers in Queensland-by providing high interest loans to be paid back over a limited repayment period with no holiday of principal repayments. It is no wonder that the Queensland National Party Government has been able to accumulate surpluses measured in tens of millions of dollars.

The 1983-84 annual report of the Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board showed surpluses totalling approximately $30m in the rural adjustment fund and the rural reconstruction fund. This figure does not take into account another $2m credited to the Consolidated Revenue Fund from the rural adjustment fund and another $8m credited to Consolidated Revenue from the rural reconstruction fund. The Queensland Government now intends to transfer the $30m into Consolidated Revenue, which represents a total effective loss of $40m for adjustment purposes to the Queensland primary producer. That is $40m of farmers' money that has been milked by the National Party to help hide its mismanagement of the State economy. Every primary producer organisation in the State should be in uproar over this rural rort. Their members are suffering but we hear very little. We hear no cries or criticism. Their industries are being short changed. The money should be spent, as the original Commonwealth-State agreement required on debt reconstruction, farm build-up, farm improvement and rehabilitation.

It is farm improvement and rehabilitation to which I intend to target my remarks. One of the major problems confronting rural producers across the nation is soil degradation. That is certainly true in Queensland. Yet, despite the serious threat to the State's rural and general economy, the Queensland National Party Government is lending soil conservation finance to farmers at 13.5 per cent, even though it is getting it at 8 per cent. There is no incentive for farmers to grapple with the problems; instead, there is a deterrent. Instead of adopting a proper land management plan where the farm is being developed and when the farm is being developed, the property owner is forced to work on a five-to-10 year plan. It is too late by that time. The erosion has occurred and the restoration is so often beyond the financial resources of the farmer. The Queensland Department of Primary Industry and water resources officers deserve the highest possible praise for their efforts but the State Government stands condemned for its lending rules.

A number of aspects tend to distinguish soil problems in Queensland from those in other States-erosivity of the rainfall, the erodability of the soil itself and the exceptionally large areas of land to protect. Queensland has to protect 1.4 million hectares of land, which any government would find an unenviable task. Present statistics indicate that 772,000 hectares are being protected through contour banks and stubble mulching, but that still leaves 47 per cent of the target area unprotected. As I said, full credit should be given to the soil conservation research branch in the Queensland Department of Primary Industry for its efforts to contend with, contain and counter soil degradation from water erosion and salinity.

Soil degradation from water erosion and salinity is the major constraint to the long term sustained productivity of Queensland's agricultural and grazing lands. The Queensland DPI conservation branch is now working on 23,500 farming establishments affected by erosion. That still leaves 48 per cent of farms with soil problems. Farmer co-operation is steadily increasing, but this much desired farmer involvement is not always forthcoming, especially in new areas or where farms have been recently expanded. It will only be forthcoming if financial assistance is available and if the loans are at a low interest rate.

At the risk of being further parochial I will quickly relate to some problems of central Queensland. I congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry for the assistance that has been given by his Government, through the national soil conservation program, especially the appointment of three additional soil conservation officers in Moura, Claremont and Emerald. Those officers, working together with the Queensland soil conservation branch, are grappling with the region's problems with a dedication that is unsurpassed anywhere in the country. I fear that unless further financial support is given to the farmers the battle could be lost. The ball is at the feet of the State Government now. It has $40m to play with.

The soils of central Queensland are generally shallow. There is less than 90 centimetres or three feet of soil to bedrock. The average is more around 60 centimetres. In the brigalow areas there is about 45 centimetres of top soil and below that a high saline subsoil. The soil in the region has been described as the most fragile in the nation. Because of summer cropping and the erosive rainfall, intensive soil conservation measures need to be applied. The region encompasses approximately 600,000 hectares of arable land, which give some idea of the extent of the task of protection. In the last eight years about 250,000 hectares have been protected with contour banks and land management programs. Despite this effort, there are enormous losses in soil tonnages. In fact they are frightening. In the April to June rains in 1983 the average soil loss on bare, unprotected land was 100 tonnes per hectare. Some farms experienced losses of 200 tonnes per hectare. It has been assessed that in some unprotected areas the annual loss is reaching 50 tonnes per hectare. When the loss rate is related to the shallow depths of soil, it will be appreciated why there are fears that some farming areas have a life expectancy of only about 20 years. More and more farmers are becoming aware that soil forms at only approximately l2 tonnes per hectare per annum and they see the battle against erosion lost unless help is given. So I again make the plea for cheap finance to these farmers.

The cost of earth works for contour banks is about $80 per hectare, which could entail expenditure of up $100,000 on the average property. The State Government has $40m, which means that 400 Queensland properties could be relieved totally of their soil erosion and degradation problems, or work could commence immediately on some 4,000 to 5,000 farming establishments. I call on the Bjelke-Peterson Government to overturn the decision of his Cabinet and his Treasury to siphon off that $40m. I call on Bjelke-Peterson and his Primary Industries Minister, Mr Turner, to make it available to the Queensland farmers so that they can finally redress the grave soil erosion problems in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: I use these arguments for two reasons. The first is to stress once again that, contrary to some Labor thought and feelings from the cities, the rural industry is not the great subsidy taker as some would believe, but actually suffers a penalty of $7,000 per farm unit per annum as a result of protection of the manufacturing industry. The second reason is to indicate that financial assistance through the rural adjustment scheme is justified if Australia is to maintain the present standard of living of all Australians and its place in the world markets through our exports and to help those farmers who fight not only the seasons but the Government introduced costs. They fight the costs of protection of manufacturing industries and the cost of the regulated, centralised wage-fixing system over which they have no control. These are the daily battles that farmers and graziers around Australia fight.

I refer as the best example I have to the present plight of the sugar industry, which has not had any assistance by direct grants but only a small amount from the nitrogenous fertiliser bounty. This industry, because it has seldom sought help in the past, is now being victimised by the present Labor Government which is seeking to deregulate, but the industry has been given no assurance of financial assistance, even if it does regulate to the extent of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics recommendations contained in the final Industries Assistance Commission report. Rural adjustment finance is not a subsidy because most of the payments through the scheme are repayable loans with interest, albeit at lower rates of interest depending on the circumstances of individual cases. I quote from the Australian Financial Review of 1 May 1985, giving the situation in relation to people in the sugar industry as far as their difficulties of finance are concerned. Queensland sugar cane growers, keeping up the pressure on Federal and State governments for the quickest possible decision on aid to the industry, released a survey this week suggesting two-thirds of Queensland growers have run out of credit with their bankers.

There is a need for Commonwealth and State participation in this funding. There is a need to make States more accountable, but there has to be at both levels of government some appreciation of problems that can be alleviated through the RAS. Rural reconstruction boards have to become more involved in individual applications. Blanket guidelines that limit assistance to $40,000 per producer are just not realistic. Again I go back to the individual State boards and suggest that they take a fresh look at their responsibilities and react accordingly because it requires the good will of both State and Federal governments if we are to maintain the exports on which Australia's economy depends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to implement the Government's decision, announced on 12 March 1985, to establish the Australian Customs Service-the ACS-as a separate identity within the Industry, Technology and Commerce portfolio. Before I detail the matters covered by the Bill I will take a few moments to mention some important background points relating to the Customs' functions. I know that honourable members are eager to hear this. The Australian Constitution gives this Parliament the exclusive power to impose duties of customs and of excise, and to grant bounties on the production or export of goods.

Administration of the Parliament's powers has traditionally been performed by the Customs. In addition to its role in administering these industry assistance measures, the Customs is charged with enforcing measures to control the import and export of goods and, on behalf of other agencies, the movement of people and ships and aircraft into and out of Australia. Customs has a significant role in the Government's overall strategy against illicit drug trafficking and illegal drug importation. More than 5,000 members of the Australian Public Service are engaged in customs and customs related functions. The majority of the Customs staff are located in custom offices in the States and the Northern Territory. There are in excess of 100 airports, seaports and inland sub-offices, staffed on a full time or part time basis. Representatives of the Customs are also stationed in Auckland, Brussels, Hong Kong, London, New York and Tokyo.

Responsibility for the customs function has, until now, been transferred six times amongst various Australian Public Service departments in different guises. For 55 years it was located in a department called Trade and Customs. It was for another 19 years in the Department of Customs and Excise and has been with the Industry portfolio since 1982. The Government believes that the Customs should now be established on a permanent basis with a permanent identity.

An important role of the Customs is to implement industry assistance measures. The close co-operation between the customs and industry policy areas of the Department arises from its present location within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce which has considerably enhanced its performance in this role. The Government does not wish to disturb this arrangement and it is for this reason that the proposed independent ACS will continue to be responsible to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

I now turn to the main features of this Bill. Clause 4 establishes an Australian Customs Service and the office of the Comptroller-General of Customs. The appointee to that office will, under the Minister, control and direct persons employed in the ACS.

The companion to this Bill, which I will introduce shortly, proposes to invest the general administration of the legislation to be administered by the ACS in the Comptroller-General. That legislation includes the various bounty and schemes and, of course, the Customs Act and the Excise Act.

By the provisions of clause 15 the Comptroller-General is to be invested with all of the powers of a Secretary to a department of the Australian Public Service so that he may have direct control over the staffing and other resources required by the Australian Customs. Similar to other statutory appointments it is proposed that the Comptroller-General of Customs be appointed for a period of seven years with salary and allowances being determined by the Remuneration Tribunal and the usual provisions relating to leave of absence, resignation, outside employment, portability and acting appointments being applied. To provide maximum flexibility for the recruitment of appropriate staff at all levels within the ACS, clause 15 of the Bill also provides for the staff of that body to be appointed and employed under the Public Service Act.

Two other important provisions in this Bill are clauses 16 and 17. Clause 16 will permit the Comptroller-General or an authorised member of the ACS to pass on, in very limited circumstances, certain information received by the ACS in confidence. (Quorum formed) This will be particularly relevant in connection with the Government's efforts to combat illicit drug trafficking. It will facilitate exchanges of information between the ACS and other law enforcement agencies in Australia and overseas. Under the provisions of clause 17 the Comptroller-General is required to furnish an annual report of the operations of the ACS to the Minister. The report will be tabled in accordance with normal procedure.

It is appropriate that I mention it is proposed that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the ACS will have separate management services and other support services. The sharing of such areas might initially seem attractive but experience has shown that, generally speaking, such arrangements are of limited effectiveness and practicability over any extended period. I mentioned earlier the importance of close co-operation between the industry policy areas of the Department and the Customs. It is essential that this be maintained. The Government considers that such co-operation should be placed on a firm basis by the preparation of a document detailing the working relationship between the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Customs Service. Such a document is currently being prepared and when appropriate I will arrange to have it tabled for the information of honourable members. The creation of the office of Comptroller-General of Customs and the establishment of the Australian Customs Service will provide a number of benefits, including relieving the Minister and Secretary to the Department of the routine of Customs administration with greater opportunity, in consequence, for both to concentrate on the major and complex issues facing industry in this country.
Financial Impact Statement

The measures contained in this Bill have no direct financial implications. The division of the support services between the Department and the ACS may, however, involve the creation of new positions within each body. Details have not yet been finalised. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Customs Administration Bill proposed to implement the Government's decision, announced last March, to establish the Australian Customs Service as a separate organisation within the general portfolio of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It has been a well known fact for some time, virtually from the establishment of the present Government, that the current Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), when he took over those responsibilities, saw little purpose in having to carry the onerous and sometimes time-consuming responsibilities of administering the Customs Act and the functions of being the Minister responsible for Customs while at the same time carrying the extremely heavy portfolio load of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It was on this basis that negotiations were conducted by the Minister and his senior officers with the Public Service Board soon after the Hawke Government was elected with the intention of achieving the establishment of a separate entity, as is now the purpose of this legislation. We must not lose sight of the fact that under the Constitution the executive power to impose duties on customs and/or excise and to grant bounties on the production or export of goods is a traditional responsibility of the Customs department. It is equally important to point out that after personal taxation, most indirect taxation is collected through the structure of the Customs function. In addition, its role to protect Australia from illegal imports of a wide variety of goods is a matter of grave importance, and as we have seen in recent reports tabled in this Parliament, and from other reports from royal commissions, there has been for some years serious concern about the capacity of the Customs Service to satisfactorily protect this country, especially from illegal drug trafficking and drug importation and distribution.

SPEECH.PARA: In relative terms the Customs Service is large. It has a staff of over 5,000 members who are under the Public Service Act. They are spread throughout Australia at all airports and seaports. They also have representation overseas, essentially of an administrative nature but they perform an important intelligence function as well. It is an undoubted fact that, over recent years, the Customs function has been somewhat akin to the ugly duckling of the Public Service. It has been transferred no fewer than six times among various Commonwealth departments in an effort to try to find an amenable home for it which would enable the officers within the Service to be able to function satisfactorily.

The Government's proposal to establish a permanent basis and a separate identity for the Australian Customs Service is generally supported by the Opposition. In addition to its other important responsibilities, the Service has to carry out and implement industry assistance measures which require that the new Customs Service maintain a very close relationship with the industry policy areas within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister, in another place, in his second reading speech, emphasised this fact. However, I must place on record that I have my doubts at having established a separate entity which will, in turn, automatically develop its own policy concepts and interests, that it will be possible to maintain the closeness of working relationship which the Minister obviously regards as desirable. Having the Customs Service continue to be responsible to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce may well not be enough, but time alone will tell.

Under the legislation, the Comptroller-General will have all the powers of a secretary of a Public Service department. He will have direct control over the staffing and other resources required by the Australian Customs Service. He will be appointed for a period of seven years with the salaries and allowances determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. Staff of the ACS will be appointed and employed under the Public Service Act. I note with some scepticism in the Minister's speech that it is intended that the department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the ACS will have separate management services and other support services.

While it may be true, as the Minister claims, that experience has shown that continuing with common services does create practical problems, I can assure the House that it is not possible to separate the administrative functions of these two organisations and at the same time come into this Parliament and claim in the financial impact statement:
The measures contained in this Bill have no direct financial implications.

Obviously, as has been stated, new positions at the administrative level will be created for the Service. In other words, we are seeing yet another example of the Parkinsonian principle being applied and very much at work. Administrative costs in the Australian Public Service have an inexorable capacity to spiral upwards and there is no doubt, whatever the administrative advantages may be, that the establishment of a separate, independent administrative arm for the ACS will, in time, become a major cost factor in the overall functioning of the Service.

Customs is responsible for enforcing the laws relating to the control and import and export of goods on behalf of other departments. It also is responsible for the movement of people, ships and aircraft into and out of Australian ports. Consequently it has a focal point of great importance for the security of this country. But the legislation in no way addresses any changes which might be required in the actual administration of Customs, nor are we told what the user benefits are going to be. The existing Customs Service is, in effect, a self-contained unit administered within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. There have been a number of difficulties with the Customs Service over recent years and inquiries which have resulted have touched on various aspects of the Customs Service. These include the Black inquiry into Mr Young's problems, importation of teddy bears and other likely things, the Senate inquiry into pornography, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Royal Commission on meat substitution, and the Mahony Review of Customs Administration and Procedures.

The financial impact which we have been told has no relevance will, as I have already stated, have a major impact because of the realities that additional staff positions and the duplication of functions between what will now effectively be two departments will obviously have a financial cost. A focal point in the Government's strategy to combat illicit drug trafficking and illegal drug importation will obviously be the role played by the new Customs Service. It also has a role to play in terms of illegal immigration. The Customs Service is of great importance in the overall collection of revenue, as I have already stated. In supporting the very preliminary steps to overhaul the Customs administration presented in the Bill before the House tonight, the Opposition stresses the vital role of Customs. Customs controls the import and export of all goods into Australia. It polices the traffic of illegal drugs into the country and illicit drug exportation. It plays a very significant role in raising revenue, which in terms of excise collection is estimated at $10.8 billion. In addition, it employs some 5,000 personnel. There has been widespread concern over the ability of the present system to perform these very complex functions, and it is believed that these initial procedures to establish an independent Australian Customs Service will go some way towards overcoming these problems.

The Bill creates the office of the Comptroller-General of Customs as the controlling officer of the Australian Customs Service and gives him the status of a secretary to a department. The legislation proposed by the Government tonight however, is somewhat unclear on the specific roles of the Comptroller-General, who takes over much of the direct responsibility of the Customs administration and yet is acting under the existing Minister; nor is the proposed legislation incisive in its proposals for the actual administrative reform that is so obviously necessary in this area. The legislation also fails to undertake a modernisation of the whole Customs Act to bring it more into line with current international and Australian commercial and trading practices, legal concepts and judicial systems, as called for by the coalition in another place. In this I echo my colleague Senator Chaney who has said in another place about the Opposition:

. . . can see advantages flowing to the Customs Service in having it as a separate entity, but we are concerned that the way it is being done and the actual justification have not really been dealt with in any serious way by the Government in putting this very important proposition forward.

It was these concerns that the Opposition endeavoured to have resolved through an amendment to refer the Bills to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in the other place. The Opposition called for explanation and justification of the establishment of the statutory position of the Comptroller-General, the relationship between this office and the Minister and its accountability, and a defined plan of administration and cost.

In its report on statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations established guidelines for the establishment of statutory authorities. We should support its approach that the creation of a new authority needs to be justified. The Committee recommended that a statement expressing specific reasons for preferring a statutory authority should be tabled with the legislation. It went on to recommend that, if such a statement is not tabled, or if the reasons given in the statement are not persuasive:
. . . the Committee will request that the Senate refer the legislation to the Committee for investigation and report on the necessity for the creation of an authority.

Therefore, it is not good enough for the Government to feel its way and to modify as it goes along some of the changes which will be implemented as a result of this legislation. The Opposition believes that legislation with such a direct and major impact should be thoroughly reviewed before any further inefficiency is allowed to creep into the Customs system. The errors of the past must be found and rooted out in all possible ways to ensure that Australia is protected and the personnel involved in Customs are able to carry out their activities in the most cost effective manner.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The House of Representatives, recognizing the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:
(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention-

(a) a delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament take part in the deliberations of the Convention, and comprise 12 members of the Parliament of whom 4 shall be members of the Senate and 8 shall be members of the House of Representatives;
(b) the 8 members of the House of Representatives comprise 4 members of the Australian Labor Party, 3 members of the Liberal Party of Australia and one member of the National Party of Australia.
(2) That-
(a) the Prime Minister and 3 other members of the House of Representatives, being members of the Australian Labor Party, nominated by him;
(b) the Leader of the Opposition and 2 other members of the House, being members of the Liberal Party of Australia, nominated by him; and
(c) the Leader of the National Party of Australia or another member of the House, being a member of the National Party of Australia, nominated by the Leader of that Party,
be members of the Delegation.
(3) That the Prime Minister or his nominee be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition or his nominee be the Deputy Leader.
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if-
(a) he ceases to be a member of the Commonwealth Parliament;
(b) the House of the Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

(5) That where, because of illness or any other cause, a member of the Delegation is not available to attend a meeting, or part of a meeting, of the Convention, the Leader or senior available member of that member's Party may nominate an alternative member and the member so nominated shall be a member of the Delegation for that meeting, or that part of that meeting.

(6) That, in the event of a member of the Delegation ceasing to be such a member, the Leader of that member's Party in the House from which that member was drawn may nominate another member (being a member of the House of which the first-mentioned member is or was a member) to replace the first-mentioned member.

(7) That the Leader of the Delegation from time to time makes a report for presentation to each House of the Parliament on matters arising out of the Convention, and that the Deputy Leader of the Delegation may make an accompanying report.
(8) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of the resolution agreed to by the House of Representatives.
